known_issues: Cross-references to specific books of Gregory's Moralia may require verification against modern editions
The work is a florilegium (anthology) drawing from multiple patristic sources, particularly Gregory the Great
Chapter 25 appears incomplete in this chunk; continuation would follow in next section
Some Greek transliterations may vary from modern scholarly conventions
Translation maintains Gregory the Great's characteristic dense allegorical style which may challenge modern listeners
The translation of 'throni' as 'thrones' and similar technical theological terms follows traditional English theological vocabulary
Some citations attributed to Gregory the Great and Augustine are compilations rather than direct quotations
Some biblical references modernized for clarity (e.g., 'I Petr.' to 'Peter's first letter')
Some biblical citations may have variant numbering between modern editions
Text ends mid-citation with incomplete reference to Paterius book 5 - appears to be cut off at section boundary
Heavy use of allegorical interpretation throughout - characteristic of patristic exegesis

This is the final chunk (4 of 4) of Taio of Zaragoza's First Book of Sentences. The text consists entirely of patristic citations (Gregory, Augustine, pseudo-Augustinian appendices) arranged topically. The work ends mid-discussion without formal conclusion, suggesting either manuscript damage or that subsequent books would continue. Chapter 40 on the Synagogue contains supersessionist theology reflecting 7th-century Christian-Jewish relations. Several complex theological concepts (predestination, beatific vision, modes of divine communication) require careful handling for modern audiences unfamiliar with patristic thought. The Greek term 'electrum' (Ezekiel's vision) is challenging—translated as amber/glowing metal mixture. Multiple long quotations within quotations made speaker attribution complex. Chapter title requirements met by describing content rather than just numbering (e.g., 'On Predestination' not 'Chapter 35'). Bible citations fully spelled out per instructions. Total estimated duration for entire work would be substantial given theological density—perhaps 6-8 hours for all four chunks at normal narration pace.
The source text contains multiple numbered sections (Num. X, etc.) that appear to be editorial annotations from the compiled edition - these have been retained where they appear in context
Chapter title derivations required interpretive reading of content since Latin headers were minimal ('CAPUT XXVI' etc.)

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: God's Unchangeable, Supreme, and Eternal Nature
chunks.latin: CAPUT PRIMUM. Quod Deus incommutabilis, summus et aeternus existat.
chunks.english: Chapter 1: God's Unchangeable, Supreme, and Eternal Nature

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (S. Gregor., Moral. lib. XII, c. 33, n. 38.) Solus Deus in semetipso incommutabilis est, quia solus habet immortalitatem: de quo per Jacobum dicitur: Apud quem non est transmutatio, nec vicissitudinis obumbratio (Jac. I, 17): ac per hoc quia in Deo mutabilitas non venit, nulla ejus lumen umbrae vicissitudo intercidit.
chunks.english: God alone is unchangeable in himself, because he alone possesses immortality. As the letter of James says: In him there is no change, no shadow cast by turning, from the first chapter, verse seventeen. And because mutability does not come to God, no shadow's shifting ever interrupts his light.
chunks.notes: From Gregory the Great's Moralia in Job

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid mutabilitas rerum nisi mors quaedam est? Quae dum rem quamlibet in aliud immutat, quasi occidit quod fuerat ut incipiat esse quod non erat; nam de incommutabili Deo scriptum est: Qui solus habet immortalitatem [Edit., immutabilitatem] et lucem habitat inaccessibilem (I Tim. VI, 6).
chunks.english: What is the changeability of things but a kind of death? For when something changes into something else, it kills what it was so that it may begin to be what it was not. But concerning the unchangeable God it is written: He alone has immortality and dwells in unapproachable light, from Paul's first letter to Timothy, chapter six, verse six.
chunks.notes: Citation adapted from 1 Timothy 6:16

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancti omnes per naturam in semetipsis propriam stabilitatem non habent. Sed dum immutabili veritati studiose semper inhaerere desiderant, inhaerendo agunt, ut immutabiles fiant; cumque ad hanc toto affectu se tenent, quandoque accipiunt ut supra semetipsos ducti vincant hoc quod in semetipsis mutabiles exstiterunt.
chunks.english: All the saints do not possess stability in themselves by nature. But when they earnestly desire to cling always to unchangeable truth, by clinging they act so as to become unchangeable. And when they hold to this truth with their whole affection, they sometimes receive the gift that, being led above themselves, they overcome the changeability they experienced in themselves.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Mor. XI, 29, n. 41.) Cum sit naturae incommutabilis Deus, in ira judicii perturbabilis non est. Sed plerumque humano verbo motus Dei dicitur ipsa rectitudinis ejus districtio, qua humana pravitas feritur, sicut per beatum Job dicitur: Statim ut se commoverit, turbabitur [Edit., turbabit vos], et terror ejus irruet super vos (Job. XIII, 11).
chunks.english: Since God is of unchangeable nature, he is not disturbed in the wrath of judgment. But often in human language, God's emotion is called that very severity of his righteousness by which human wickedness is struck down. As it says through blessed Job: As soon as he stirs, you will be troubled, and his terror will rush upon you, from the book of Job, chapter thirteen, verse eleven.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deus omnipotens, quamvis ipse sit aeternitas, qualiter tamen sit ipsa aeternitas ignoratur. (Mor. XVI, 43, n. 54.) In hoc namque quod de divinae naturae potentia audimus, ea nonnunquam cogitare consuevimus quae per experientiam scimus.
chunks.english: God almighty, although he himself is eternity, how he is eternity itself remains unknown. For in what we hear about the power of the divine nature, we are accustomed sometimes to think of those things which we know through experience.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omne quod coepit et desinit, initio et fine concluditur. Quod si mora aliquantula differtur ut finiatur, longum dicitur. In qua videlicet longinquitate cum quisque mentis oculos reducit retro per memoriam, tendit ante per exspectationem, quasi per spatium temporis dilatat in mente.
chunks.english: Everything that begins and ends is enclosed by beginning and end. If its ending is delayed by some duration, it is called long. In such length, when someone turns back the eyes of the mind through memory and stretches forward through expectation, the mind expands as if through a span of time.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cumque audit aeternitatem Dei, humano more intendenti animo longa vitae spatia proponit, in quibus metiatur semper; et quid abiit retro quod retineatur in memoria, aut [Edit., et] quid ante restat quod exspectetur ex intentione, humanae fragilitatis animus nequaquam comprehendere valet.
chunks.english: And when someone hears of God's eternity, the mind straining in human fashion imagines long spans of life in which to measure always. But what has passed behind to be retained in memory, or what remains ahead to be expected from intention, the mind of human frailty cannot comprehend at all.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 55.) Quoties in aeternitate praeterita aut futura tempora cogitamus, aeternitatem necdum cognovimus. Ibi quippe est quod nec initio incipitur, nec fine terminatur, ubi nec exspectatur quod veniat, neque percurrit quod debeat recordari.
chunks.english: Whenever we think of past or future times in eternity, we have not yet known eternity. For there is that which neither begins with a beginning nor ends with an end, where nothing is awaited that will come, nor passes by that must be remembered.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Est unum quod semper est. Quod et si nos et angeli Deum cum initio videre incipimus, esse tamen hunc sine initio videmus, ubi sic semper sine fine esse est, ut nunquam se animus tendat ad sequentia, ac si multiplicentur universa quae sunt et longa fiant.
chunks.english: There is one thing that always is. Even though we and the angels begin to see God with a beginning, yet we see him existing without beginning, where to exist always without end means the mind never stretches toward what follows, even if all things that exist were multiplied and made long.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per prophetiae Spiritum dictum est: Domine, qui regnas in aeternum, et in saeculum saeculi, et adhuc (Fortasse Exod., XV, 18. Vid. edit. nov.), more sacri eloquii humano modo Spiritus hominibus est locutus, ut ibi adhuc diceret ubi exspectatio non inesset.
chunks.english: Through the Spirit of prophecy it was said: Lord, you who reign forever and ever and ever, likely from the book of Exodus, chapter fifteen, verse eighteen. In the manner of sacred speech, the Spirit spoke to human beings in human fashion, saying ever where there is no expectation.
chunks.notes: The text notes uncertainty about the exact reference

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Adhuc enim aeternitas non habet quae semper esse habet. In qua nulla pars suae longitudinis praeterit, ut pars alia succedat. Sed totum simul esse est, ut nihil deesse videatur quod non cernat. In qua omne quod est, animus videt, et tardum non esse, et longum esse.
chunks.english: For eternity does not have what it always has in the sense of having it still. In eternity no part of its length passes away so that another part might follow. Rather, the whole exists simultaneously, so that nothing seems to be missing that it does not perceive. In eternity the mind sees everything that exists as neither slow nor long.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scriptum est: Dixit Dominus ad Moysem: Ego sum qui sum, et dices filiis Israel: Qui est misit me ad vos (Exod. III, 14). [In Ezech., lib. I, hom. 2, n. 20.] Esse etenim Dei est aeternum hunc atque incommutabilem permanere.
chunks.english: It is written: The Lord said to Moses: I am who I am, and you shall say to the children of Israel: He who is has sent me to you, from the book of Exodus, chapter three, verse fourteen. For God's being is to remain eternal and unchangeable.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam omne quod mutatur desinit esse quod fuit, et incipit esse quod non fuit. Omnipotentis Dei esse est dissimiliter nunquam esse. Solus quippe veraciter est qui solus incommutabiliter permanet.
chunks.english: For everything that changes ceases to be what it was and begins to be what it was not. But almighty God's being is to never be in a different way. For he alone truly exists who alone remains unchangeably.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. XVIII Moral., 50, n. 82.) Omne quod modo sic, modo aliter est, juxta non esse est. Permanere enim in statu suo non potest. Atque aliquomodo ad non esse itur, dum ab eo quod fuerat ad aliud per momenta temporum ducitur.
chunks.english: Everything that is now one way, now another way, is close to not existing. For it cannot remain in its own state. And in some manner it goes toward not existing, since it is led from what it was to something else through moments of time.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut ergo in participatione illius essentiae aliquid simus, cognoscamus nosmetipsos quia prope nihilum sumus. (Moral. IV, 32, n. 65, 67.) Maxima virtus est ad illud cui nihil venit, nihil praeterit, gaudium aeternitatis anhelare.
chunks.english: Therefore, so that we may be something through participation in that essence, let us recognize ourselves as being almost nothing. The greatest virtue is to long for the joy of eternity, toward that to which nothing comes, nothing passes away.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod nimirum Veritas semper esse suum, ut nobis utcunque infunderet, Mose mediante, ut supradictum est, insinuat dicens: Ego sum qui sum, et haec dices filiis Israel: Qui est misit me ad vos (Exod. III, 14).
chunks.english: Indeed, Truth, to pour into us somehow its always existing, hints through Moses as a mediator, as mentioned above, saying: I am who I am, and you shall say to the children of Israel: He who is has sent me to you, from the book of Exodus, chapter three, verse fourteen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum Dei incommutabilem situm aeternitatis Psalmista aspiceret, dixit: Tu idem ipse es, et anni tui non deficient (Psal. X, 28). Hunc electorum locum esse denuntiat, dicens: Filii servorum tuorum inhabitabunt ibi (Ibid. 29).
chunks.english: When the Psalmist looked upon God's unchangeable position in eternity, he said: You are the same, and your years will not fail, from Psalm one hundred two, verse twenty-eight. He declares this to be the place of the elect, saying: The children of your servants will dwell there, verse twenty-nine.
chunks.notes: Psalm numbering adjusted to modern Psalm 102

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deus summus, aeternus atque incommutabilis, qui sine situ omnia continet, nobis ad se venientibus locus non localis manet. Quem locum dum pertingimus, etiam ipsa in hac vita mentis nostrae tranquillitas, quanta fuerit perturbatio videmus.
chunks.english: God most high, eternal and unchangeable, who contains all things without spatial location, remains to us who come to him a non-spatial place. When we reach that place, even the tranquility of our mind in this life shows us how great our disturbance had been.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia etsi jam justi in pravorum comparatione quieti sunt, in aestimatione tamen quietis intimae omnimodo quieti non sunt.
chunks.english: For even if the righteous are now at rest in comparison with the wicked, they are not yet fully at rest when measured against the deepest rest.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: [CAPUT II] De immensitate vel omnipotentia Dei.
chunks.english: Chapter 2: God's Immensity and Omnipotence
chunks.notes: Chapter number supplied editorially

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 5, n. 10, 11.) Omnipotens Deus in semetipso habet sine mutatione mutabilia disponere; sine diversitate sui diversa agere; sine cogitationum vicissitudine dissimilia formare.
chunks.english: Almighty God has it within himself to arrange changeable things without change, to do different things without diversity in himself, and to form unlike things without any shifting of thoughts.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Longe ergo dissimiliter operatur dissimilia nunquam sibi dissimilis Deus, qui et ubique est, et ubique totus est.
chunks.english: Therefore God, never unlike himself, works unlike things in very different ways. He is everywhere and is wholly everywhere.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scriptum est: Coelum mihi sedes est, terra autem scabellum pedum meorum (Isai. LXVI, 1). Rursumque scriptum est: Coelum metitur palmo, et terram pugillo concludit (Isai. XL, 12).
chunks.english: It is written: Heaven is my throne, and earth is my footstool, from the prophet Isaiah, chapter sixty-six, verse one. And again it is written: He measures heaven with a palm and encloses earth in his fist, from Isaiah chapter forty, verse twelve.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex qua re considerare necesse est, quia is qui coelo velut sedi praesidet, et super et intus est. Et qui coelum palmo et terram pugillo concludit, exterius, superius et inferius est.
chunks.english: From this we must consider that he who presides over heaven as over a throne is both above and within it. And he who encloses heaven in his palm and earth in his fist is outside, above, and below.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut indicaret omnipotens Deus interiorem se esse et superiorem omnibus, coelum sibi sedem esse perhibuit. Ut ergo se ostenderet omnia circumdare, coelum metiri palmo, et terram se asserit pugillo concludere.
chunks.english: To show that almighty God is interior and superior to all things, he declared heaven to be his throne. Therefore, to show that he surrounds all things, he asserts that he measures heaven with his palm and encloses earth in his fist.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Aug. in Specul., c. 23.) Deus omnipotens ipse est interior et exterior, ipse inferior et superior: regendo superior, portando inferior; replendo interior, circumdando exterior.
chunks.english: Almighty God is himself interior and exterior, himself lower and higher: higher by ruling, lower by carrying, interior by filling, exterior by surrounding.
chunks.notes: Attributed to Augustine's Speculum

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicque est intus ut extra sit, sic circumdat ut penetret; sic praesidet ut portet, sic portat ut praesideat.
chunks.english: Thus he is within so as to be without, thus he surrounds so as to penetrate, thus he presides so as to carry, thus he carries so as to preside.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Intelligamus omnipotentem Deum intra omnia, sed non inclusum; extra omnia, sed non exclusum. Ideo interiorem ut omnia contineat, ideo exteriorem ut immensitate sua omnia concludat.
chunks.english: Let us understand almighty God as within all things but not enclosed, outside all things but not excluded. He is interior so as to contain all things, exterior so as to enclose all things by his immensity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per id ergo quod exterior est, ostenditur esse creator; per id vero quod interior, gubernare omnia demonstratur. Ac ne ea quae creata sunt sine Deo essent, Deus est intra omnia: verum ne extra Deum esset, Deus exterior est, ut omnia concludantur ab eo.
chunks.english: Through being exterior, he is shown to be creator. Through being interior, he is demonstrated to govern all things. And lest created things exist without God, God is within all things. But lest anything exist outside God, God is exterior, so that all things are enclosed by him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non ideo coelum et terram implet Deus, ut contineant eum, sed ut ipsa potius contineantur ab eo. Nec particulatim Deus implet omnia; sed cum sit unus, ubique tamen est totus.
chunks.english: God does not fill heaven and earth so that they might contain him, but rather so that they might be contained by him. Nor does God fill all things in parts. But though he is one, he is nevertheless wholly everywhere.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Apud Isidor., lib. I Sent., c. 2.) Omnipotens Deus cuncta potestatis suae immensitate concludit, nec evadendi potentiam ejus quisquam aditum invenire poterit, quia ille omnia circumquaque constringit.
chunks.english: Almighty God encloses all things by the immensity of his power, and no one will be able to find a way to escape his power, because he constrains all things on every side.
chunks.notes: From Isidore's Sentences

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Intra divini imperii [Ed., judicii] omnipotentiam cuncta coarctantur; sive quae continenda sunt ut salva sint, sive quae amputanda sunt ut pereant; nullatenus ergo dicimus effugere posse Deum quempiam.
chunks.english: Within the omnipotence of divine authority, all things are constrained, whether those that must be kept safe or those that must be cut off to perish. Therefore we do not say that anyone can escape God in any way.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui enim non habet placatum, nequaquam evadet iratum. De consummatione alicujus facti dicitur perfectio: Deus autem qui non est factus, quomodo est perfectus?
chunks.english: For whoever does not have him appeased will by no means escape him angered. Concerning the completion of some made thing, perfection is spoken of. But how is God, who was not made, perfect?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed hunc sermonem de usu nostro sumit humana inopia sicut et reliqua verba: quatenus id quod ineffabile est, utcunque dici possit: quia de Deo nihil digne humanus sermo dicit.
chunks.english: But human poverty takes this expression from our usage, just as with other words, so that what is ineffable might somehow be spoken. For human speech says nothing worthy about God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non ita putandus est esse in omnibus Deus, ut unaquaeque res pro magnitudine portionis suae capiat eum, id est, maxima majus, et minima minus, dum sit potius ipse totus in tota, ipse totus in omnibus, sive omnia in ipso.
chunks.english: God must not be thought to exist in all things in such a way that each thing receives him according to the size of its portion, that is, the greatest receiving more and the smallest less. Rather, he is wholly in the whole, wholly in all things, and all things are in him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dum localis non sit Deus, localiter tamen in suis ambulat sanctis, dum de loco in locum praedicatur ab eis. Nam Deus, qui nec loco movetur, nec tempore, in servis tamen suis et tempore et loco movetur, quoties ab eis praedicatur.
chunks.english: Though God is not spatial, he nevertheless walks locally in his saints when he is preached by them from place to place. For God, who is moved neither by place nor time, is nevertheless moved in time and place in his servants, as often as he is preached by them.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: [CAPUT III] De eo quod invisibilis vel incircumscriptus sit Deus.
chunks.english: Chapter 3: God's Invisibility and Unlimited Nature

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. XVII Moral., c. 27, n. 32.) Omnipotens Deus nequaquam claritate ab inferioribus cernitur, quia in superioribus dominatur. Scriptum quippe est: Caligo sub pedibus ejus. Ascendit super cherubim et volavit (Psal. XVII, 10, 11).
chunks.english: Almighty God is not at all perceived in clarity by lower beings, because he rules in higher realms. For it is written: Darkness is under his feet. He mounted the cherubim and flew, from Psalm eighteen, verses ten and eleven.
chunks.notes: Psalm numbering adjusted to modern convention

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cherubim quippe plenitudo scientiae dicitur. Proinde super plenitudinem scientiae ascendisse perhibetur et volasse, quia majestatis ejus celsitudinem scientia nulla comprehendit.
chunks.english: For cherubim means fullness of knowledge. Therefore he is said to have ascended and flown above the fullness of knowledge, because no knowledge comprehends the height of his majesty.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Volavit omnipotens Deus, quia longe in altum ab intellectu nostro sese rapuit. Volavit super pennas ventorum, quia scientiam transcendit animarum.
chunks.english: Almighty God flew, because he snatched himself far on high from our understanding. He flew upon the wings of the winds, because he transcends the knowledge of souls.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dum caligine nostrae infirmitatis obscuramur, per ignorantiam nostram nobis absconditur Deus, ne a nobis modo in aeterna et intima atque incircumscripta claritate videatur, sicut scriptum est: Posuit tenebras latibulum suum (Ibid. 12).
chunks.english: While we are obscured by the darkness of our weakness, God is hidden from us through our ignorance, lest he now be seen by us in eternal, intimate, and unlimited brightness, as it is written: He made darkness his hiding place, verse twelve.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral. XXIII, c. 19, n. 36.] Quomodo videre possumus incircumscriptam omnipotentiam, quam nequaquam comprehendere valemus? Est autem quod de usu carnis trahere ad sensum spiritus debeamus.
chunks.english: How can we see unlimited omnipotence, which we cannot comprehend at all? But there is something we ought to draw from bodily experience to spiritual understanding.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam si quis in tenebris clausis oculis jaceat, atque ante eum subitum lucernae lumen erumpat, clausi ejus oculi ipso adventu luminis feriuntur, ut patescant.
chunks.english: For if someone lies with closed eyes in darkness, and sudden lamplight bursts forth before him, his closed eyes are struck by the very arrival of light so that they open.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cur ergo turbati sunt, si clausi nihil viderunt? nec tamen perfectum aliquid fuit quod videre clausi potuerunt; nam si perfecte totum vidissent, cur aperti quaererent quod viderent?
chunks.english: Why then were they disturbed if, being closed, they saw nothing? Yet it was not anything perfect that closed eyes could see. For if they had seen the whole thing perfectly, why would they seek when opened what they might see?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum de incomprehensibili Deitate intueri aliquid conamur, eo ipso quod fulgore admirationis percutitur animus, et quasi videt quod videri non valet, velut in tenebris positus vim lucis oculis clausis videt.
chunks.english: When we attempt to behold something of the incomprehensible Deity, by the very fact that the mind is struck by the brilliance of wonder, it both sees and does not see what cannot be seen, like one placed in darkness seeing the force of light with closed eyes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. V, 7, n. 12; XXVI, 12, n. 17.) Auctor noster omnipotens Deus a nobis lucem suae visionis abstulit, et sese nostris oculis quasi in tenebrarum latibulo abscondit.
chunks.english: Our creator, almighty God, has withdrawn from us the light of his vision and has hidden himself from our eyes as if in a hiding place of darkness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deum adhuc videre non possumus; sed jam ad ejus visionem tendimus, si eum in his quae fecit miramur. Ejus ergo vestigia creaturam dicimus, quia per haec quae ab ipso sunt, sequendo imus ad ipsum.
chunks.english: We cannot yet see God, but we are already straining toward his vision if we marvel at him in the things he made. Therefore we call creation his footprints, because through these things that are from him, by following we go to him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde Paulus ait: Invisibilia ejus per ea quae facta sunt intellecta conspiciuntur, sempiterna quoque virtus ejus, et divinitas (Rom. I, 20).
chunks.english: Hence Paul says: His invisible qualities are clearly seen through the things that are made, being understood, his eternal power and divinity, from Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter one, verse twenty.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Menti humanae peccato suo exterius sparsae necdum Deus qualis sit interius innotescit. Sed dum facturae suae decus foris proponit, quasi quibusdam nobis nutibus innuit, et quae intus sequamur ostendit.
chunks.english: To the human mind scattered outward by its sin, God has not yet made known what he is like inwardly. But when he sets forth the beauty of his creation outwardly, he signals to us as if by certain nods and shows what we should follow within.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: [CAPUT IV] De Deo Patre omnipotente.
chunks.english: Chapter 4: God the Father Almighty

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Divinitatis incomprehensibilia sacramenta ab infirmitatis nostrae cognitione disjuncta sunt, ejusque potentia creatura transcendit naturam, quia celsitudo divinitatis nec coepit esse, nec desinit, nec per initium nascitur, nec termino coangustatur. Deus Pater omnipotens Filium suum sine tempore genuit.
chunks.english: The incomprehensible mysteries of divinity are separated from the knowledge of our weakness, and his power transcends created nature, because the height of divinity neither began to exist nor ceases, is neither born through a beginning nor confined by an end. God the Father almighty begot his Son without time.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXIII, c. 19, n. 36.) Et quis digne fari queat illam ineffabilem nativitatem, quod de aeterno natus est coaeternus; quod existens ante saecula genuit aequalem; quod gignente natus posterior non est?
chunks.english: And who can worthily speak of that ineffable birth, that the coeternal was born from the eternal, that he who existed before the ages begot an equal, that the one born is not later than the one begetting?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ev., hom. 25, n. 6.) Quae videlicet nos mirari possumus, sed intueri minime valemus. Illius autem nativitatis vim jam mirari posse, aliquatenus videre est.
chunks.english: These things we can marvel at, but we can scarcely behold them. Yet to be able to marvel at the power of that birth is already, in some measure, to see it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui Patre Filium minorem putat, Patri specialiter derogat, cujus sapientiam esse ei inaequalem fatetur. Quis enim homo potens aequanimiter ferret, si quis ei diceret: Magnus quidem es, sed sapientia tua te minor est?
chunks.english: Whoever thinks the Son is less than the Father specifically detracts from the Father, for he confesses that his wisdom is unequal to him. For what powerful man would calmly endure if someone said to him: You are great indeed, but your wisdom is less than you?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipse omnipotens Dominus dicit: Ego et Pater unum sumus (Joan. X, 30). Et rursus ait: Pater major me est (Joan. II, 51). De quo etiam scriptum est, quia subditus erat parentibus suis (Luc. II, 51).
chunks.english: The almighty Lord himself says: I and the Father are one, from the Gospel of John, chapter ten, verse thirty. And again he says: The Father is greater than I, from John chapter fourteen, verse twenty-eight. Concerning whom it is also written that he was subject to his parents, from the Gospel of Luke, chapter two, verse fifty-one.
chunks.notes: The text's citation to John 2:51 appears to be an error; the reference is corrected to John 14:28

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid ergo mirum, si ex humanitate sua minorem se Patre asserit in coelo ex qua subjectus erat etiam parentibus in terra?
chunks.english: What wonder then if, from his humanity, he declares himself less than the Father in heaven when by that same humanity he was subject even to his parents on earth?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omne quod loquimur transit, quod scribimus permanet. Lingua Patris scribae calamus dicitur (Psal. XLIV), quia ab eo est Verbum illius coaeternum ac sine transitu generatum.
chunks.english: Everything we speak passes away, what we write remains. The tongue of the Father is called the pen of a scribe, from Psalm forty-five, because from him is his Word, coeternal and begotten without passing away.
chunks.notes: Psalm numbering adjusted

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex persona Dei Patris David propheta ait: Ex utero ante luciferum genui te (Ps. CIX). [Ex Dial. Aug. ad Oros., quaest. 1.) Non quod Deus Pater uterum habeat sicut nos, aut corporeus esse credendus sit; sed per uterum substantiam intelligi voluit, de qua natus est Filius.
chunks.english: From the person of God the Father, David the prophet says: From the womb before the morning star I begot you, from Psalm one hundred ten. Not that God the Father has a womb as we do, or that he should be believed to be corporeal, but by womb he wished to be understood the substance from which the Son was born.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod est Pater, hoc genuit: Deus Deum, lux lucem, aequalem sibi Deum de Deo, Verbum apud Deum, Verbum Dei per quod facta sunt omnia. Lumen de lumine, coaeternum illi qui genuit, et unum cum illo qui genuit.
chunks.english: What the Father is, this he begot: God from God, light from light, God equal to himself from God, the Word with God, the Word of God through whom all things were made. Light from light, coeternal with him who begot, and one with him who begot.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ac per hoc Deus Pater non de nihilo, neque de aliqua substantia, sed de se ipso genuit Filium coaeternum.
chunks.english: And thus God the Father begot the coeternal Son not from nothing, nor from any other substance, but from himself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Aug. Dial. de Unit. S. Trinit.) Pater, et Filius, et Spiritus sanctus, nomina sunt appellativa. Licet Pater ad Filium, Filius ad Patrem dicatur, relativa haec nomina nuncupantur.
chunks.english: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are appellative names. Although Father is said in relation to Son, and Son in relation to Father, these are called relative names.
chunks.notes: From Augustine's Dialogue on the Unity of the Trinity

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deus autem nomen est proprium Patri, et Filio, et Spiritui sancto, sicut scribitur in psalmo: Secundum nomen tuum Deus, ita et laus tua in fines terrae (Psal. XLVII, 11).
chunks.english: But God is the proper name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit, as it is written in the psalm: According to your name, O God, so is your praise to the ends of the earth, from Psalm forty-eight, verse eleven.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ergo appellativa nomina Pater, et Filius, et Spiritus sanctus, proprium vero Deus, Deus, et Deus. Scriptum est: Audi Israel, Dominus Deus tuus, Deus unus est (Deut. VI, 4). In hoc testimonio trinam taxationem Dei univit. Dominus, inquit, Deus, et Deus. Habes denique quid Pater, quid Filius, quid Spiritus sanctus sit. Et mox intulit, unus est, qui est, in trinitate personarum unus Deus.
chunks.english: Therefore the appellative names are Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, but the proper name is God, God, and God. It is written: Hear O Israel, the Lord your God, God is one, from the book of Deuteronomy, chapter six, verse four. In this testimony he united a threefold designation of God. It says Lord, God, and God. You have then what the Father is, what the Son is, what the Holy Spirit is. And immediately he added, he is one, who is, in the Trinity of persons one God.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin:
CAPUT X
Quod ex humanis affectionibus quaedam species ad
Deum referantur.
chunks.english: Chapter 10: How Certain Human Attributes Are Applied to God

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Vis divinae majestatis, quae absque necessitate omnia creavit, sine despectu omnibus praesidet, et sine labore cuncta sustentat, et sine occupatione regit, et sine commotione corrigit. Sicque humanas mentes ad ea quae voluerit faciliter informat, ut in diversitatis umbram a suae incommutabilitatis luce non transeat. Ad humana membra divina verba condescendunt, ut factum omnipotentis Domini ab homine utcunque capiatur. (Lib. XVII, Moral., c. 2, n. 2.)
chunks.english: The power of divine majesty created all things without necessity, presides over everything without disdain, sustains all things without labor, governs without preoccupation, and corrects without disturbance. God shapes human minds to whatever purpose he wills, yet never passes from the light of his unchangeability into the shadow of variation. Divine words condescend to human terms so that mortals might somehow grasp the deeds of almighty God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sciendum est quod recordari Deus nequaquam proprie dicitur; qui enim oblivisci non potest, quo pacto recordari potest? Sed quia eos quos nos recordamur amplectimur, elongamus autem quos odimus, humano usu, et recordari Deus dicitur cum dona tribuit, et oblivisci cum in culpa derelinquit. Omnipotens Deus cuncta pensat, cuncta sine intermissionis alternatione considerat, et recordatur bonorum, quorum tamen nunquam obliviscitur: et nullatenus recordatur malorum, quos tamen per judicium semper intuetur.
chunks.english: We should understand that God is not properly said to remember, for how can one remember who cannot forget? But because we embrace those we remember and keep at a distance those we hate, we use human language: God is said to remember when he bestows gifts, and to forget when he abandons someone in their guilt. Almighty God weighs all things and considers everything without interruption. He remembers the good, though he never actually forgets them, and in no way remembers the wicked, though he always beholds them in judgment.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quasi redit Deus ad bonorum memoriam, quam tamen nunquam deseruit, et quasi nequaquam malos respicit, quorum facta considerat, sed super haec damnationis judicium in ultimis servat. (Lib. V, Mor., c. 18, n. 37.)
chunks.english: God seems to return to the memory of the good, which he never truly abandoned, and seems not to regard the wicked at all, though he considers their deeds—yet he reserves judgment of condemnation for them at the last.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nos cum irascimur, flatu furoris inflamur. Ut ergo vindictam cogitans Dominus demonstretur, flare irascendo dicitur. Non quo ipse in natura sua mutabilitatis vicissitudinem recipiat, sed quo post longam patientiam, quando vindictam peccatoris exsequitur, is qui in semetipso tranquillus est pereuntibus turbulentus videtur.
chunks.english: When we grow angry, we are inflamed by the breath of fury. So to show that the Lord is contemplating vengeance, he is said to breathe forth in anger. This doesn't mean that his nature undergoes any change or variation. Rather, after long patience, when he executes vengeance on the sinner, he who is tranquil in himself appears turbulent to those who are perishing.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Mens reproba, quia adversum suis actibus judicem conspicit, quasi commotus ei ostenditur, quia in conspectu illius reatu suo ipsa turbatur. Nostro usu Deus zelare dicitur vel dolere; horum quippe motuum apud Deum turbatio nulla est, apud quem tranquillitas aeterna est.
chunks.english: The reprobate mind sees the judge opposed to its actions, and he appears agitated to it—though it's really the mind itself that's disturbed by its guilt in his presence. By our manner of speaking, God is said to be jealous or to grieve. Yet there is no turbulence of these emotions in God, in whom eternal tranquility resides.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tam clementer Deus consulit humanae infirmitati, ut quia eum sicut est non possumus agnoscere, nostrae locutionis more se ipsum nobis insinuat. Unde et membrorum nostrorum qualitatem habere scribitur, et passionum indigna digna dici de se voluit, quatenus ad sua per nostra nos attraheret, et cum condescenderet nobis, consurgeremus ei.
chunks.english: God so mercifully accommodates human weakness that, because we cannot know him as he truly is, he reveals himself to us using our own manner of speech. That's why Scripture describes him as having bodily members like ours, and why he allows unworthy passions to be spoken of him in worthy terms—so that he might draw us to his reality through our own experience, and that by condescending to us, he might raise us up to himself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Multis modis Deus ad significandum se hominibus de inferioribus rebus species ad se trahit, quem revera juxta propriam substantiam invisibilem esse et incorporeum constat.
chunks.english: In many ways God draws images from lower things to signify himself to humanity, though we know that in his own substance he is truly invisible and incorporeal.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XI]
De mirabilibus Dei.
chunks.english: Chapter 11: On the Wonders of God

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. VI, 15, n. 18.) Omnipotentis Dei mirabilia quis hominum perscrutari sufficiat, quod cuncta ex nihilo creavit, quod ipsa mundi fabrica mira potentiae virtute disposita est, et super aera coelum suspenditur, et super abyssum terra libratur; quod ex rebus invisibilibus omnis haec universitas ac visibilibus existit, quod Deus aeternus hominem fecit, ut ita dixerim, in brevi colligens mundum alterum, sed rationalem; quod hunc ex anima et carne constituens investigabili virtutis dispositione permiscuit spiritum et lutum?
chunks.english: What person can fully explore the wonders of almighty God—that he created all things from nothing, that the very fabric of the world is arranged by the wondrous power of his might, that heaven is suspended above the air and earth is balanced above the abyss? The entire universe exists from things both invisible and visible. The eternal God made man, gathering in brief compass, so to speak, another world—but a rational one. In forming man from soul and flesh, he mingled spirit and clay through an inscrutable arrangement of power.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex mirabili creatura Dei aliud novimus, aliud sumus; sed tamen mirari negligimus, quia ea quae incomprehensibili indagatione mira sunt humanis oculis, viluerunt. Unde fit ut si mortuus homo suscitetur, in admirationem omnes exsiliant; et quotidie homo qui non erat nascitur, et nemo miratur: dum procul dubio omnibus constet quia plus sit creari quod non erat quam reparari quod erat.
chunks.english: From God's marvelous creation we know one thing and we are another, yet we neglect to wonder—because what is truly marvelous by any comprehensive investigation has become commonplace to human eyes. So if a dead man is raised, everyone leaps in amazement, yet every day a person who did not exist is born, and no one marvels. Clearly it is a greater thing to create what did not exist than to restore what once was.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia arida Aaron virga floruit, cuncti mirati sunt; quotidie ex arente terra arbor producitur, virtusque pulveris in lignum vertitur, et nemo miratur. Quia quinque sunt panibus quinque millia homines satiati, crevisse escas in dentibus cuncti mirati sunt: quotidie sparsa grana seminum, plenitudine multiplicantur spicarum, et nemo miratur.
chunks.english: Because Aaron's dry staff flowered, everyone marveled. Yet every day a tree is produced from dry earth, and the power of dust is transformed into wood—and no one marvels. Because five thousand people were fed with five loaves, everyone marveled that the food increased in people's mouths. Yet every day scattered grains of seed are multiplied into abundant sheaves—and no one marvels.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aquam semel in vinum permutatam videntes cuncti mirati sunt, quotidie humor terrae in radicem vitis attractus, per botrum in vinum vertitur, et nemo miratur. Beatus Job, cum diceret: Qui facit magna, adjunxit statim: Et inscrutabilia (Job. V, 9). Minus enim fuerat magna facere, si tamen ea quae facta sunt scrutari potuissent. Recte quoque addidit: Et mirabilia absque numero; quia minoris esset magnitudinis, si quae inscrutabilia condidit pauca fecisset.
chunks.english: Everyone marveled when they saw water changed into wine that one time, yet every day moisture from the earth is drawn into the root of the vine and transformed through the grape cluster into wine—and no one marvels. Blessed Job said, 'He does great things,' and immediately added, 'and inscrutable things,' according to the book of Job, chapter five, verse nine. It would be less great to do mighty things if those things could be fully examined. He rightly added, 'and wonders without number'—for it would be of lesser magnitude if the inscrutable things he created were few.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 19.) Sciendum procul dubio est quia divina miracula et semper debent considerari per studium, et nunquam discuti per intellectum. Saepe humanus sensus, dum quarumdam rerum rationem quaerens non invenit, in dubitationis se voraginem mergit.
chunks.english: We should understand beyond doubt that divine miracles must always be contemplated with diligence but never dissected by the intellect. Often the human mind, when it seeks the explanation of certain things and cannot find it, plunges itself into a whirlpool of doubt.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde fit ut nonnulli homines mortuorum corpora in pulverem redacta considerent; dumque resurrectionis vim colligere ex ratione non possunt, haec ad statum pristinum redire desperent. Miracula Dei, quae ex fide credenda sunt, perscrutanda per rationem non sunt; quia si haec nostris oculis ratio expanderet, mira non essent.
chunks.english: Some people consider how the bodies of the dead are reduced to dust, and because they cannot grasp the power of resurrection through reason, they despair that these bodies could return to their former state. God's miracles, which must be believed through faith, are not to be examined through reason—for if reason could fully explain them to our eyes, they would not be marvelous.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum in Dei mirabilibus fortasse animus titubat, necesse est ut ea quae per usum novit, nec tamen per rationem colligit, ad memoriam reducat; quatenus rei similis argumento fidem roboret, quam labefactari sua sagacitate deprehendit.
chunks.english: When the mind perhaps stumbles over God's wonders, it must recall to memory those things it knows through experience yet cannot grasp through reason—so that through the argument from similar cases, it may strengthen the faith it perceives to be weakened by its own cleverness.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Creation and Confirmation of the Angels
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XII]
De conaitione vel perpetuitate angelorum, seu ruina superbientium.
chunks.english: Chapter 12: On the Creation and Permanence of the Angels and the Fall of the Proud

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tales creati sunt angeli ut, si vellent, in beatitudinis luce persisterent; si autem nollent, etiam labi potuissent. Unde et Satan cum sequacibus legionibus cecidit; sed post ejus lapsum ita confortati sunt angeli qui perstiterunt, ut cadere omnino non possent.
chunks.english: The angels were created in such a way that, if they willed it, they could persist in the light of blessedness, but if they did not will it, they could also fall. Thus Satan fell with his legions of followers. But after his fall, the angels who persisted were so strengthened that they could no longer fall at all.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. XXVII Mor., c. 39, n. 65.) Virtutes angelicae quae in divino amore fixae perstiterunt, lapsis superbientibus angelis, hoc in munere retributionis acceperunt, ut nulla jam rubigine subripientis culpae mordeantur, ut in contemplatione Conditoris sine felicitatis fine permaneant, et in hoc quod sunt conditae aeterna stabilitate subsistant.
chunks.english: The angelic powers that persisted fixed in divine love, when the proud angels fell, received this gift as their reward: they are no longer bitten by any rust of creeping sin, they remain in contemplation of the Creator without end of happiness, and they continue in eternal stability in what they were created to be.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Apud Moysen (Gen. I, 6) de ipsa mundi historica verba testantur origine, cum prius factum coelum dicitur, et hoc idem postmodum firmamentum vocatur; quia videlicet natura angelica, et prius subtilis est in superioribus condita, et post, ne unquam potuisset cadere, mirabilius confirmata.
chunks.english: In Moses, according to the book of Genesis, chapter one, verse six, the historical words testify about the very origin of the world, when heaven is said to have been made first and the same thing is later called the firmament. This is because the angelic nature was first created in its subtle form in the heights, and afterward was more wondrously confirmed so that it could never fall.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancti angeli, dum in aliis cadentibus naturae suae damna conspiciunt, in se ipsis jam cautius robustiusque consistunt. (Moral. XXXIV, 7, n. 13.) Unde fit, auctore rerum Domino cuncta mirabiliter ordinante, ut illi electorum spirituum patriae etiam de ruinae suae damno proficiat, dum inde firmius constructa est unde fuerat ex parte destructa.
chunks.english: When the holy angels see the loss of their nature in others who are falling, they stand more cautiously and strongly in themselves. Thus it happens, with the Lord ordering all things wondrously, that the homeland of the elect spirits profited even from the loss of its ruin, since it was more firmly built up from the very thing by which it had been partly destroyed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Angelo primo ab arce beatitudinis cadente, certum est in ruina ejus etiam electos angelos expavisse. (Num. 12.) Ut cum istum ex illorum numero superbiae lapsus ejiceret, illos ad robustius standum timor ipse solidaret. De apostata angelo scriptum est: Cum sublatus fuerit, timebunt angeli, et territi purgabuntur (Job. XLI, 16). Purgati enim sunt; quia nimirum isto cum reprobis legionibus exeunte, soli in coelestibus sedibus qui beate viverent remanserunt.
chunks.english: When the first angel fell from the citadel of blessedness, it is certain that even the elect angels trembled at his ruin. The fall itself through pride cast him out from their number, while fear itself strengthened the others to stand more firmly. It is written of the apostate angel, according to the book of Job, chapter forty-one, verse sixteen, 'When he is taken away, the angels will fear and, terrified, will be purified.' They were indeed purified, because when he departed with the reprobate legions, only those who would live blessedly remained in the heavenly thrones.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 13.) Lapsus Satanae angelos bonos et terruit et purgavit: terruit, ne Conditorem suum superbe despicerent; purgavit vero, quia exeuntibus reprobis, actum est ut electi soli remanerent.
chunks.english: The fall of Satan both terrified and purified the good angels. It terrified them so they would not proudly despise their Creator. It purified them because, with the reprobate departing, it brought about that the elect alone remained.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cunctorum opifex Deus, qui scit ad bonorum custodiam bene uti etiam mala actione reproborum, lapsum angelorum cadentium vertit in profectum manentium, et unde punita est culpa superbientium, inde humilibus angelis inventa et solidata sunt augmenta meritorum: quoniam istis cadentibus, illis in munere datum est ut cadere omnino non possent.
chunks.english: God, the maker of all, who knows how to use even the evil actions of the reprobate for the protection of the good, turned the fall of the falling angels into the advancement of those who remained. The very thing that punished the guilt of the proud became the source by which increases of merit were found and established for the humble angels. When the proud fell, it was given as a gift to the humble that they could not fall at all.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XXXII, c. 23, n. 47, 48.) Primus ille apostata angelus idcirco ad multa fortiter sufficit, quia in natura rerum hunc per substantiam conditor primum fecit; sicut in libro Job scriptum est: Ipse est principium viarum Dei (Job XL, 14): quia nimirum cum cuncta Deus faceret, hunc primum condidit, quem reliquis angelis eminentiorem fecit.
chunks.english: That first apostate angel is able to accomplish much through strength because the Creator made him first in substance among the nature of things, as it is written in the book of Job, chapter forty, verse fourteen, 'He is the beginning of the ways of God.' Indeed, when God made all things, he created this one first and made him preeminent over the other angels.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui speciosus factus in multis, condensisque frondibus dicitur, quia praelatum caeteris angelorum legionibus, tanta illum species pulchriorem reddidit, quanta et supposita multitudo angelorum decoravit. Apostata angelus in paradiso Dei tot quasi condensas frondes habuit, quot sub se positas supernorum spirituum legiones attendit.
chunks.english: He is said to have been made beautiful in many dense leaves, because having been placed over the other legions of angels, his appearance made him as much more beautiful as the multitude of angels placed beneath him adorned him. The apostate angel in God's paradise had as many dense leaves, so to speak, as he had legions of higher spirits placed under him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui et ideo peccans sine venia damnatus est, quia magnus sine comparatione fuerat creatus. Apostatae angelo per Ezechielem prophetam dicitur: Tu signaculum similitudinis Dei plenus sapientia, perfectus decore, in paradiso Dei fuisti (Ezech. XXVIII., 12, 13). Multa enim de ejus magnitudine locuturus, primo verbo cuncta complexus est.
chunks.english: He was condemned without pardon when he sinned because he had been created great beyond comparison. To the apostate angel it is said through the prophet Ezekiel, according to the book of Ezekiel, chapter twenty-eight, verses twelve and thirteen, 'You were the seal of the likeness of God, full of wisdom, perfect in beauty, you were in the paradise of God.' The prophet, about to speak much of his greatness, embraced everything in the first word.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid primus angelus boni non habuit, si signaculum Dei similitudinis fuit? De sigillo quippe annuli talis similitudo imaginaliter exprimitur, qualis in sigillo eodem substantialiter habetur. Et licet ad similitudinem Dei homo creatus sit, apostatae tamen angelo quasi majus aliquid tribuens, non eum ad similitudinem Dei conditum, sed ipsum signaculum Dei similitudinis dicit; ut quo subtilior est natura, eo in illo similitudo Dei plenius credatur expressa.
chunks.english: What good did the first angel not possess, if he was the seal of God's likeness? From the seal of a ring, such a likeness is expressed in image as is possessed substantially in the seal itself. And although man was created in the likeness of God, the text attributes something greater, as it were, to the apostate angel: it doesn't say he was made in God's likeness but that he was the very seal of God's likeness—so that the more subtle his nature, the more fully the likeness of God is believed to be expressed in him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Apostatae angeli principatus celsitudinem adhuc Ezechiel propheta intuens, adjungit: Tu Cherub extentus, et protegens in monte sancto Dei, in medio lapidum ignitorum perfectus ambulasti (Ezech. XXVIII, 14). Cherub quippe plenitudo scientiae interpretatur; et idcirco iste Cherub dicitur quia transcendisse cunctos angelos scientia non dubitatur.
chunks.english: The prophet Ezekiel, still contemplating the loftiness of the apostate angel's principality, adds, according to the book of Ezekiel, chapter twenty-eight, verse fourteen, 'You were an extended cherub, protecting, on the holy mountain of God; you walked perfect in the midst of fiery stones.' Cherub is interpreted as fullness of knowledge, and he is called cherub because he is understood to have surpassed all angels in knowledge.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui in medio ignitorum lapidum perfectus ambulavit, quia inter angelorum agmina [Edit., corda] charitatis igne succensa clarus gloria conditionis exstitit. (Num. 49.) De apostata angelo idcirco tam mira in quibus fuit et quae amisit propheta insinuat, ut territo homini ostendat quid ipse, si superbiat, de elationis culpa passurus sit, si feriendo illi parcere noluit quem creando in gloriam tantae claritatis elevavit.
chunks.english: He walked perfect in the midst of fiery stones because among the armies of angels, hearts kindled by the fire of charity, he stood out bright in the glory of his creation. The prophet reveals such marvelous things about what the apostate angel was and what he lost, in order to show terrified humanity what it will suffer for the guilt of pride if it becomes proud—since God did not spare in striking the one he elevated in creation to such glory and brilliance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. IV, c. 1, n. 5.) Angelicus spiritus, sive humana anima ita immortalis est, ut mori possit; ita mortalis, ut mori non possit. Nam beate vivere desinit, si se per vitium, seu per supplicium perdit. Essentialiter autem vivere, neque per vitium, neque per supplicium amittit.
chunks.english: The angelic spirit, or the human soul, is immortal in such a way that it can die, yet mortal in such a way that it cannot die. For it ceases to live blessedly if it loses itself through vice or through punishment. But it does not lose essential life either through vice or through punishment.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: A qualitate autem vivendi deficit, sed omni modo subsistendi interitum nec moriens sentit. Ut ergo breviter dixerim, et immortaliter mortalis est, et mortaliter immortalis. Electi angelorum spiritus, dum alios per superbiam cecidisse conspicerent, ipsi tanto robustius quanto humilius steterunt, quia illi supernae regionis accolae sua etiam detrimenta profecerunt, quae ad aeternitatis statum ex parte suae destructionis est solidius instructa.
chunks.english: It loses the quality of living, but even in dying it does not experience the destruction of subsisting in every mode. To put it briefly: it is immortally mortal and mortally immortal. When the elect spirits of the angels saw others fall through pride, they stood all the more firmly the more humbly they stood. Those inhabitants of the heavenly region profited even from their losses, being more solidly established in the state of eternity through part of their destruction.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XIII]
De novem ordinibus angelorum.
chunks.english: Chapter 13: On the Nine Orders of Angels

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XVII, c. 13, n. 18.) In cognitione humanae rationis supernorum spirituum numerus non est, quia quanta sit illa frequentia invisibilis exercitus nescit, de qua recte dicitur: Millia millium ministrabant ei, et decies millies centena millia assistebant ei (Dan. VII, 10). Supernorum civium numerus infinitus et definitus exprimitur, ut qui Deo est numerabilis esse nobis innumerabilis demonstretur.
chunks.english: The number of heavenly spirits is beyond the knowledge of human reason, because we do not know how great that multitude of the invisible army is, of which it is rightly said, according to the book of Daniel, chapter seven, verse ten, 'Thousands of thousands ministered to him, and ten thousand times ten thousand stood before him.' The number of heavenly citizens is expressed as both infinite and definite, so that what is countable to God is shown to be countless to us.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aliud est assistere, aliud ministrare. Assistunt enim Deo illae procul dubio angelicae potestates quae ad quaedam nuntianda hominibus non exeunt. Ministrant vero hi qui ad explenda officia nuntiorum veniunt: sed tamen ipsi per contemplationem ab intimis non recedunt. Et quia plures sunt qui ministrant quam hi qui principaliter assistunt, assistentium numerus quasi definitus, ministrantium vero indefinitus ostenditur.
chunks.english: To assist is one thing, to minister is another. Those angelic powers assist God who do not go out to announce certain messages to humanity. Those minister who come to fulfill the duties of messengers, yet even they do not depart from the innermost things through contemplation. And because more minister than principally assist, the number of those assisting is shown as defined, while the number of those ministering is shown as indefinite.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 2, n. 14.) Isaias propheta dicit: Vidi Dominum sedentem super solium excelsum et elevatum (Isai. VI, 1). Solium Dei est creatura angelica vel humana, cui per intellectum, quem dedit, praesidet: quod videlicet solium excelsum et elevatum dicit; quia et natura humana ad coelestem gloriam elevata proficit, et creatura angelica, dum multis spiritibus cadentibus jam solidata est in coelo ne cadat, inde elevata est unde confirmata.
chunks.english: The prophet Isaiah says, according to the book of Isaiah, chapter six, verse one, 'I saw the Lord seated upon a high and elevated throne.' God's throne is the angelic or human creature over which he presides through the understanding he gave it. He calls it a high and elevated throne because human nature advances when elevated to heavenly glory, and the angelic creature, now solidified in heaven so as not to fall while many spirits were falling, was elevated from the very source from which it was confirmed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Templum vero ejus hoc est quod solium, quia aeternus Rex ibi habitat ubi sedet. (Lib. II in Evang. homil. 34, n. 6, 7.) Angelorum et hominum naturam ad cognoscendum se Dominus condidit: quam dum consistere ad aeternitatem voluit, eam procul dubio ad suam similitudinem creavit.
chunks.english: His temple is the same as his throne, because the eternal King dwells where he sits. The Lord created the nature of angels and humans to know him. When he willed them to endure to eternity, he created them without doubt in his own likeness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Novem sunt ordines angelorum. Sed ut compleretur electorum numerus, homo decimus est creatus; qui a Conditore suo nec post culpam periit, quia hunc aeterna sapientia per carnem miraculis coruscans ex lumine testae reparavit.
chunks.english: There are nine orders of angels. But so that the number of the elect might be completed, man was created as the tenth. Man did not perish from his Creator even after sin, because eternal Wisdom, flashing with miracles through the flesh, restored him from the light of the earthen vessel.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Novem ordines angelorum diximus, quia videlicet testante sacro eloquio esse scimus, angelos, archangelos, virtutes, potestates, principatus, dominationes, thronos, cherubim, atque seraphim. Esse quidem angelos et archangelos pene omnes sacri eloquii paginae testantur: sed et cherubim atque seraphim saepe, ut notum est, libri prophetarum loquuntur.
chunks.english: We said there are nine orders of angels because sacred Scripture testifies that there exist angels, archangels, virtues, powers, principalities, dominations, thrones, cherubim, and seraphim. Nearly all pages of sacred Scripture testify that there are indeed angels and archangels, and the books of the prophets often speak, as is well known, of cherubim and seraphim.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quatuor quoque ordinum nomina Paulus apostolus ad Ephesios enumerat, dicens: Supra omnem principatum, et potestatem, et virtutem, et dominationem (Ephes. I, 21). Ita ad Colossenses ait: Sive throni, sive dominationes, sive principatus, sive potestates (Coloss. I, 16).
chunks.english: The apostle Paul enumerates the names of four orders in his letter to the Ephesians, chapter one, verse twenty-one, saying, 'Above every principality and power and virtue and domination.' Likewise he says in his letter to the Colossians, chapter one, verse sixteen, 'Whether thrones or dominations or principalities or powers.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dominationes vero, principatus atque potestates, jam ad Ephesios loquens descripserat; sed ea quoque Colossensibus dicturus praemisit thronos, de quibus necdum quidquam fuerat Ephesiis locutus. Dum ergo illis quatuor quae ad Ephesios ante dixit, id est, principatibus, potestatibus, virtutibus atque dominationibus conjunguntur throni, quinque sunt ordines qui specialiter exprimuntur.
chunks.english: He had already described dominations, principalities, and powers when speaking to the Ephesians, but when about to speak to the Colossians, he added thrones, about which he had not yet said anything to the Ephesians. Therefore, when thrones are joined to those four he mentioned earlier to the Ephesians—that is, principalities, powers, virtues, and dominations—there are five orders that are specifically expressed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quibus dum angeli et archangeli, cherubim atque seraphim adjuncta sunt, procul dubio novem esse ordines angelorum inveniuntur. Ipsi angelo qui primus est conditus per prophetam dicitur: Tu cherub signaculum similitudinis plenus sapientia, perfectus decore, in deliciis paradisi Dei fuisti (Ezech. XXVIII, 12).
chunks.english: When angels and archangels, cherubim and seraphim are added to these, there are found without doubt to be nine orders of angels. To the angel who was created first it is said through the prophet, according to the book of Ezekiel, chapter twenty-eight, verse twelve, 'You were a cherub, the seal of likeness, full of wisdom, perfect in beauty, you were in the delights of God's paradise.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ubi notandum est quia non ad similitudinem Dei factus, sed signaculum similitudinis dicitur; ut quo in eo subtilior est natura, eo in illum imago Dei similius insinuetur expressa. Quo in loco mox subditur: Omnis lapis pretiosus operimentum tuum: sardius, topazius, jaspis, chrysolithus, onyx, beryllus, sapphirus, carbunculus, et smaragdus (Ibid., 13).
chunks.english: Here it should be noted that he is not said to have been made in the likeness of God, but to be the seal of likeness—so that the more subtle his nature, the more closely the image of God is expressed in him. Immediately after this it is added, 'Every precious stone was your covering: sardius, topaz, jasper, chrysolite, onyx, beryl, sapphire, carbuncle, and emerald.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ecce novem dixit nomina lapidum, quia profecto novem sunt ordines angelorum. Quibus nimirum ordinibus ille primus angelus ideo ornatus et opertus exstitit, quia dum cunctis agminibus angelorum praelatus est, ex eorum comparatione clarior fuit.
chunks.english: Behold, nine names of stones are mentioned, because there are indeed nine orders of angels. That first angel was adorned and covered with these orders because, being placed over all the armies of angels, he was brighter by comparison with them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Graeca lingua angeli nuntii, archangeli vero summi nuntii vocantur. (Num. 8.) Sciendum quoque quod angelorum vocabulum nomen est officii, non naturae. Nam sancti illi coelestis patriae spiritus semper quidem sunt spiritus, sed semper vocari angeli nequaquam possunt; quia solum tunc sunt angeli cum per eos aliqua nuntiantur.
chunks.english: In the Greek language, angels are called messengers, while archangels are called chief messengers. We should also know that the word 'angel' is the name of an office, not of a nature. Those holy spirits of the heavenly homeland are always spirits indeed, but they cannot always be called angels, because they are only angels when certain messages are announced through them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde et per Psalmistam dicitur: Qui facit angelos suos spiritus (Psal. CIII, 4): ac si patenter dicat, Qui eos quos semper habet spiritus, etiam cum voluerit, angelos facit. Sciendum magnopere est quod hi qui minima nuntiant, angeli, qui vero summa, archangeli vocantur.
chunks.english: Thus it is also said in the Psalms, chapter one hundred three, verse four, 'Who makes his angels spirits'—as if to say openly, 'He who always has them as spirits also makes them angels when he wills.' It should be greatly noted that those who announce lesser things are called angels, while those who announce the greatest things are called archangels.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc est enim quod ad Mariam virginem non quilibet angelus, sed Gabriel archangelus mittitur. Ad hoc quippe ministerium summum venire dignum fuerat qui summum omnium nuntiabat. Sancti angeli privatis nominibus censentur, ut signetur per vocabula etiam in operatione quid valeant. Cumque ad nos aliquid ministraturi veniunt, apud nos etiam nomina a ministeriis trahunt.
chunks.english: That's why not just any angel but the archangel Gabriel was sent to the Virgin Mary. It was fitting that the one who announced the greatest of all things should come for this supreme ministry. The holy angels are designated by personal names so that even in their work what they can do might be signified through their names. And when they come to minister something to us, they also draw their names from their ministries among us.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 9.) Quoties mirae virtutis aliquid agitur, Michael mitti perhibetur, ut ex ipso actu et nomine detur intelligi quia nullus potest facere quod facere praevalet Deus. Michael interpretatur Quis ut Deus. Gabriel autem dicitur fortitudo Dei. Ad Mariam quoque Gabriel mittitur, qui fortitudo Dei nominatur.
chunks.english: Whenever something of wondrous power is accomplished, Michael is said to be sent, so that from the very act and name it may be understood that no one can do what God prevails to do. Michael is interpreted as 'Who is like God?' Gabriel is called the strength of God. Gabriel, who is named the strength of God, was also sent to Mary.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Illum quippe nuntiare veniebat, qui ad debellandas aereas potestates humilis apparere dignatus est. Raphael interpretatur medicina Dei, quia videlicet dum Tobiae oculos quasi per officium curationis tetigit, caecitatis ejus tenebras tersit. Quia ergo ad curandum mittitur, dignum videlicet fuit ut Dei medicina vocaretur.
chunks.english: He came to announce the one who deigned to appear humbly to conquer the powers of the air. Raphael is interpreted as the medicine of God, because when he touched the eyes of Tobit as if through the office of healing, he wiped away the darkness of his blindness. Therefore, because he was sent to heal, it was fitting that he should be called God's medicine.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed quia sanctorum angelorum nomina interpretando perstrinximus, nunc superest ut ipsa officiorum vocabula breviter exsequamur. (Num. 10.) Virtutes vocantur illi nimirum spiritus per quos signa et miracula frequentius fiunt. Potestates vocantur hi qui hoc potentius caeteris in suo ordine perceperunt, ut eorum ditioni virtutes adversae subjectae sint, quorum potestate refrenantur, ne corda hominum tantum tentare praevaleant quantum volunt.
chunks.english: But since we have briefly touched upon the interpretation of the holy angels' names, it now remains to briefly explain the terms of the offices themselves. Virtues are called those spirits through whom signs and miracles more frequently occur. Powers are called those who have received more powerfully than others in their order that the adverse forces should be subject to their authority, being restrained by their power so they cannot tempt human hearts as much as they wish.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Principatus vocantur qui ipsis quoque bonis angelorum spiritibus praesunt, qui subjectis aliis dum quaeque sunt agenda bona disponunt, eis ad explenda divina ministeria principantur. Dominationes vero vocantur qui etiam potestates principatuum dissimilitudine alta transcendunt.
chunks.english: Principalities are called those who preside even over the good spirits of angels themselves, who arrange good things to be done while others are subject to them, and lead them to fulfill divine ministries. Dominations are called those who transcend even the powers of principalities by a high dissimilarity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ea ergo angelorum agmina, quae mira potentia praeeminent, pro eo quod eis caetera ad obediendum subjecta sunt, dominationes vocantur. Throni scilicet illa agmina sunt vocata quibus ad exercendum judicium semper Deus omnipotens praesidet.
chunks.english: Therefore, those armies of angels that stand out in wondrous power are called dominations because the rest are subject to them in obedience. Thrones are called those armies over which almighty God always presides to exercise judgment.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia enim thronos latino eloquio sedes dicimus, throni dicti sunt hi qui tanta divinitatis gratia replentur, ut in eis Dominus sedeat, et per eos sua judicia decernat. Unde et per Psalmistam dicitur: Sedes super thronum, qui judicas aequitatem (Ps. IX, 5).
chunks.english: Because we call thrones 'seats' in Latin speech, they are called thrones who are so filled with divine grace that the Lord sits in them and decrees his judgments through them. Hence it is also said in the Psalms, chapter nine, verse five, 'You sit upon a throne, you who judge equity.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cherubim plenitudo scientiae dicitur; et sublimiora illa agmina idcirco cherubim vocata sunt, quia tanto perfectiori scientia plena sunt, quanto claritatem Dei vicinius contemplantur: ut secundum creaturae modum, eo plene omnia sciant quo visioni Conditoris sui per meritum dignitatis appropinquant.
chunks.english: Cherubim means fullness of knowledge. Those more sublime armies are called cherubim because they are filled with more perfect knowledge the more closely they contemplate God's brightness—so that according to the mode of creation, they know all things fully to the degree they approach the vision of their Creator through the merit of their dignity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Seraphim vocantur illa sanctorum spirituum agmina, quae ex singulari propinquitate Conditoris sui incomparabili ardent amore. Seraphim namque ardentes vel incendentes vocantur, quae quia ita Deo conjuncta sunt, ut inter haec et Deum nulli alii spiritus intersint, tanto magis ardent quanto hunc vicinius vident.
chunks.english: Seraphim are called those armies of holy spirits who burn with incomparable love from their singular nearness to their Creator. Seraphim are called burning or setting on fire, because they are so joined to God that no other spirits come between them and God, they burn all the more the more closely they see him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quorum profecto flamma ardor est charitatis, quia quo subtilius claritatem divinitatis ejus aspiciunt, eo validius in ejus amore flammescunt. (Num. 11.) Superna illa civitas ex angelis et hominibus constat, ad quam tantum credimus hominum genus ascendere, quantos illic contigit electos angelos remansisse, sicut scriptum est: Statuit terminos gentium secundum numerum angelorum Dei (Deut. XXXII, 8).
chunks.english: Their flame is truly the ardor of charity, because the more subtly they perceive the brightness of his divinity, the more strongly they burn in love for him. That heavenly city above consists of angels and humans. We believe that the human race will ascend to it in such number as the elect angels remained there, as it is written in the book of Deuteronomy, chapter thirty-two, verse eight, 'He established the boundaries of the nations according to the number of the angels of God.'

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XIV]
De sanctis angelis quibus gentibus praelatis.
chunks.english: Chapter 14: On the Holy Angels Assigned to Nations

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XVII, cap. 12, n. 17.) Dum pax in sublimibus angelorum ordinibus summa teneatur, quid est quod per angelum Danieli dicitur: Ego veni propter sermones tuos: princeps autem regni Persarum restitit mihi viginti et uno diebus: et ecce Michael unus de principibus primis venit in adjutorium mihi (Dan. X, 13)?
chunks.english: While supreme peace is maintained in the lofty orders of angels, what does it mean that the angel says to Daniel, according to the book of Daniel, chapter ten, verse thirteen, 'I came because of your words, but the prince of the kingdom of Persia resisted me for twenty-one days, and behold, Michael, one of the first princes, came to my aid'?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et paulo post angelus ait: Nunc revertar, ut praelier adversus principem Persarum. Cum enim egrederer, apparuit princeps Graecorum veniens (Ibid. 20). Quos itaque alios principes gentium nisi angelos appellat, qui sibi resistere exeunti potuissent?
chunks.english: And a little later the angel says, 'Now I will return to fight against the prince of the Persians. When I was departing, the prince of the Greeks appeared coming.' What other princes of nations does he call except angels, who could resist him as he went out?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae ergo esse pax in sublimibus potest, si inter ipsos quoque angelicos spiritus praeliandi certamen agitur, qui semper conspectui Veritatis assistunt? Certa angelorum ministeria dispensandis singulis quibusque gentibus sunt praelata. Et cum subjectorum mores adversum se vicissim praepositorum spirituum opem merentur, ipsi qui praesunt spiritus contra se venire referuntur.
chunks.english: What peace can there be in the heights, if a struggle of fighting is carried on even among the angelic spirits themselves, who always stand in the sight of Truth? Certain ministries of angels are set over each individual nation to be governed. And when the conduct of their subjects merits the help of the presiding spirits against each other in turn, the spirits who preside are said to come against each other.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Angelus qui Danieli loquebatur, captivis Israelitici populi in Perside constitutis praelatus agnoscitur. Michael autem eorum qui ex eadem plebe in Judaeae terra remanserant praepositus invenitur. Unde ab hoc eodem angelo paulo post Danieli dicitur: Nemo est adjutor meus in omnibus his, nisi Michael princeps vester (Ibid. 21). De quo et hoc quod praemisimus dicit: Et ecce Michael unus de principibus primis venit in adjutorium mihi (Ibid 13).
chunks.english: The angel who spoke to Daniel is recognized as having been set over the captives of the Israelite people established in Persia. Michael, however, is found to be the one placed over those from the same people who remained in the land of Judea. Thus by this same angel it is said a little later to Daniel, 'No one is my helper in all these things except Michael your prince.' Of whom he also says what we mentioned earlier, 'And behold, Michael, one of the first princes, came to my aid.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui dum nequaquam simul esse, sed venire in adjutorium dicitur, aperte ei populo praelatus agnoscitur qui captivus in alia parte tenebatur. Quid est angelum dicere: Ego veni propter sermones tuos; princeps autem regni Persarum restitit mihi (Ibid. 13), nisi sua subditis opera nuntiare? Ac si aperte dicat: Precum quidem tuarum merita exigunt ut Israeliticus populus a jugo suae captivitatis exuatur; sed est adhuc quod in eodem populo Persarum dominio purgari debeat: unde ereptioni illius Persarum princeps mihi jure contradicat, quamvis preces tuas eorum lacrymae qui in Judaea relicti sunt adjuvent.
chunks.english: When he is said not to be present together, but to come to aid, he is openly recognized as having been set over the people who were held captive in another part. What is it for the angel to say, 'I came because of your words, but the prince of the kingdom of Persia resisted me,' except to announce his works to his subjects? As if he were saying openly, 'The merits of your prayers demand that the Israelite people be freed from the yoke of their captivity, but there is still something in that same people that must be purged under Persian dominion. Therefore the prince of the Persians rightly contradicts their liberation, though the tears of those left in Judea help your prayers.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Angelus qui loquebatur Danieli dixit: Michael princeps vester venit in adjutorium mihi. Cumque ut adversum Persarum principem praelietur egreditur, Graecorum sibi princeps adveniens apparet. Qua ex re innuitur quod adversum Graecos aliquid Judaea commiserat, quorum profecto causa ereptioni illius resistebat.
