chunks.english: The angel who was speaking to Daniel said, 'Michael your prince came to my aid.' And when he goes out to fight against the prince of the Persians, the prince of the Greeks appears coming toward him. From this it is implied that Judea had committed something against the Greeks, whose cause was indeed resisting their liberation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Prophetae preces angelus exaudit, sed Persarum princeps resistit; quia etsi jam vita justi deprecantis ereptionem populi exigit, ejusdem tamen populi adhuc vita contradicit; ut quia necdum plene hi qui in captivitatem fuerant ducti purgati sunt, jure eis adhuc Persae dominentur.
chunks.english: The angel hears the prophet's prayers, but the prince of the Persians resists—because even if the life of the just one praying demands the liberation of the people, nevertheless the life of that same people still contradicts it. Since those who had been led into captivity are not yet fully purified, the Persians justly still rule over them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Michael adjuvat, sed Graecorum princeps ad praelium venit; quia mereri quidem veniam tam longa oppressorum captivitas poterat, sed ereptionis eorum beneficio hoc quoque quod in Graecos deliquerant obviabat. Recte dicitur quod contra se angeli veniunt, quia subjectarum sibi gentium vicissim merita contradicunt.
chunks.english: Michael helps, but the prince of the Greeks comes to battle—because the long captivity of the oppressed could indeed merit pardon, but what they had done wrong against the Greeks still stood in the way of the benefit of their liberation. It is rightly said that angels come against each other, because the merits of the nations subject to them contradict each other in turn.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam sublimes spiritus eisdem gentibus principantes nequaquam pro injuste agentibus decertant, sed eorum facta juste judicantes examinant. Cum uniuscujusque gentis vel culpa vel justitia ad supernae curiae consilium ducitur, ejusdem gentis praepositus vel obtinuisse in certamine, vel non obtinuisse perhibetur.
chunks.english: For the sublime spirits ruling over these nations do not fight on behalf of those acting unjustly, but examine their deeds by judging them justly. When the guilt or justice of any nation is brought to the council of the heavenly court, the leader of that nation is said either to have prevailed in the contest or not to have prevailed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quorum tamen omnium una victoria est sui super se opificis voluntas summa, quam dum semper aspiciunt, quod obtinere non valent nunquam volunt.
chunks.english: Yet for all of them there is one victory: the supreme will of their Maker over themselves, which they always behold—and what they cannot obtain, they never wish for.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Nature and Origin of Evil
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XV]
Quia matum nullius sit substantiae, sed a diabolo primum inventum est.
chunks.english: Chapter 15: That Evil Has No Substance but Was First Invented by the Devil

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Aug. de Gen. ad litter., lib. XVIII, c. 14. Idem, Enchir., cap. 12, 13, 14, 15.) Malum natura non est, sed privatio boni hoc nomen accepit. Omnis natura bonum est, magnum si corrumpi non potest, parvum si potest: nullum est ergo quod dicitur malum, si nullum sit bonum. Sed bonum omni malo carens integrum bonum est. Cui vero inest malum, vitiatum vel vitiosum bonum est. Nec malum unquam esse potest ullum, ubi est bonum nullum.
chunks.english: Evil is not a nature, but the privation of good has received this name. Every nature is good—great if it cannot be corrupted, small if it can. Therefore there is no such thing as evil if there is no good. But a good lacking all evil is an integral good. One in which evil is present is a corrupted or vicious good. Evil can never exist where there is no good at all.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Malum omnino non esset, nisi quod bonum est esset; quoniam omnis natura bonum est, nec res aliqua mala esset, si res ipsa quae mala est natura non esset. Omnis natura etiam si vitiosa est, in quantum natura est, bona est; in quantum vitiosa est, mala est.
chunks.english: Evil would not exist at all unless what is good existed, since every nature is good. No thing would be evil if the thing itself that is evil were not a nature. Every nature, even if vicious, is good insofar as it is a nature; insofar as it is vicious, it is evil.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex bonis mala orta sunt, et nisi in aliquibus bonis non sunt: nec erat, unde oriretur ulla mali natura. Nam si esset, in quantum natura esset, profecto bona esset. Non fuit prorsus unde primitus oriretur malum, nisi ex angeli et hominis natura bona.
chunks.english: Evils arose from goods, and they do not exist except in some goods. There was no source from which any nature of evil could arise. For if there were, insofar as it was a nature, it would certainly be good. There was absolutely no source from which evil could first arise except from the good nature of angel and man.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex bona quippe hominis natura oriri voluntas et bona potest et mala: ac per hoc dicimus angelum bonum et angelum malum, hominem bonum et hominem malum: sed bonum quod angelus, malum quod vitiosus; bonum quod homo, malum quod vitiosus. Quando dicimus bonum, naturam laudamus; quando dicimus malum, non naturam, sed vitium, quia inest bonae naturae, deprehendimus.
chunks.english: From man's good nature, both a good will and an evil will can arise. Therefore we speak of a good angel and an evil angel, a good man and an evil man—but good in that he is an angel or man, evil in that he is vicious. When we say 'good,' we praise the nature; when we say 'evil,' we identify not the nature but the vice that is present in the good nature.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Ibid., Sent. lib. I, c. 11.) Non ergo alicubi, aut aliquando erat malum, unde fieret diabolus malus, sed quia vitium est malum, dum esset angelus bonus, superbiendo effectus est malus. Ideoque recte dicitur ab eo inventum malum; malum igitur a diabolo non est creatum, sed inventum; et ideo malum nihil est, quia nullius substantiae est: nam sine Deo factum est nihil, Deus autem malum non fecit.
chunks.english: Therefore evil did not exist somewhere or at some time, from which the devil became evil. Rather, because evil is a vice, while he was a good angel, he became evil through pride. Therefore it is rightly said that evil was invented by him. Evil was not created by the devil but invented by him. Therefore evil is nothing, because it has no substance—for without God nothing was made, and God did not make evil.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Creditur ab haereticis mentem a Deo, vitia a diabolo fuisse creata, unde et ab his duae naturae, bona et mala, putantur. Sed vitia natura non sunt, et dum vere a diabolo sint, non tamen creata sunt.
chunks.english: Heretics believe that the mind was created by God and vices were created by the devil, from which they suppose there are two natures, good and evil. But vices are not natures, and though they truly come from the devil, they were not created.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Creation of Heaven and Earth
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XVI]
De initio mundi vel creatione coeli et terrae.
chunks.english: Chapter 16: On the Beginning of the World and the Creation of Heaven and Earth

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Mor., lib. XXXII, c. 12, n. 16.) Rerum substantia simul creata est; sed simul species formata non est; et quod simul exstitit per substantiam materiae, non simul apparuit per speciem formae. Cum simul factum coelum terraque describitur, simul spiritualia atque corporalia, simul quidquid de coelo oritur, simul factum quidquid de terra producitur, indicatur.
chunks.english: The substance of things was created simultaneously, but their species were not formed simultaneously. What existed together in the substance of matter did not appear together in the form of species. When heaven and earth are described as made together, it indicates that spiritual and corporeal things, whatever originates from heaven, and whatever is produced from earth were all made together.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dixerat Moyses: In principio creavit Deus coelum et terram [Gen. I, 1]. (Lib. I in Ezech., hom. 1, n. 2.) Sed quis crederet quia verum de praeterito diceret, si de futuro etiam aliquid non dixisset? In ipsius etenim libri fine, in cujus exordio illa de praeterite dixerat, aliquid prophetiae per Jacob vocem de venturis permiscuit, dicens: Non auferetur sceptrum de Juda, et dux de femoribus ejus, donec veniat qui mittendus est, et ipse erit exspectatio gentium (Gen. XLIX, 10).
chunks.english: Moses had said, 'In the beginning God created heaven and earth,' according to the book of Genesis, chapter one, verse one. But who would believe that he spoke truth about the past if he had not also said something about the future? At the very end of the book, in whose beginning he had spoken those things about the past, he mixed in something of prophecy through Jacob's voice about things to come, saying, according to the book of Genesis, chapter forty-nine, verse ten, 'The scepter shall not be taken away from Judah, nor the leader from his loins, until he comes who is to be sent, and he shall be the expectation of the nations.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral. XXXII, c. 12, n. 26.] Qui diversis diebus creatum coelum et terram, virgultum herbamque narraverat, nunc uno die facta manifestat; ut liquido ostenderet quod creatura omnis simul per substantiam exstitit, quamvis non simul per speciem processerit.
chunks.english: He who had narrated that heaven and earth, shrubs and grass were created on different days, now shows that they were made in one day—to clearly demonstrate that every creature existed simultaneously in substance, though it did not proceed simultaneously in species.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Apud Isidor., lib. I Sent., cap. 10.) Ratio mundi de uno consideranda est homine: nam sicut per dimensiones aetatum ad finem homo vergitur, ita et mundus per hoc quod distenditur tempore deficit; quia unde homo atque mundus crescere videtur, inde uterque minuitur.
chunks.english: The principle of the world should be considered from one man: for just as man moves toward his end through the stages of life, so also the world fails through being stretched out in time. Whatever makes man and world seem to grow actually diminishes both.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Aug., lib. XII Conf., cap. 29.) Materies, ex qua formatus est mundus, origine, non tempore res a se factas praecessit, ut sonus cantum; prior est enim sonus cantu, quia suavitas cantilenae ad sonum vocis, non sonus pertinet ad suavitatem. Ac per hoc utrumque simul sunt; sed ille ad quem pertinet cantus prior est, id est, sonus.
chunks.english: The matter from which the world was formed preceded the things made from it in origin, not in time—as sound precedes song. Sound is prior to song because the sweetness of melody pertains to the sound of the voice, but the sound does not pertain to the sweetness. Therefore both exist simultaneously, but that to which the song pertains is prior—that is, the sound.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Materies, ex qua coelum terraque formata est, ideo informis vocata est, quia nondum ex ea formata erant quae formari restabant; verum ipsa materia ex nihilo facta erat. Aliud est aliquid fieri posse, aliud fieri necesse esse. Fieri necesse est quod Deus naturis inseruit, fieri autem posse est quod extra cursum indictum naturarum creator ut faceret quandoque voluit reservavit.
chunks.english: The matter from which heaven and earth were formed is called formless because what remained to be formed had not yet been formed from it, yet the matter itself was made from nothing. It is one thing for something to be able to come into being, another for it to necessarily come into being. What God inserted into natures must necessarily come to be, but what is able to come to be is what the Creator reserved to make at some time outside the appointed course of natures whenever he willed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Aug., lib. XIII Conf., cap. 6, 7.) Post annumeratam coeli terraeque creaturam, ideo nominatur in Genesi (I, 3) Spiritus, ut quia superferri eum dici oportebat, ante illa nominarentur quorum creator Spiritus sanctus superferri diceretur: quod et Apostolus indicat (Rom. V, 5), dum supereminentem viam charitatis demonstrat.
chunks.english: After the enumeration of the creation of heaven and earth, the Spirit is named in Genesis, chapter one, verse three, so that—because he had to be said to be borne above—those things might first be named over which the Holy Spirit, their creator, would be said to be borne above. The Apostle also indicates this in Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter five, verse five, when he demonstrates the surpassing way of charity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ideo superferri aquis sanctus dicitur Spiritus, quia donum est Dei, in quo subsistentes requiescimus, atque protegendo nos superfertur nobis.
chunks.english: The Holy Spirit is said to be borne above the waters because he is the gift of God, in whom we who subsist find rest, and by protecting us he is borne above us.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Eternal Essence of Heaven and Earth
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XVII]
Quod essentia coeli et terrae in aeternum subsistat.
chunks.english: Chapter 17: That the Essence of Heaven and Earth Endures Forever

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XVII, c. 9, n. 11.) Coeli et terra per eam quam nunc habent imaginem transeunt, sed tamen per essentiam sine fine subsistunt. Hinc namque per Paulum dicitur: Praeterit enim figura hujus mundi (I Cor. VII, 31). Hinc per semetipsam Veritas dicit: Coelum et terra transibunt, verba autem mea non praeteribunt (Matth. XXIV, 35).
chunks.english: Heaven and earth pass away in the form they now have, yet they endure without end in their essence. For Paul says in his first letter to the Corinthians, chapter seven, verse thirty-one, 'The form of this world is passing away.' Truth itself says in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-four, verse thirty-five, 'Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will not pass away.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc ad Joannem dicitur angelica voce: Erit coelum novum et terra nova (Apoc. XXI, 1). Quae quidem non alia condenda sunt, sed haec ipsa renovantur. Coelum ac terra et transit et erit, quia et ab ea quam nunc habet specie per ignem tergitur, et tamen in sua semper natura servatur.
chunks.english: Thus it is said by angelic voice in the book of Revelation, chapter twenty-one, verse one, 'There will be a new heaven and a new earth.' These are not to be created as other things, but these very ones are renewed. Heaven and earth both pass away and will be, because they are cleansed by fire from the form they now have, yet are always preserved in their nature.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde per Psalmistam dicitur: Mutabis ea, et mutabuntur (Psal. CI, 27). In fine saeculi hujus ultimam commutationem suam coelum et terra ipsis nobis nunc vicissitudinibus nuntiant, quibus nostris usibus indesinenter alternant.
chunks.english: Thus it is said in the Psalms, chapter one hundred one, verse twenty-seven, 'You will change them, and they will be changed.' At the end of this age, heaven and earth announce their final transformation to us through the very changes by which they ceaselessly alternate for our use.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam terra a sua specie hiemali ariditate deficit, vernali humore viridescit. Hinc ergo, hinc fidelis quisque colligat, et interire speciem coeli et terrae, et tamen per innovationem refici, quae constat nunc assidue alternantium specierum vicissitudinibus velut ex defectu reparari.
chunks.english: The earth fails from its own form in winter dryness, and grows green with spring moisture. From this, then, let every faithful person conclude that the form of heaven and earth will perish yet be restored through renewal—which is now evidently being repaired, as it were, from failure through the constant alternation of changing forms.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XVIII]
De distinctione creaturarum.
chunks.english: Chapter 18: On the Distinction of Creatures

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. IV, c. 20, n. 55). Ex rebus insensibilibus discimus quid de sensibilibus atque intelligibilibus sentiamus. Terra namque aere fecundatur, aer autem ex coeli qualitate disponitur. Jumentis quippe homines, hominibus angeli, archangeli vero angelis praesunt; nam quod jumentis homines praesint, et usu cernimus, et Psalmistae verbis docemur, qui ait: Omnia subjecisti sub pedibus ejus, oves et boves universas, insuper et pecora campi (Ps. VIII, 8).
chunks.english: From insensible things we learn what to think about sensible and intelligible things. The earth is made fertile by air, and air is disposed according to the quality of heaven. Humans preside over beasts, angels over humans, and archangels over angels. That humans preside over beasts we both see by experience and are taught by the words of the Psalmist, who says in Psalm eight, verse eight, 'You have subjected all things under his feet, all sheep and oxen, and moreover the beasts of the field.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia vero angeli hominibus praesint, per prophetam testatur angelus dicens: Princeps regni Persarum restitit mihi (Dan. X, 13). Quod angeli a superiorum angelorum potestatibus dispensantur, Zacharias perhibet propheta, qui ait: Ecce angelus, qui loquebatur in me, egrediebatur; et alius angelus egrediebatur in occursum ejus; et dixit ad eum: Curre, loquere ad puerum istum dicens: Absque muro habitabitur Jerusalem (Zach. II, 3).
chunks.english: That angels preside over humans the angel testifies through the prophet Daniel, saying, 'The prince of the kingdom of Persia resisted me,' according to the book of Daniel, chapter ten, verse thirteen. That angels are governed by the powers of higher angels the prophet Zechariah attests, saying, according to the book of Zechariah, chapter two, verse three, 'Behold, the angel who was speaking within me went out, and another angel went out to meet him, and said to him: Run, speak to this young man, saying, Jerusalem shall be inhabited without walls.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si enim in ipsis officiis sanctorum spirituum nequaquam potestates summae minimas disponerent, nullo modo hoc quod homini diceret angelus ab angelo cognovisset. Quia cunctorum conditor omnia per semetipsum tenet, et tamen ad distinguendum pulchrae universitatis ordinem, alia aliis dispensantibus regit; non immerito reges angelorum spiritus accipimus, qui quo auctori omnium familiarius serviunt, eo subjecta potius regunt.
chunks.english: For if in the very offices of the holy spirits the highest powers did not govern the least, the angel would in no way have learned from another angel what to say to the man. Because the Creator of all holds all things through himself, yet governs some things through others who dispense them to distinguish the order of the beautiful universe, we rightly understand the spirits of angels as kings, who govern their subjects all the more because they serve the Author of all more intimately.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Homo cum angelis quiesceret, si persuasoris linguam sequi noluisset. Unde non immerito angeli consules vocantur: quia spirituali reipublicae consulunt, dum nos sibi ad regnum socios jungunt. Dum sanctis angelis nuntiantibus voluntatem Conditoris agnoscimus, in eis procul dubio consultum ab hac angustia nostrae tribulationis invenimus.
chunks.english: Man would rest with the angels if he had not chosen to follow the tongue of the persuader. Therefore angels are not undeservedly called counselors, because they give counsel to the spiritual commonwealth when they join us to themselves as companions in the kingdom. When we recognize the will of the Creator through the holy angels announcing it, we find in them without doubt counsel from this distress of our tribulation.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XIX]
Quod rationalis creatura angelorum atque hominum simul creata sit.
chunks.english: Chapter 19: That Rational Creatures, Angels and Humans, Were Created Together

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXXII, cap. 12, n. 17.) Omnis creatura ab auctore Deo, qui in actione sua nequaquam temporis protelatione distenditur, simul condita non dubitatur. Et si rerum causas subtili discussione pulsamus, simul factum angelum hominemque cognoscimus: simul videlicet, non unitate temporis, sed cognitione rationis; simul per acceptam imaginem sapientiae, et non simul per conjunctam substantiam formae.
chunks.english: Every creature was created simultaneously by God the Author, who in his action is in no way stretched out by the extension of time. And if we examine the causes of things with subtle investigation, we know that angel and man were made together—together not in unity of time, but in recognition of reason; together through the received image of wisdom, and not together through the conjoined substance of form.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scriptum de homine est: Faciamus hominem ad imaginem et similitudinem nostram (Gen. I, 26). Et per Ezechielem ad Satan dicitur: Tu signaculum similitudinis, plenus sapientia, et perfectus decore in deliciis paradisi fuisti (Ezech. XXVIII, 12). In cuncta igitur creatura homo et angelus simul exstitit; quia ab omni natura irrationabili distinctus processit.
chunks.english: It is written of man, according to the book of Genesis, chapter one, verse twenty-six, 'Let us make man in our image and likeness.' And to Satan it is said through Ezekiel, according to the book of Ezekiel, chapter twenty-eight, verse twelve, 'You were the seal of likeness, full of wisdom, and perfect in beauty, you were in the delights of paradise.' Therefore in all creation man and angel existed together, because they proceeded distinct from all irrational nature.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In cuncta conditione rerum nullum rationale animal nisi angelus et homo est. Quidquid ratione uti non potest, cum homine factum non est. (Moral. lib. IX, c. 49, n. 75.) Licet per coaeternum Patris Verbum cuncta creata sint, in ipsa tamen ratione creationis ostenditur quantum cunctis animalibus, quantum rebus coelestibus, sed tamen insensibilibus homo praeferatur.
chunks.english: In all the establishment of things there is no rational animal except angel and man. Whatever cannot use reason was not made with man. Although all things were created through the coeternal Word of the Father, nevertheless in the very plan of creation it is shown how much man is preferred to all animals, how much to heavenly things, yet insensible ones.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cuncta dixit Deus, et facta sunt (Ps. CXLVIII, 5). Cum vero facere hominem decernit, hoc quod reverenter pensandum est, praemittit dicens: Faciamus hominem ad imaginem et similitudinem nostram (Gen. I, 26). Neque enim de eo sicut de rebus caeteris scriptum est: Fiat, et factum est (Ibid. 3); nec ut aqua volatilia, sic terra hominem protulit: sed prius quam fieret, Faciamus dicitur, ut videlicet quia rationalis creatura condebatur, quasi cum consilio facta videretur.
chunks.english: God said all things, and they were made, according to Psalm one hundred forty-eight, verse five. But when he determines to make man—and this should be reverently considered—he says first, 'Let us make man in our image and likeness,' according to the book of Genesis, chapter one, verse twenty-six. For it is not written of him as of other things, 'Let it be made, and it was made.' Nor did the earth bring forth man as the water brought forth birds. Rather, before he was made, 'Let us make' is said, so that because a rational creature was being created, it would appear to have been made, as it were, with counsel.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quasi per studium de terra plasmatur homo, et inspiratione Conditoris in virtute spiritus vitalis erigitur; ut scilicet non per jussionis vocem, sed per dignitatem operationis existeret, qui ad Conditoris imaginem fiebat.
chunks.english: Man is formed from earth as if with careful attention, and is raised up by the inspiration of the Creator in the power of the life-giving spirit—so that he who was being made in the Creator's image might come into existence not through a voice of command but through the dignity of the operation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scriptum est: Creavit Deus hominem ad imaginem suam, ad imaginem Dei creavit illum, masculum et feminam fecit eos (Gen. I, 27). [Moral. lib. XXXII, c. 12, n. 16.] Necdum Eva facta describitur, et jam homo masculus et femina perhibetur. Sed quia ex Adae latere erat procul dubio femina processura, in illo jam computatur per substantiam a quo fuerat producenda per formam.
chunks.english: It is written, according to the book of Genesis, chapter one, verse twenty-seven, 'God created man in his image, in the image of God he created him, male and female he made them.' Eve is not yet described as having been made, yet man is already said to be male and female. But because the woman was without doubt going to proceed from Adam's side, she is already counted in him by substance from whom she was to be produced by form.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Considerare tamen haec et in minimis possumus, ut ex minimis majora pensemus. Herba namque cum creatur, necdum in illa fructus, necdum semen ostenditur. Inest vero ei, etiam cum non apparet, fructus et semen, quia nimirum simul sunt in radicis substantia quae non simul prodeunt per temporis incrementa.
chunks.english: Yet we can consider these things even in the smallest matters, so that from small things we may weigh greater ones. When grass is created, neither fruit nor seed is yet shown in it. Yet fruit and seed are present in it even when they do not appear, because they exist together in the substance of the root, though they do not come forth together through increases of time.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. IV, c. 3, n. 8.) Duas ad intelligendum se creaturas Deus fecerat, angelicam videlicet et humanam. Utramque vero superbia perculit, atque ab statu ingenitae rectitudinis fregit; sed una tegmen carnis habuit, alia vero nihil infirmum de carne gestavit. Angelus namque solummodo spiritus, homo vero et spiritus et caro.
chunks.english: God had made two creatures to understand him, namely angelic and human. Pride struck both and broke them from the state of innate righteousness. But one had the covering of flesh, while the other bore nothing weak from the flesh. For the angel is spirit only, but man is both spirit and flesh.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Misertus ergo Creator, ut hominem redimeret, carnem ad se debuit reducere, quam in perpetratione culpae ex infirmitate aliquid constat habuisse. Et eo altius debuit apostatam angelum repellere, quo, cum a persistendi fortitudine corruit, nihil infirmum ex carne gestavit.
chunks.english: The Creator, having mercy, had to bring back to himself the flesh in order to redeem man, which is known to have had something from weakness in the perpetration of guilt. And he had to repel the apostate angel all the more, because when he fell from the strength of persisting, he bore nothing weak from the flesh.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Recte Psalmista, cum misertum Redemptorem hominibus diceret, ipsam quoque causam misericordiae expressit, dicens: Et memoratus est, quia caro sunt (Ps. LXXVII, 39). Ac si diceret: Quo eorum infirma vidit, eo districte culpas punire noluit.
chunks.english: The Psalmist rightly expressed the very cause of mercy when speaking of the merciful Redeemer toward humanity, saying in Psalm seventy-seven, verse thirty-nine, 'And he remembered that they are flesh'—as if to say: The more he saw their weakness, the less strictly he wished to punish their sins.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Est adhuc aliud quod et perditus homo reparari debuit, et superbiens spiritus reparari non possit, quia nimirum angelus sua malitia cecidit, homo vero aliena prostratus est.
chunks.english: There is yet another reason why lost man had to be restored and the proud spirit cannot be restored: the angel fell by his own malice, but man was cast down by another's.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Perfection of the Number Seven
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XX]
De septenarii numeri perfectione.
chunks.english: Chapter 20: On the Perfection of the Number Seven

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Septem diebus universum tempus evolvitur. Aeterna enim dies, quae expleta septem dierum vicissitudine sequitur, scilicet octava est. (Greg. lib. II in Ezech., homil. 4, n. 2.) Unde et Psalmista resurrectionis diem considerans, quia de extremi judicii erat districtione locuturus, praemisit titulum, dicens: In finem Psalmus David pro octava (Psalm. VI, 1).
chunks.english: All time unfolds in seven days. For the eternal day, which follows after the completion of the alternation of seven days, is the eighth day. Thus the Psalmist, contemplating the day of resurrection, because he was about to speak of the severity of the final judgment, placed the title first, saying in Psalm six, verse one, 'To the end, a Psalm of David for the eighth day.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut enim quam octavam diceret demonstraret, diem illam tremendi terroris in psalmi inchoatione secutus est, dicens: Domine, ne in ira tua arguas me, neque in furore tuo corripias me (Ibid., 2). [Moral., lib. XXXV, c. 8, n. 16.] Septenario numero perfectio aeternitatis innuitur, cum dies septimus in requiem Domini sanctificatus vocatur.
chunks.english: To show what he meant by the eighth day, he followed with that day of fearful terror at the beginning of the psalm, saying, 'O Lord, do not rebuke me in your anger, nor chastise me in your fury.' The perfection of eternity is signified by the number seven, when the seventh day is called sanctified unto the Lord's rest.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cui jam vespera inesse non dicitur, quia aeternae beatitudinis requies nullo termino coarctatur. Hinc est etiam quod lege data dies septimus feriatus esse praecipitur (Levit. XXV, 8, 9), ut aeterna per illum requies designetur. (Num. 17.) Quod per septenarium numerum praesentis vitae universitas designatur tunc magis ostenditur cum post eum quoque etiam octonarius subinfertur.
chunks.english: No evening is said to belong to it, because the rest of eternal blessedness is not restricted by any boundary. This is also why the seventh day is commanded by the given law to be kept as a holiday, according to the book of Leviticus, chapter twenty-five, verses eight and nine, so that eternal rest might be designated through it. That the whole of present life is designated by the number seven is shown more clearly when the eighth is also added after it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Septenarium quippe cum adhuc alius sequitur, ex ipso ejus augmento exprimitur quod finienda tempora aeternitate concludantur. Scriptum est: Da partes septem, necnon et octo (Eccl. XI, 2). Per septenarium quippe numerum, hoc quod septem diebus agitur praesens tempus expressit; per octonarium vero vitam perpetuam designavit, quam tamen sua nobis Dominus resurrectione patefecit.
chunks.english: Indeed, when another follows the number seven, it is expressed by this very increase that the times that must end are concluded by eternity. It is written in the book of Ecclesiastes, chapter eleven, verse two, 'Give portions to seven and also to eight.' By the number seven he expressed the present time that is conducted in seven days; by the number eight he designated perpetual life, which the Lord manifested to us by his resurrection.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dominico scilicet die resurrexit, qui dum diem septimum, id est, sabbatum, sequitur, a conditione octavus invenitur. (Num. 16.) In annorum curriculo septenarius numerus septies multiplicatus monade addita ad quinquagenarium ducitur, ut perpetuam beatitudinem signans jubilaei sacratissima requies observetur.
chunks.english: He rose on the Lord's day, which, while following the seventh day, that is the Sabbath, is found to be the eighth by counting. In the course of years, the number seven multiplied seven times with one added leads to fifty, so that the most sacred rest of jubilee might be observed, signifying perpetual blessedness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 15.) Septenarius numerus apud sapientes hujus saeculi quadam sua habetur ratione perfectus, quod ex primo pari et ex primo impari consummatur. Primus enim impar ternarius est, primusque par quaternarius. Ex quibus duobus septenarius constat, qui eisdem partibus suis multiplicatus in duodenarium surgit. Nam sive tres per quatuor, seu quatuor per tres ducimus, ad duodenarium pervenimus.
chunks.english: The number seven is held by the wise of this age to be perfect by a certain calculation of its own, because it is completed from the first even and the first odd number. For the first odd number is three, and the first even is four. From these two, seven is constituted, which when multiplied by its same parts rises to twelve. For whether we multiply three by four or four by three, we arrive at twelve.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nos quia a superno munere veritatis praedicamenta percepimus, haec fixa scientiae altitudine despiciendo calcamus; hoc procul dubio inconcussa fide retinentes, quia quos spiritus gratiae septiformis repleverit perficit, eisque non solum Trinitatis notitiam, sed etiam virtutum quatuor, id est, prudentiae, temperantiae, fortitudinis atque justitiae operationem praebet.
chunks.english: Because we have received the teachings of truth from the heavenly gift, we trample these things by looking down from the established height of knowledge. We hold this with unshaken faith: that the sevenfold Spirit of grace perfects those whom he fills, and provides them not only knowledge of the Trinity but also the working of the four virtues—that is, prudence, temperance, fortitude, and justice.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Soul and Its Interior Senses
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XXI]
De anima ejusque sensibus.
chunks.english: Chapter 21: On the Soul and Its Senses

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XI, c. 33, n. 45.) In Scriptura sacra dentes aliquando interni sensus accipi solent, Jeremia testante, qui ait: Fregit ad numerum dentes meos (Thren. III, 10). Per dentes enim cibus frangitur ut glutiatur. Unde non immerito in dentibus internos sensus accipimus, qui singula quae cogitant quasi mandunt et comminuunt, atque ad ventrem memoriae transmittunt.
chunks.english: In sacred Scripture, teeth are sometimes understood to mean interior senses, as Jeremiah testifies, saying in the book of Lamentations, chapter three, verse ten, 'He has broken my teeth to pieces.' Through teeth food is broken so it may be swallowed. Therefore we rightly understand by teeth the interior senses, which chew and grind, as it were, individual things they think about, and transmit them to the stomach of memory.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Internos sensus animae quasi dentes propheta ad numerum fractos dicit, quia juxta mensuram uniuscujusque peccati intelligentiae caecitas generatur in sensibus, et secundum quod quisque egit exterius, in eo obstupescit quod de internis atque invisibilibus intelligere potuit.
chunks.english: The prophet says the interior senses of the soul are broken to pieces like teeth, because according to the measure of each person's sin, blindness of understanding is generated in the senses, and according to what each person has done outwardly, that person becomes dull in what he could understand about interior and invisible things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omnis homo qui comederit uvam acerbam, obstupescent dentes ejus (Ezech. XVIII, 2; Jerem. XXX, 30). Quid namque acerba uva nisi peccatum est? Uva quippe acerba est fructus ante tempus. Quisquis enim praesentis vitae delectationibus satiari desiderat, quasi fructus ante tempus comedere festinat.
chunks.english: Every person who eats a sour grape will have his teeth set on edge, according to the book of Ezekiel, chapter eighteen, verse two, and the book of Jeremiah, chapter thirty, verse thirty. What is a sour grape but sin? A sour grape is fruit before its time. Whoever desires to be satisfied with the pleasures of present life hastens, as it were, to eat fruit before its time.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui uvam acerbam comedit, dentes ejus obstupescunt, quia qui praesentis mundi delectatione pascitur, interni ejus sensus ligantur, ut jam spiritualia mandere, id est, intelligere, nequeant, quia unde in exterioribus delectati sunt, inde in intimis obstupescunt.
chunks.english: Whoever eats a sour grape has his teeth set on edge, because whoever feeds on the delight of the present world has his interior senses bound, so that they can no longer chew, that is, understand spiritual things—because from what delighted them in exterior things, they become dull in interior things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et dum peccato anima pascitur, panem justitiae edere non valet, quoniam ligati dentes ex peccati consuetudine, justum quod intus sapit edere nequaquam possunt. Considerare magnopere quid agere justi soleant debemus. Qui plerumque, si qua in se quamlibet leviter carnalia esse deprehendunt, haec in internis sensibus retractantes, vehementer in semetipsis insequuntur, afflictione se conterunt magnisque cruciatibus, vel minima in se prava dijudicant atque per poenitentiam damnant.
chunks.english: And while the soul feeds on sin, it cannot eat the bread of justice, because the teeth, bound by the habit of sin, can in no way eat the just thing that has inner flavor. We should greatly consider what the just are accustomed to do. They, for the most part, if they detect anything however slightly carnal in themselves, reconsidering these things in their interior senses, vehemently pursue them in themselves, grind themselves down with affliction and great torments, and judge and condemn through penance even the smallest evil things in themselves.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Electi quotidie agunt ut in conspectu aeterni judicis et ipsi inveniri, in quantum est possibile, irreprehensibiles debeant, et hi qui eos sic se judicare conspiciunt emendate semetipsos a culpis gravioribus inardescant.
chunks.english: The elect act daily so that they themselves should be found, as much as possible, irreproachable in the sight of the eternal Judge, and those who see them judging themselves in this way should burn to correct themselves from graver faults.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XXII]
De conditione primi hominis.
chunks.english: Chapter 22: On the Condition of the First Man

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XXV, c. 3, n. 4; lib. XI, c. 50, n. 68; lib. XXV, c. 3, n. 4; lib. IV, c. 28, n. 54.) Primus homo ita conditus fuit, ut manente illo decederent tempora, nec cum temporibus ipse transiret. Stabat enim momentis decurrentibus, quia nequaquam ad vitae terminum per dierum incrementa tendebat.
chunks.english: The first man was created in such a way that while he remained, times would pass, and he would not pass with the times. For he stood while moments ran past, because he was in no way tending toward the end of life through the increase of days.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Primus homo ante culpam statum habere fixum potuit, quia tempora eo stante transibant. Stabat tanto robustius, quanto semper stanti arctius inhaerebat; sed postquam deliquit, in quodam se quasi lubrico temporalitatis posuit. Et quia cibum comedit vetitum, status sui protinus invenit defectum. Et mox offenso Creatore coepit ire cum tempore.
chunks.english: Before sin, the first man could have a fixed state because times passed while he remained standing. He stood all the more firmly the more closely he clung to the one who always stands. But after he sinned, he placed himself in a kind of slippery temporality. And because he ate the forbidden food, he immediately found the failure of his state. And soon, having offended the Creator, he began to move with time.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ad hoc in paradiso homo conditus fuerat, ut si se ad Conditoris sui obedientiam vinculis charitatis astringeret, ad coelestem angelorum patriam quandoque sine morte carnis transiret. Sic primus homo immortalis est conditus, ut tamen si peccaret mori posset; et sic mortalis est conditus, ut si non peccaret, mori etiam non posset, atque ex merito liberi arbitrii beatitudinem illius regionis attingeret, in qua vel peccare vel mori non posset.
chunks.english: Man was created in paradise for this purpose: that if he bound himself to obedience to his Creator with the bonds of charity, he might at some time pass to the heavenly homeland of the angels without the death of the flesh. Thus the first man was created immortal, yet in such a way that if he sinned he could die. And he was created mortal in such a way that if he did not sin, he could not die, and by the merit of free will he would attain the blessedness of that region in which he could neither sin nor die.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In aeternae beatitudinis felicitate, ubi post redemptionis tempus, morte interposita, electi transeunt, illuc procul dubio parentes primi, si in conditionis suae statu perstitissent, etiam sine morte corporum transferri potuissent.
chunks.english: Into the happiness of eternal blessedness, where after the time of redemption, with death intervening, the elect pass—there without doubt the first parents, if they had persisted in the state of their creation, could have been transferred even without the death of their bodies.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quasi quoddam silentium primus homo conditus habuit, cum contra hostem suum liberum voluntatis arbitrium accepit. Cui quia sua sponte succubuit, mox de se quod contra se perstreperet invenit. Quamvis silentio homo ab Auctore fuerit conditus, hosti tamen sponte substratus, clamores de pugna toleravit. Ipsa enim carnis suggestio quasi quidam clamor est contra quietem mentis.
chunks.english: The first man had, as it were, a kind of silence when he received free will against his enemy. Because he yielded to the enemy of his own accord, he immediately found in himself something that clamored against him. Although man was created in silence by the Author, yet having voluntarily submitted to the enemy, he endured the clamors of battle. For the very suggestion of the flesh is like a certain clamor against the quiet of the mind.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XXIII]
De lignis paradisi et ligno scientiae boni et mali.
chunks.english: Chapter 23: On the Trees of Paradise and the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XXXV, c. 14, n. 29.) In paradiso nequaquam mala arbor exstitit, quam Deus homini ne contingeret interdixit. Sed ut melius per obedientiae meritum homo bene conditus cresceret, dignum fuerat ut hunc etiam a bono prohiberet; quatenus tanto verius hoc quod ageret virtus esset, quanto et a bono cessans auctori suo se subditum humilius exhiberet.
chunks.english: There was by no means an evil tree in paradise that God forbade man to touch. But so that man, who was well created, might grow better through the merit of obedience, it was fitting that God should forbid him even from a good thing—so that what he did would be all the more truly virtue, because by refraining even from good he would show himself more humbly subject to his Author.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex omni ligno paradisi, inquit Deus, edite, de ligno autem scientiae boni et mali ne tetigeritis (Gen. II, 16). Qui enim ab uno quolibet bono subjectos vetat, necesse est ut multa concedat, ne obedientis mens funditus intereat, si a bonis omnibus penitus repulsa jejunat.
chunks.english: God said, according to the book of Genesis, chapter two, verse sixteen, 'Eat from every tree of paradise, but from the tree of knowledge of good and evil do not touch.' For whoever forbids subjects from any one good thing must necessarily grant many things, lest the mind of the obedient person perish utterly if, completely repelled from all good things, it starves.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omnes paradisi arbores ad esum Dominus concessit cum ab una prohibuit, ut creaturam suam, quam nolebat exstingui sed provehi, tanto facilius ab una restringeret, quanto ad cunctas latius relaxaret.
chunks.english: The Lord granted all the trees of paradise for food when he forbade one, so that he might more easily restrain his creature, whom he did not wish to be destroyed but to advance, from one tree, the more broadly he allowed access to all the rest.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Fall of the First Man
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XXIV]
De praevaricatione primi hominis.
chunks.english: Chapter 24: On the Transgression of the First Man

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XXIV, c. 7, n. 14.) Callidus hostis et humani generis inimicus quod in paradiso egit hoc quotidie agere non desistit. Verba quippe Dei de cordibus hominum molitur evellere, atque in eis ficta promissionis suae blandimenta radicare: quotidie antiquus hostis id quod Deus minatur levigat, et ad hoc credendum quod falsum promittit in vitat.
chunks.english: The cunning enemy and adversary of the human race does not cease to do daily what he did in paradise. He labors to uproot God's words from human hearts and to plant in them the false enticements of his promise. Daily the ancient enemy smooths over what God threatens and invites people to believe what he falsely promises.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Falso enim pollicetur temporalia, ut mentibus hominum ea supplicia leviget quae Deus minatur aeterna. Humani generis adversarius, cum praesentis vitae gloriam spondet, quid aliud dicit quam Gustate, et eritis sicut dii (Gen. III, 5)? Ac si aperte diceret: Temporalem concupiscentiam tangite, et in hoc mundo sublimes apparete.
chunks.english: For he falsely promises temporal things in order to minimize in human minds the eternal punishments that God threatens. The adversary of the human race, when he promises the glory of present life, what else does he say but, according to the book of Genesis, chapter three, verse five, 'Taste, and you will be like gods'? As if he were saying openly: Touch temporal desire, and appear exalted in this world.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Antiquus hostis, cum a cordibus hominum timorem divinae sententiae amovere conatur, quid aliud loquitur quam id quod primis hominibus dixit: Cur praecepit vobis Deus ut non comederetis de omni ligno paradisi (Ibid., 1)? Sed quia divino munere redemptus homo justitiam recepit quam dudum conditus amisit, robustior se jam contra blandimenta callidae persuasionis exercet, quia experimento didicit quantum obediens esse debeat praecepto.
chunks.english: When the ancient enemy tries to remove the fear of divine judgment from human hearts, what else does he speak but what he said to the first humans, 'Why did God command you not to eat from every tree of paradise?' But because redeemed man has received by divine gift the justice he lost when he was created long ago, he now exercises himself more strongly against the enticements of cunning persuasion, because he has learned by experience how obedient he ought to be to the commandment.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et quem tunc culpa duxit ad poenam, nunc poena sua restringit a culpa: ut tanto magis delinquere metuat, quanto, cogente supplicio, et ipse jam quod perpetravit accusat.
chunks.english: And whereas guilt then led him to punishment, now his punishment restrains him from guilt—so that he fears to sin all the more because, compelled by punishment, he now accuses what he has committed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Evang., homil. 16, n. 2, 3.) Callidus adversarius contra primum hominem parentem nostrum in tribus se tentationibus erexit, quia hunc videlicet gula, vana gloria et avaritia tentavit; sed tentando superavit, quia sibi eum per consensum subdidit.
chunks.english: The cunning adversary raised himself against the first man, our parent, in three temptations, because he tempted him through gluttony, vainglory, and avarice. But by tempting he overcame him, because he subjected him to himself through consent.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex gula quippe tentavit, cum cibum ligni vetitum ostendit, atque ad comedendum suasit. Ex vana gloria tentavit, cum diceret: Eritis sicut dii (Gen. III, 5). Ex avaritia tentavit, cum diceret: Scientes bonum et malum (Ibid.). In hoc ergo eum ad superbiam traxit, quod illum ad avaritiam sublimitatis excitavit.
chunks.english: He tempted through gluttony when he showed the food of the forbidden tree and persuaded them to eat. He tempted through vainglory when he said, 'You will be like gods.' He tempted through avarice when he said, 'Knowing good and evil.' Thus he drew him to pride by stirring him to the avarice of loftiness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quibus modis diabolus primum hominem stravit, eisdem modis secundo homini tentato succubuit. Per gulam tentavit, cum dixit: Dic ut lapides isti panes fiant (Matth. IV, 3). Per vanam gloriam tentavit, cum dixit: Si Filius Dei es, mitte te deorsum (Ibid., 6). Per sublimitatis avaritiam tentavit, cum regna omnia mundi ostendit, dicens: Haec omnia tibi dabo, si cadens adoraveris me (Ibid., 9).
chunks.english: By the same means the devil overthrew the first man, by those same means he was defeated when he tempted the second man. He tempted through gluttony when he said, according to the Gospel of Matthew, chapter four, verse three, 'Command these stones to become bread.' He tempted through vainglory when he said, 'If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down.' He tempted through the avarice of loftiness when he showed all the kingdoms of the world, saying, 'All these I will give you if you fall down and worship me.'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral. XXVIII, c. 1, n. 6.] Quid est quod ad auram post meridiem Dominus deambulat, nisi quod lux ferventior charitatis abscesserat, et peccatricem animam culpae suae frigora constringebant?
chunks.english: What does it mean that the Lord walks in the breeze after midday, except that the more fervent light of charity had departed, and the coldness of guilt was constricting the sinful soul?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Increpavit ergo Adam deambulans, ut caecis mentibus nequitiam suam non solum sermonibus, sed etiam rebus aperiret; quatenus peccator homo, et per verba quod fecerat audiret, et per deambulationem, amisso aeternitatis statu, mutabilitatis suae inconstantiam cerneret, et per auram fervore charitatis expulso, torporem suum animadverteret, et per declinationem solis cognosceret quod ad tenebras propinquaret.
chunks.english: Therefore he rebuked Adam by walking, so that to blind minds he might reveal their wickedness not only by words but also by things—so that sinful man might hear through words what he had done, and through the walking, having lost the state of eternity, might perceive the inconstancy of his changeability, and through the breeze, with the fervor of charity expelled, might notice his torpor, and through the declining of the sun might know that he was approaching darkness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. II, c. 5, n. 6.) Scriptum est: Vocavit Deus Adam, et dixit ei: Ubi es (Gen. III, 9)? Quid est quod Dominus Adam post lapsum requirit, dicens: Ubi es? Nunquidnam divina potentia nesciebat post culpam servus ad quae latibula fugerat?
chunks.english: It is written, according to the book of Genesis, chapter three, verse nine, 'God called Adam and said to him, Where are you?' What does it mean that the Lord seeks Adam after the fall, saying, 'Where are you?' Did divine power not know to what hiding places the servant had fled after his guilt?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed quia vidit in culpa lapsum, jam sub peccato velut ab oculis veritatis absconditum, quia tenebras erroris ejus non approbat, quasi ubi sit peccator ignorat. Omnipotens Dominus Adam et vocat et requirit, dicens: Ubi es? Per hoc quod vocat, signum dat quia ad poenitentiam revocat. Per hoc quod requirit, aperte insinuat quia peccatores jure damnatos non ignorat.
chunks.english: But because he saw him fallen in guilt, now hidden from the eyes of truth as it were under sin—because he does not approve the darkness of his error—he acts as if he does not know where the sinner is. The almighty Lord both calls Adam and seeks him, saying, 'Where are you?' By calling, he gives a sign that he is calling back to repentance. By seeking, he openly suggests that he does not fail to know sinners who are justly condemned.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XI, c. 43, n. 59.) Humanum genus contemplationem lucis intimae habuit in paradiso; sed sibimetipsi placens, quod ad se recessit, lumen Conditoris perdidit ejusque faciem; ad ligna paradisi fugit, quia post culpam videre metuebat quem amare consueverat.
chunks.english: The human race possessed contemplation of interior light in paradise. But pleasing itself, it withdrew to itself, lost the light of the Creator and his face, and fled to the trees of paradise, because after sin it feared to see him whom it had been accustomed to love.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed ecce post culpam venit in poenam, ex poena autem ad amorem redit, quia quis fuerit culpae fructus invenit; atque illam faciem quam timuit in culpa, excitatus requirit ex poena: ut jam caliginem caecitatis suae fugiat, atque hoc ipsum quod Auctorem suum non videt graviter perhorrescat.
chunks.english: But behold, after guilt it came into punishment, and from punishment it returns to love, because it discovered what the fruit of guilt was. And aroused by punishment, it seeks that face which it feared in guilt—so that it may now flee the fog of its blindness and severely dread the very fact that it does not see its Author.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin:
[CAPUT XXV]
De mutatione et volubilitate temporum.
chunks.english: Chapter 25: On the Change and Instability of Times

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XI, c. 50, n. 68.) Fixum statum temporum in praesenti saeculo habere non possumus, ubi transituri venimus atque hoc ipsum nostrum vivere quotidie a vita transire est. Quem videlicet lapsum temporum primus homo ante culpam habere non potuit, quia tempora, eo stante, transibant.
chunks.english: We cannot have a fixed state of times in the present age, where we come to pass away and our very living is daily a passing from life. This lapse of times the first man could not have before sin, because times passed while he remained standing.
chunks.notes: The chunk ends mid-section but this is the last complete chunk under 800 tokens

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: lib. XXV, c. 3, n. 4.) Nos quippe, quia de propagine primi homis nascimur, radicis amaritudinem quasi in virgulto retinemus. Nam quia ex illo originem ducimus, ejus cursum nascendo sortimur, ut eo ipso momento quotidiano quo vivimus incessanter a vita transeamus, et vivendi nobis spatium unde crescere creditur, inde decrescat. Dum infantia ad pueritiam, pueritia ad adolescentiam, adolescentia ad juventutem, senectus transit ad mortem in cursu vitae praesentis, ipsis suis augmentis ad detrimentum miser homo compellitur, et inde semper deficit unde se proficere in spatium vitae credit.
chunks.english: We, because we are born from the first man's lineage, retain the bitterness of the root as in a sapling. For since we derive our origin from him, we inherit his trajectory through birth, so that in the very daily moment in which we live, we unceasingly pass from life, and the space of living that we believe increases actually decreases. While infancy passes to boyhood, boyhood to adolescence, adolescence to youth, and old age passes to death in the course of present life, wretched humanity is compelled toward decline by its very growth, and always loses ground at the very point where it believes itself advancing in the span of life.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Discord Between Angels and Fallen Humanity
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXVI] De discordia angelorum sanctorum atque hominum sub praevaricatione constitutorum.
chunks.english: Chapter 26: On the discord between the holy angels and human beings established under transgression.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ev., homil. 8, n. 2.) Priusquam Redemptor noster per carnem nasceretur, discordiam cum angelis habuimus, a quorum claritate atque munditia per primae culpae meritum, per quotidiana delicta, longe distabamus. Quia ergo peccando extranei eramus a Deo, extraneos nos a suo consortio deputabant Angeli cives Dei. Sed quia nos cognovimus Regem nostrum, recognoverunt nos Angeli cives suos. Quia coeli Rex terram nostrae carnis assumpsit, infirmitatem nostram angelica celsitudo non despicit. Ad pacem nostram Angeli redeunt, intentionem prioris discordiae postponunt: et quos infirmos prius, abjectosque despexerunt, jam socios venerantur.
chunks.english: Before our Redeemer was born in the flesh, we had discord with the angels. Through the merit of the first sin and through daily transgressions, we were far removed from their brightness and purity. Because we were estranged from God through sin, the angels who are citizens of God regarded us as strangers to their company. But because we have acknowledged our King, the angels have recognized us as their fellow citizens. Because the King of heaven has taken on the earth of our flesh, angelic majesty does not despise our weakness. The angels return to peace with us, setting aside the intention of former discord, and those whom they previously despised as weak and abject, they now honor as companions.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In veteri testamento Loth, et Josue Angelos adorant, nec tamen adorare prohibentur: Johannes in Apocalypsi adorare Angelum voluit, sed tamen idem hunc Angelus, ne se adorare debeat, compescuit, dicens: Vide ne feceris: conservus tuus sum et fratrum tuorum.
chunks.english: In the Old Testament, Lot and Joshua adore the angels, and yet they are not prohibited from adoring. In the Apocalypse, John wished to adore the angel, but the same angel restrained him from adoring, saying: See that you do not do this: I am your fellow servant and that of your brothers.
chunks.notes: The biblical reference to John's encounter with the angel is from the book of Revelation (Apocalypse), chapter 19, verse 10, and chapter 22, verse 9.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid est, quod ante Redemptoris adventum Angeli ab hominibus adorantur, et tacent, postmodum vero adorari refugiunt: nisi quod naturam nostram, quam prius despexerunt, postquam hanc super se adsumptam conspiciunt, substratam sibi videre pertimescunt? Nec jam sub se velut infirmam contemnere ausi sunt, quam super se videlicet in coeli Rege venerantur. Nec habere dedignantur hominem socium, qui super se adorant hominem Deum.
chunks.english: What does it mean that before the Redeemer's coming, angels are adored by humans and remain silent, but afterward they refuse to be adored? It is because they fear to see our nature, which they previously despised, placed beneath them after they behold it assumed above themselves. They no longer dare to despise as weak beneath them what they venerate above themselves in the King of heaven. Those who adore the God-man above themselves do not disdain to have a human being as their companion.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Heavenly Jerusalem and Its Citizens
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXVII] De Jerusalem coelesti vel ejus civibus.
chunks.english: Chapter 27: On the heavenly Jerusalem and its citizens.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech. homil. I, n. 5.) Jerusalem visio pacis interpretatur. Hi nimirum in Jerusalem habitant qui in visione pacis intimae mentem figunt. Scriptum quippe est: Jerusalem quae aedificatur ut civitas (Psal. CXXI, 3). Quia enim illa internae pacis visio ex sanctorum civium congregatione construitur, Jerusalem coelestis ut civitas aedificatur. Superna illa Jerusalem civitas dum in hac peregrinationis terra flagellis percutitur, tribulationibus tunditur, ejus lapides quotidie quadrantur.
chunks.english: Jerusalem is interpreted to mean vision of peace. Those dwell in Jerusalem who fix their minds on the vision of intimate peace. For it is written: Jerusalem which is built as a city, according to the Psalms, chapter one hundred twenty-one, verse three. Because that vision of interior peace is constructed from the gathering of holy citizens, heavenly Jerusalem is built as a city. While that supernal city of Jerusalem is struck with scourges and beaten with tribulations on this land of pilgrimage, its stones are squared daily.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipsa est civitas, scilicet sancta Ecclesia, quae regnatura in coelo adhuc laborat in terra: cujus civibus Petrus dicit: Et vos tanquam lapides vivi superaedificamini (I Petr. II, 5). Et Paulus ait: Dei agricultura, Dei aedificatio estis (I Cor. III, 9). Jerusalem civitas habet hic in sanctorum moribus magnum jam aedificium suum. In aedificio quippe lapis super lapidem ponitur, et qui portat alterum portatur ab altero.
chunks.english: This is the city, namely the holy Church, which while destined to reign in heaven still labors on earth. To its citizens Peter says: You also, as living stones, are built up, according to Peter's first letter, chapter two, verse five. And Paul says: You are God's cultivation, God's building, according to Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter three, verse nine. The city of Jerusalem already has its great edifice here in the conduct of the saints. For in a building, stone is placed upon stone, and whoever bears another is borne by another.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 9, n. 10.) Isaias propheta ait: Vivit Dominus, cujus ignis est in Sion, et caminus ejus in Jerusalem (Isai. XXXI, 9). Plus est enim caminum esse quam ignem, quia ignis esse et parvus potest, in camino autem vastior flamma succenditur. Sion vero speculatio, Jerusalem autem visio pacis dicitur, pacem vero nostram hic interim speculamur, ut illic postmodum plene videamus.
chunks.english: The prophet Isaiah says: The Lord lives, whose fire is in Zion and whose furnace is in Jerusalem, according to the book of Isaiah, chapter thirty-one, verse nine. For it is greater to be a furnace than to be a fire, because fire can be small, but in a furnace a vaster flame is kindled. Zion means watchfulness, while Jerusalem means vision of peace. We contemplate our peace here in the meantime, that we may afterward see it fully there.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex amore omnipotentis Domini in Sion ignis est, in Jerusalem vero caminus; quia hic amoris ejus flammis aliquatenus ardemus ubi de illo aliquid contemplamur. Sed ibi plene ardebimus ubi plene videbimus quem amamus.
chunks.english: From love of the almighty Lord there is fire in Zion, but a furnace in Jerusalem, because here we burn somewhat with the flames of his love where we contemplate something of him. But there we shall burn fully where we shall fully see him whom we love.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXVIII] De Babylonia ejusque civibus.
chunks.english: Chapter 28: On Babylon and its citizens.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XIV, c. 53, n. 65; VI, c. 16, n. 25.) Sciendum est quod Sennaar latissima vallis est, in qua turris Babyloniae a superbientibus aedificari coeperat. Sennaar quippe interpretatur fetor eorum: quae turris linguarum facta diversitate destructa est, quae et Babylon dicta est, pro ipsa videlicet confusione mentium atque linguarum. Babylon confusio interpretatur.
chunks.english: It should be known that Shinar is a very broad valley in which the proud began to build the tower of Babylon. Shinar is interpreted to mean their stench. This tower was destroyed when the diversity of languages was made, and it was called Babylon, precisely because of the confusion of minds and languages. Babylon is interpreted to mean confusion.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Recte igitur infecunda mens Babylonis filia nuncupatur, quae in eo quod nequaquam bona opera germinat, dum nullo ordine rectae vitae componitur, quasi confusione matre generatur. Scriptum est: Descende, sede in pulvere, virgo filia Babylon, sede in terra; non est solium filiae Chaldaeorum (Isai. XLVII, 1).
chunks.english: The unfruitful mind is therefore rightly called the daughter of Babylon. Because it in no way brings forth good works, while it is arranged by no order of right life, it is as if generated by confusion as its mother. It is written: Descend, sit in the dust, virgin daughter of Babylon, sit on the ground; there is no throne for the daughter of the Chaldeans, according to the book of Isaiah, chapter forty-seven, verse one.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Humana igitur mens, postquam statum salutis perdidit, ad confusionis suae cumulum, appellatur virgo, vel incorrupta, quod dudum fuit, cui apte per increpationem dicitur divina voce, Descende. In alto quippe humanus animus stat quando supernis retributionibus inhiat, sed ab hoc statu descendit cum, turpiter victus, sese defluentibus mundi desideriis subjicit.
chunks.english: The human mind, after it has lost the state of salvation and added to the heap of its confusion, is called virgin or uncorrupted for what it once was. To it the divine voice aptly says by way of rebuke: Descend. For the human soul stands on high when it yearns for heavenly rewards, but it descends from this state when, shamefully conquered, it subjects itself to the flowing desires of the world.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XIV, c. 17, n. 21.) Certissime filiae Babylonis dicitur: Sede in pulvere; cum enim semper terra sit pulvis, quid per pulverem nisi cogitationes debemus accipere? Quae dum importune ac silenter in mente volant, ejus oculos excaecant. Et quid per terram, nisi terrena actio designatur? Reproborum mens prius ad cogitanda prava dejicitur, et postmodum ad facienda.
chunks.english: Most certainly it is said to the daughter of Babylon: Sit in the dust. Since earth is always dust, what should we understand by dust except thoughts? These, while they fly inopportunely and silently in the mind, blind its eyes. And what is designated by earth except earthly action? The mind of the reprobate is first cast down to thinking depraved things, and afterward to doing them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Recte ergo filiae Babylon, quae ab hoc internae rectitudinis judicio descendit, per ferientem sententiam dicitur ut prius in pulvere et post in terra sedeat, quia nisi se in cogitatione prosterneret, in malo opere non haesisset. (Moral. VI, 16, n. 25.) Descendens enim, in pulvere residet, quia coelestia deserens, terrenis cogitationibus aspersa in infimis vilescit.
chunks.english: Rightly, therefore, it is said to the daughter of Babylon, who descends from this judgment of interior righteousness, through a striking sentence, that she should first sit in dust and then on earth, because unless she had prostrated herself in thought, she would not have stuck fast in evil work. For descending, she sits in dust, because abandoning heavenly things and sprinkled with earthly thoughts, she becomes worthless in the lowest things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. III, 31, n. 60.) Sunt nonnulli qui, cum parva agunt, de semetipsis magna sentiunt. In altum mentem sublevant, et praeire se caeteros virtutum meritis putant. Hi nimirum apud se introrsum humilitatis sterquilinium deserunt, et elationis fastigia ascendunt. Illum videlicet imitantes qui primus se apud se extulit, sed elevando prostravit.
chunks.english: There are some who, while doing small things, think great things of themselves. They lift up their mind on high and think they surpass others in the merit of virtues. These indeed abandon within themselves the dunghill of humility and ascend the heights of pride, imitating him who first exalted himself before himself but by lifting himself up cast himself down.
chunks.notes: Reference to Lucifer's fall.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Illum imitantes qui accepta conditionis dignitate contentus non fuit, dicens: In coelum conscendam, super astra coeli exaltabo solium meum (Isai. XIV, 13). Apostatae angelo male conjuncta Babylonia, id est, confusa multitudo peccantium dicit: Sedeo regina, et vidua non sum (Isai. XLVII, 8, secund. LXX).
chunks.english: Imitating him who was not content with the dignity of his created condition, saying: I will ascend to heaven, I will exalt my throne above the stars of heaven, according to the book of Isaiah, chapter fourteen, verse thirteen. Babylon, wickedly joined to the apostate angel, that is, the confused multitude of sinners, says: I sit as queen and I am not a widow, according to the book of Isaiah, chapter forty-seven, verse eight, following the Septuagint.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quisquis ergo introrsus intumescit, in altum se apud semetipsum posuit, sed eo se gravius in infimis deprimit quod de se infima veraciter sentire contemnit. (Moral. V, 21, n. 41.) Leaenae nomine aliquando hujus mundi civitas, id est, Babylonia, designatur, quae contra vitam innocentium immanitate crudelitatis efferatur, quae antiquo hosti, quasi saevissimo leoni, sociata, perversae persuasionis ejus semina concipit, et reprobos ex se filios ad similitudinem illius, quasi crudeles catulos gignit.
chunks.english: Whoever therefore swells up inwardly has placed himself on high before himself, but the more heavily presses himself down into the lowest things in that he scorns to feel truly about himself the lowest things. The city of this world, that is Babylon, is sometimes designated by the name of lioness, which rages with savagery of cruelty against the life of the innocent. United to the ancient enemy as to a most savage lion, she conceives the seeds of his perverse persuasion and begets from herself reprobate sons in his likeness, as it were cruel cubs.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Catuli leonum sunt quilibet reprobi ad iniquam vitam malignorum spirituum errore generati, qui et simul omnes universam mundi civitatem, quam praediximus, Babyloniam faciunt, et tamen hi iidem singuli Babyloniae filii, quasi non leaena, sed leaenae catuli vocantur. Sicut Sion tota simul Ecclesia dicitur, filii autem Sion sanctorum quique singuli memorantur; ita et filii Babyloniae singuli quique reproborum, et eadem Babylonia simul omnes reprobi vocantur.
chunks.english: The cubs of lions are any reprobates generated unto iniquitous life by the error of malignant spirits. All together they make up the universal city of the world, which we mentioned before as Babylon, and yet these same individuals are called sons of Babylon, as though not the lioness herself but the lioness's cubs. Just as Zion means the whole Church together, while the sons of Zion are remembered as individual saints, so also the sons of Babylon are individual reprobates, and the same Babylon means all the reprobate together.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 42.) Sancti viri quandiu in hac vita sunt, semetipsos sollicita circumspectione custodiunt, ne leo circuiens insidiando subripiat, id est, antiquus hostis sub aliqua imagine virtutis occidat; et leaenae vox auribus obstrepat, id est, ne Babyloniae gloria sensum ab amore coelestis patriae avertat.
chunks.english: Holy men, as long as they are in this life, guard themselves with anxious watchfulness lest the circling lion steal upon them by ambush, that is, lest the ancient enemy kill them under some image of virtue, and lest the voice of the lioness clamor in their ears, that is, lest the glory of Babylon turn their mind away from love of the heavenly homeland.
chunks.notes: Reference to 1 Peter 5:8 regarding the devil as a roaring lion.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXIX] Quid significet arca diluvii.
chunks.english: Chapter 29: What the ark of the flood signifies.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 4, n. 16.) Arca diluvii, quae inferius ampla, superius vero angusta describitur, sancta Ecclesia figuratur, quae a trecentis et sexaginta ac triginta cubitis ad unum cubitum colligitur (Gen. VI, 15); quia ab ea latitudine quam sancta Ecclesia in membris suis adhuc infirmantibus habet, paulisper angustata, et in altum proficiens, ad unum tendit.
chunks.english: The ark of the flood, which is described as broad below but narrow above, represents the holy Church. It is gathered from three hundred and sixty and thirty cubits to one cubit, according to the book of Genesis, chapter six, verse fifteen. From that breadth which the holy Church has in its still weak members, gradually narrowed and advancing upward, it tends toward the one.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ratio exigit ut credamus quod in illa arcae latitudine omnes bestiae cunctaque quadrupedia atque reptilia in inferioribus fuerunt, homo vero atque volatilia nimirum in superioribus. Juxta superiorem etenim partem fenestra fuit in latere, de qua corvum vel columbam dimisit homo, ut si jam diluvii transissent aquae, cognosceret.
chunks.english: Reason requires that we believe that in that breadth of the ark all beasts and all quadrupeds and reptiles were in the lower parts, while man and birds were naturally in the upper parts. For near the upper part there was a window in the side, from which the man sent out a raven or dove to learn whether the waters of the flood had already passed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et quia arca eadem in uno fuit cubito consummata, homo et volatilia juxta cubitum fuerunt. Recte per arcam universa Ecclesia designatur, quae adhuc in multis suis carnalibus lata est, in paucis spiritualibus angusta. Et quia ad unum hominem, qui est sine peccato, colligitur, quasi in uno cubito consummatur.
chunks.english: And because the same ark was completed in one cubit, man and birds were near the cubit. The universal Church is rightly designated by the ark, which is still broad in its many carnal members, narrow in its few spiritual ones. And because it is gathered to one man who is without sin, it is as if completed in one cubit.
chunks.notes: The one man without sin is Christ.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Evang. homil. 38, n. 8.) Arca in undis diluvii Ecclesiae typum gessit, quia scilicet ampla in inferioribus et angusta in superioribus fuit; quae in summitate etiam sua ad unius mensuram cubiti excrevit. Inferius quippe quadrupedia atque reptilia, superius vero aves et homines habuisse credenda est.
chunks.english: The ark on the waves of the flood bore the type of the Church, because it was broad in the lower parts and narrow in the upper, and at its summit it grew to the measure of one cubit. Below it is to be believed that it held quadrupeds and reptiles, but above, birds and humans.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ibi lata exstitit arca ubi bestias habuit, ibi angusta ubi homines servavit, quia nimirum sancta Ecclesia in carnalibus ampla est, in spiritualibus angusta. Ubi enim bestiales hominum mores tolerat, illic latius sinum laxat. Ubi autem eos habet qui spirituali ratione suffulti sunt, illic quidem ad summum ducitur, sed tamen, quia pauci sunt, angustatur.
chunks.english: The ark was broad where it held beasts, narrow where it preserved humans, because the holy Church is indeed broad in carnal members, narrow in spiritual ones. For where it tolerates beastly human conduct, there it extends its embrace more widely. But where it has those who are sustained by spiritual reason, there indeed it is led to the summit, but nevertheless, because they are few, it is narrowed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Lata quippe via est quae ducit ad perditionem, et multi sunt qui vadunt per eam: et angusta porta est quae ducit ad vitam, et pauci sunt qui inveniunt eam (Matth. VII, 13). Eo usque arca angustatur in summis, quousque ad mensuram unius cubiti perducatur: quia in sancta Ecclesia quanto sanctiores quique sunt, tanto pauciores.
chunks.english: For broad is the way that leads to destruction, and many are those who go through it, and narrow is the gate that leads to life, and few are those who find it, according to the Gospel of Matthew, chapter seven, verse thirteen. The ark is narrowed at the top to the point that it is brought to the measure of one cubit, because in the holy Church the holier each one is, the fewer they are.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae in summo ad illum perducitur, qui solus homo in hominibus, et sine ullius comparatione natus est sanctus. Qui, juxta Psalmistae vocem, Factus est sicut passer unicus in aedificio (Ps. CI, 8).
chunks.english: It is brought at the summit to him who alone is man among men, and who was born holy without any comparison. He who, according to the voice of the Psalmist, has been made like a solitary sparrow on a house, according to the Psalms, chapter one hundred one, verse eight.
chunks.notes: Reference to Christ as uniquely holy.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Elect Before and Under the Law
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXX] De electis ante legem vel sub lege exortis.
chunks.english: Chapter 30: On the elect who arose before the law or under the law.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. IV, 32, n. 65.) Multi electi ab ipso mundi primordio ante redemptionis tempus exorti sunt, et tamen huic mundo semetipsos mortificare curaverunt. Qui conscriptae legis tabulas non habentes, quasi ab utero mortui sunt, quia Auctorem suum naturali lege timuerunt; et cum venturum Mediatorem crederent, studuerunt summopere mortificandis voluptatibus etiam quae scripta non acceperant praecepta servare.
chunks.english: Many elect arose from the very beginning of the world before the time of redemption, and yet they took care to mortify themselves to this world. Not having the tablets of the written law, they were as if dead from the womb, because they feared their Author by natural law. And when they believed the Mediator was to come, they strove mightily to observe even those precepts they had not received in writing, mortifying pleasures.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tempus illud quod juxta mundi initium mortuos huic saeculo patres nostros protulit quasi abortivi uterus fuit. Ibi namque Abel, qui occidenti se fratri restitisse non legitur (Gen. IV, 8, 24). Ibi Enoch, qui talem exhibuit vitam, ut ambulaturus cum Domino transferretur (Gen. V, 22). Noe scilicet, per hoc quod divino examini placuit, in mundum mundo superstes fuit (Gen. VII, 23).
