chunks.english: That time which near the world's beginning brought forth our fathers dead to this age was like an aborting womb. For there was Abel, who is not read to have resisted his murdering brother, according to the book of Genesis, chapter four, verses eight and twenty-four. There was Enoch, who displayed such a life that he was translated to walk with the Lord, according to the book of Genesis, chapter five, verse twenty-two. There was Noah, who through pleasing the divine judgment survived the world while the world perished, according to the book of Genesis, chapter seven, verse twenty-three.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Abraham patriarcha, dum peregrinus exstitit saeculo, factus est amicus Deo (Gen. XII, 1). Isaac quippe caligantibus carnis oculis, per aetatem quidem praesentia non vidit, sed per virtutem prophetici spiritus, in futuris etiam saeculis magna videndi luce radiavit (Gen. XXVII, 1). Jacob iram fratris humiliter fugit, clementer edomuit (Gen. XXXIII, 4). Qui prole quidem fecundus exstitit, sed tamen spiritus ubertate fecundior, eamdem prolem sub prophetiae suae vinculis astrinxit.
chunks.english: Abraham the patriarch, while he remained a stranger to the age, became a friend to God, according to the book of Genesis, chapter twelve, verse one. Isaac, with the eyes of flesh growing dim, through age did not see present things, but through the power of prophetic spirit he shone with great light of seeing even in future ages, according to the book of Genesis, chapter twenty-seven, verse one. Jacob humbly fled his brother's wrath and mercifully tamed it, according to the book of Genesis, chapter thirty-three, verse four. He was fruitful in offspring, but even more fruitful in abundance of spirit, binding that same offspring under the bonds of his prophecy.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: A mundi primordiis, dum quosdam paucos electos Mose scribente cognoscimus, pars nobis maxima humani generis occultatur. Neque enim tot justos solummodo usque ad acceptam legem exstitisse credendum est, quot Moses brevissima descriptione perstrinxit. Quia ergo a mundi primordio edita multitudo bonorum ex magna parte notitiae nostrae subtrahitur, quasi abortiuum absconditum vocatur (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. I, n. 4).
chunks.english: From the world's beginnings, while we know a few elect through Moses' writing, the greater part of the human race is hidden from us. For it should not be believed that only as many just men existed until the reception of the law as Moses touched upon in his very brief description. Because, therefore, the multitude of good people brought forth from the world's beginning is for the most part withdrawn from our knowledge, it is called a hidden miscarriage.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Fuerunt in Israelitico populo sancti viri patriarchae atque prophetae qui montes jure vocarentur, quia per vitae meritum ad coelestia propinquaverunt. Sed incarnatus Unigenitus istis montibus aequalis non fuit, quia naturam, vitam, et merita omnium ex sua divinitate transcendit. Dominus Jesus Christus mons super verticem montium dicitur, quia excelsus ex divinitate sua inventus est etiam super cacumina sanctorum (Isai. II, 2), ut hi, qui multum in Deo profecerunt, ejus vestigia vix potuissent tangere ex vertice cogitationis.
chunks.english: There were in the Israelite people holy men, patriarchs and prophets, who could justly be called mountains, because through the merit of their life they drew near to heavenly things. But the incarnate Only-begotten was not equal to these mountains, because he transcended the nature, life, and merits of all by his divinity. The Lord Jesus Christ is called a mountain above the summit of mountains, because he was found exalted by his divinity even above the peaks of the saints, according to the book of Isaiah, chapter two, verse two, so that those who advanced much in God could scarcely touch his footsteps from the summit of thought.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Electi, qui post acceptam legem in hoc mundo nati sunt, auctori suo ejusdem legis sunt admonitione concepti. (Moral. IV, c. 32, n. 64.) Sed tamen quasi concepti lucem minime viderunt. quia ad adventum incarnationis dominicae, quamvis hanc fideliter crederent, pervenire nequiverunt.
chunks.english: The elect who were born in this world after receiving the law were conceived for their Author by the admonition of that same law. But nevertheless, though conceived, they scarcely saw the light, because they could not arrive at the coming of the Lord's incarnation, although they faithfully believed in it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Incarnatus Dominus dicit: Ego sum lux mundi (Joann. VIII, 12). Atque ipsa Lux ait: Multi prophetae et justi desideraverunt videre quae videtis, et non viderunt (Matth. XIII, 17). Quia ad spem venturi Mediatoris apertis prophetarum vocibus excitati, nequaquam potuerunt cernere ejus incarnationem.
chunks.english: The incarnate Lord says: I am the light of the world, according to the Gospel of John, chapter eight, verse twelve. And that same Light says: Many prophets and just men desired to see what you see, and did not see it, according to the Gospel of Matthew, chapter thirteen, verse seventeen. Because aroused to hope of the coming Mediator by the open voices of the prophets, they could in no way behold his incarnation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ante adventum Redemptoris nostri multitudo electorum formam quidem fidei habuit, sed hanc usque ad apertam visionem divinae praesentiae non perduxit, quia prius hos a mundo mors interveniens rapuit quam manifesta mundum veritas illustravit. (Moral. IV, c. 33, n. 66.) Mediatoris adventum, quem patres in lege positi diu praestolati sunt, ad vitae suae requiem populi gentiles invenerunt. Paulo attestante, qui ait: Quod quaerebat Israel, hoc non est consecutus, electio autem consecuta est (Rom. XI, 7).
chunks.english: Before the coming of our Redeemer, the multitude of the elect had the form of faith, but did not bring it to the open vision of divine presence, because intervening death snatched them from the world before manifest truth illuminated the world. The coming of the Mediator, which the fathers placed under the law long awaited, the gentile peoples found for the repose of their life. Paul attests to this, saying: What Israel sought, it did not obtain, but the elect obtained it, according to Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter eleven, verse seven.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXXI] De electis viris ante adventum Christi exortis.
chunks.english: Chapter 31: On elect men who arose before the coming of Christ.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Praef. in lib. Job, c. 6, n. 13.) Mira divinae dispensationis opera libet cernere quomodo ad illuminandam noctem vitae praesentis astra quaeque suis vicibus in coeli faciem veniant, quousque in finem noctis Redemptor humani generis, quasi verus Lucifer, surgat. Nocturnum namque spatium, dum decedentium succedentiumque stellarum cursibus illustratur, magno coeli decore peragitur.
chunks.english: It pleases us to observe the wondrous works of divine dispensation: how each star comes in its turn into the face of heaven to illuminate the night of present life, until at night's end the Redeemer of humankind rises like the true morning star. For the nocturnal span, while illuminated by the courses of departing and succeeding stars, is completed with great beauty of heaven.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut scilicet noctis nostrae tenebras suo tempore editus vicissimque permutatus stellarum radius tangeret, ad ostendendam innocentiam, venit Abel; ad docendam actionis munditiam, venit Enoch; ad insinuandam longanimitatem spei et operis, venit Noe; ad manifestandam obedientiam, venit Abraham; ad demonstrandam conjugalis vitae castimoniam, venit Isaac; ad insinuandam laboris tolerantiam, venit Jacob; ad rependendam pro malo bonae retributionis gratiam, venit Joseph; ad ostendendam mansuetudinem, venit Moses; ad informandam contra adversa fiduciam, venit Josue; ad ostendendam inter flagella patientiam, venit Job.
chunks.english: So that the ray of stars, brought forth in its time and exchanged in turn, might touch the darkness of our night: Abel came to show innocence; Enoch came to teach purity of action; Noah came to insinuate longsuffering of hope and work; Abraham came to manifest obedience; Isaac came to demonstrate the chastity of married life; Jacob came to insinuate the endurance of labor; Joseph came to repay the grace of good recompense for evil; Moses came to show meekness; Joshua came to form confidence against adversity; Job came to show patience amid scourges.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ecce quam fulgentes stellas in coelo figuraliter cernimus: ut inoffenso pede operis iter nostrae noctis ambulemus. Cognitioni hominum divina dispensatio quot justos exhibuit, quasi tot astra super peccantium tenebras coelum misit, quousque verus Lucifer surgeret, qui, aeternum nobis mane nuntians, stellis caeteris clarius ex divinitate radiaret.
chunks.english: Behold what shining stars we discern figuratively in heaven, so that we may walk the journey of our night with unhindered foot of work. Divine dispensation displayed as many just men to human knowledge as heaven sent stars above the darkness of sinners, until the true morning star should rise, who, announcing eternal morning to us, would shine more brightly than other stars by his divinity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 14.) Electi omnes dum Mediatorem Dei et hominum bene vivendo praeeunt, et rebus et vocibus prophetando promiserunt. Nullus etenim justus fuit qui non ejus per figuram nuntius exstiterit. Dignum quippe erat ut in semetipsis bonum omnes ostenderent, de quo et omnes boni essent, et quod prodesse omnibus scirent. Unde et sine cessatione promitti debuit, quod et sine aestimatione dabatur percipi, et sine fine retineri: ut simul omnia saecula dicerent quid in redemptione communi saeculorum finis exhiberet.
chunks.english: All the elect, while they preceded the Mediator of God and men by living well, promised him both in deeds and in voices by prophesying. For there was no just man who was not a messenger of him through figure. It was fitting that all should show in themselves the good from which all would be good, and which they knew would benefit all. Hence it had to be promised without ceasing, which was given to be perceived without estimation and to be retained without end, so that all ages together might declare what the end of ages would display in the common redemption.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXXII] De dilectione Dei et proximi.
chunks.english: Chapter 32: On the love of God and neighbor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Prima virtus obedientiae in charitate est; quae videlicet charitas in duobus praeceptis distinguitur, ut Deus et proximus diligatur. Et recta operatio ex decalogi completione perficitur, ut cum bona agi coeperint, mala jam nulla perpetrentur. (Moral. VII, c. 14, n. 28.) Duo sunt praecepta charitatis, dilectio videlicet Dei et dilectio proximi. Per quae utraque nos sacrae Scripturae dicta vivificant, quia dilectionem Dei et proximi capimus in eloquiis divinis.
chunks.english: The first virtue of obedience is in charity, which charity is distinguished in two precepts: that God and neighbor should be loved. And right action is perfected from the completion of the Decalogue, so that when good things begin to be done, no evil things are any longer committed. There are two precepts of charity: namely the love of God and the love of neighbor. Through both of these the sayings of Sacred Scripture give us life, because we grasp the love of God and neighbor in the divine words.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per amorem Dei amor proximi gignitur, et per amorem proximi Dei amor nutritur. Nam qui amare Deum negligit, profecto diligere proximum nescit. Tunc plenius in Dei dilectione proficimus, si in ejusdem dilectionis gremio prius proximi charitate lactamur. Quia amor Dei amorem proximi generat, dicturus per legem Dominus: Diliges proximum tuum, praemisit dicens: Diliges Dominum Deum tuum (Deut. VI, 5; X, 12; Matth. XXII, 37, 39); ut videlicet in terra pectoris nostri prius amoris sui radicem figeret, quatenus per ramos postmodum dilectio fraterna germinaret.
chunks.english: Through love of God, love of neighbor is begotten, and through love of neighbor, love of God is nourished. For he who neglects to love God assuredly does not know how to love neighbor. We advance more fully in love of God when we are first nursed in the bosom of that same love by charity toward neighbor. Because love of God generates love of neighbor, when the Lord was about to say through the law: You shall love your neighbor, he first said: You shall love the Lord your God, according to the book of Deuteronomy, chapter six, verse five; chapter ten, verse twelve; and the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-two, verses thirty-seven and thirty-nine. He did this so that he might first fix the root of his love in the earth of our heart, so that afterward fraternal love might germinate through branches.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Amor Dei ex proximi amore coalescit, sicut testatur Joannes, qui quosdam increpat, dicens: Qui non diligit fratrem suum quem videt, Deum, quem non videt, quomodo potest diligere (I Joan. IV, 20)? Quae tamen divina dilectio per timorem nascitur, sed in affectum crescendo permutatur.
chunks.english: Love of God grows strong from love of neighbor, as John testifies, rebuking certain people and saying: He who does not love his brother whom he sees, how can he love God whom he does not see? according to John's first letter, chapter four, verse twenty. Yet that divine love is born through fear, but is transformed into affection by growing.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 29.) Saepe omnipotens Deus, ut quantum quisque a charitate ejus et proximi longe sit, vel in ea quantum profecerit innotescat, miro ordine cuncta dispensans, alios flagellis deprimit, alios successibus fulcit. Et cum quosdam temporaliter deserit, in quorumdam cordibus quod malum latet ostendit. Nam plerumque ipsi nos miseros insequuntur qui felices sine comparatione coluerunt.
chunks.english: Almighty God often, disposing all things in wondrous order so that it may become known how far each one is from love of him and neighbor, or how much each has advanced in it, presses down some with scourges and supports others with successes. And when he temporarily abandons certain people, he shows what evil lies hidden in the hearts of some. For very often those who honored us beyond comparison when we were happy pursue us when we are wretched.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Evang. homil. 30, n. 10.) Inoffenso pede iter nostrum in terra agitur, si Deus et proximus integra mente diligatur. Nec Deus enim vere diligitur sine proximo, nec proximus vere diligitur sine Deo. Spiritus sanctus secundo legitur discipulis datus, prius a Domino in terra degente, postmodum a Domino coelo praesidente. In terra quippe, ut diligatur proximus; e coelo vero, ut diligatur Deus.
chunks.english: Our journey on earth is made with unhindered foot if God and neighbor are loved with whole mind. For God is not truly loved without neighbor, nor is neighbor truly loved without God. The Holy Spirit is read to have been given to the disciples twice: first by the Lord dwelling on earth, afterward by the Lord presiding in heaven. On earth, that neighbor might be loved; from heaven, that God might be loved.
chunks.notes: References to the two givings of the Holy Spirit: John 20:22 and Acts 2:1-4.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed cur prius in terra, postmodum e coelo, nisi quod patenter datur intelligi quia, juxta Joannis vocem, Qui fratrem suum non diligit quem videt, Deum, quem non videt, quomodo potest diligere (I Joan. IV, 20)? Amemus et amplectamur proximum, qui juxta nos est, ut pervenire valeamus ad amorem illius qui super nos est. Meditetur mens in proximo quod exhibeat Deo, ut perfecte mereamur in eo gaudere cum proximo.
chunks.english: But why first on earth, then from heaven, except that it is clearly given to be understood because, according to John's voice: He who does not love his brother whom he sees, how can he love God whom he does not see, according to John's first letter, chapter four, verse twenty? Let us love and embrace our neighbor who is beside us, so that we may be able to arrive at love of him who is above us. Let the mind meditate in neighbor what it may display to God, so that we may worthily rejoice in him perfectly with neighbor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tunc enim ad illam supernae frequentiae laetitiam perveniemus, de qua nunc sancti Spiritus pignus accepimus. Ad istum finem, scilicet ad dilectionem Dei et proximi, toto amore tendamus. Omne mandatum de sola dilectione est, et omnia unum praeceptum sunt. Quia quidquid praecipitur, in sola charitate solidatur.
chunks.english: For then we shall arrive at that joy of heavenly assembly, of which we have now received the pledge of the Holy Spirit. Let us tend with all love toward this end, namely toward the love of God and neighbor. Every commandment is about love alone, and all commandments are one precept. Because whatever is commanded is solidified in charity alone.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Praecepta dominica et multa sunt et unum: multa per diversitatem operis, unum in radice dilectionis. Qualiter dilectio Dei et proximi sit tenenda ipse insinuat qui in plerisque Scripturae suae sententiis et amicos jubet diligi in se, et inimicos diligi propter se.
chunks.english: The Lord's precepts are both many and one: many through diversity of work, one in the root of love. How the love of God and neighbor is to be held he himself insinuates, who in very many sentences of his Scripture commands both that friends be loved in him and that enemies be loved for his sake.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Old Law and Its Severity
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXXIII] De lege veteri.
chunks.english: Chapter 33: On the old law.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XI, 17, n. 26.) Legis duritia unumquemque peccantem morte corporis puniri sanciebat. Sed postquam Redemptor noster asperitatem legalis sanctionis per mansuetudinem temperavit, non jam pro culpa mortem carnis inferri constituit, sed mors spiritus quantum timenda esset indicavit.
chunks.english: The harshness of the law decreed that each sinner be punished with bodily death. But after our Redeemer tempered the severity of legal sanction through gentleness, he no longer established that death of the flesh be inflicted for fault, but indicated how much the death of the spirit should be feared.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Evang. homil. 33, n. 8.) Scriptum est in Exodo: Manus Moysi erant graves: sumentes igitur lapidem posuerunt subter eum, in quo sedit: Aaron autem et Hur sustentabant manus ejus (Exod. XVII, 12). Moyses igitur sedit in lapide, cum Lex requievit in Ecclesia. Sed haec eadem Lex manus graves habuit, quia peccantes quosque non misericorditer pertulit, sed severa districtione percussit.
chunks.english: It is written in Exodus: The hands of Moses were heavy, so taking a stone they placed it under him, on which he sat, and Aaron and Hur supported his hands, according to the book of Exodus, chapter seventeen, verse twelve. Moses therefore sat on the stone when the Law rested in the Church. But that same Law had heavy hands, because it did not bear any sinners mercifully but struck them with severe strictness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aaron sacerdos mons fortitudinis, Hur autem ignis interpretatur. Quem itaque iste mons fortitudinis signat, nisi Redemptorem nostrum, de quo per prophetam dicitur: Erit in novissimis diebus praeparatus mons domus Domini in vertice montium (Isa. II, 2)? Aut quis per ignem, nisi sanctus Spiritus figuratur, de quo idem Redemptor dicit: Ignem veni mittere in terram (Luc. XII, 49)?
chunks.english: Aaron the priest means mountain of strength, while Hur is interpreted as fire. Whom therefore does this mountain of strength signify except our Redeemer, of whom it is said through the prophet: In the last days the mountain of the Lord's house shall be prepared on the summit of mountains, according to the book of Isaiah, chapter two, verse two? Or who is figured by fire except the Holy Spirit, of whom the same Redeemer says: I came to cast fire upon the earth, according to the Gospel of Luke, chapter twelve, verse forty-nine?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aaron scilicet et Hur graves manus Moysi sustinent, atque sustentando leviores reddunt, quia Mediator Dei et hominum cum igne sancti Spiritus veniens, mandata Legis gravia, quae dum carnaliter tenerentur portari non poterant, tolerabiliora nobis per spiritualem intelligentiam ostendit. Quasi enim manus Moysi leves reddidit, quia pondus mandatorum Legis ad virtutem confessionis retorsit.
chunks.english: Aaron and Hur support the heavy hands of Moses and by supporting make them lighter, because the Mediator of God and men, coming with the fire of the Holy Spirit, showed to us more tolerable through spiritual understanding the grave commandments of the Law, which while they were held carnally could not be borne. For he as it were made the hands of Moses light, because he turned back the weight of the Law's commandments to the virtue of confession.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXXIV] De historia et allegoria.
chunks.english: Chapter 34: On history and allegory.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXI, 1, n. 1.) Intellectus sacri eloquii inter textum et mysterium tanta est libratione pensandus, ut utriusque partis lance moderata, hunc neque nimiae discussionis pondus deprimat, neque rursum torpor incuriae vacuum relinquat. Multae sacri eloquii sententiae tanta allegoriarum conceptione sunt gravidae, ut quisquis eas ad solam tenere historiam nititur, earum notitia per suam incuriam privetur.
chunks.english: The understanding of sacred discourse is to be weighed with such balance between text and mystery that, with the scale of each part moderated, neither the weight of excessive analysis depress it, nor the lethargy of carelessness leave it empty. Many sentences of sacred discourse are so pregnant with conception of allegories that whoever strives to hold them to history alone is deprived of their knowledge through his own carelessness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nonnullae vero ita exterioribus praeceptis inserviunt, ut si quis eas subtilius penetrare desiderat, intus quidem nihil inveniat, sed hoc sibi etiam quod foras loquuntur abscondat. (Num. 2.) Ante considerationis nostrae oculos praecedentium patrum sententiae quasi virgae variae ponuntur. In quibus dum plerumque intellectum litterae fugimus, quasi corticem subtrahimus. Et dum plerumque intellectum litterae sequimur, quasi corticem reservamus.
chunks.english: But some so serve exterior precepts that if anyone desires to penetrate them more subtly, he finds nothing within, but even hides from himself what they speak outwardly. Before the eyes of our consideration the sentences of preceding fathers are placed like various rods. In these, when we often flee the understanding of the letter, we as it were remove the bark. And when we often follow the understanding of the letter, we as it were preserve the bark.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dumque ab ipsis cortex litterae subducitur, allegoriae candor interior demonstratur; et dum cortex relinquitur, exterioris intelligentiae virentia exempla monstrantur. Varias virgas Jacob in aquae canalibus posuit (Gen. XXX, 38): quia Redemptor noster in libris eas sacrae scientiae sententias, quibus nos intrinsecus infundimur, fixit.
chunks.english: And when the bark of the letter is drawn away from them, the inner whiteness of allegory is shown, and when the bark is left, the green examples of exterior understanding are shown. Jacob placed various rods in water channels, according to the book of Genesis, chapter thirty, verse thirty-eight, because our Redeemer fixed in books those sentences of sacred knowledge by which we are inwardly infused.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Has aspicientes arietes cum ovibus coeunt; quia rationales nostri spiritus, dum in earum intentione defixi sunt, in singulis quibusque actionibus permiscentur, ut tales fetus operum procreent qualia exempla praecedentium in vocibus praeceptorum vident, scilicet, ut diversum colorem proles boni operis habeat. Nonnunquam subtracto litterae cortice, acutius mens nostra interna considerat, et reservato nonnunquam historiae tegmine, bene se in exterioribus format.
chunks.english: Looking upon these, rams couple with ewes, because our rational spirits, while fixed in their intention, are mingled in each and every action, so that they may procreate such offspring of works as they see examples of predecessors in the voices of precepts, namely, that the offspring of good work may have diverse color. Sometimes with the bark of the letter removed, our mind considers interior things more acutely, and sometimes with the covering of history preserved, it forms itself well in exterior things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In sacro eloquio intelligentiae magna discretio est. (Ap. Paterium lib. II, c. 29, in Exodum.) Saepe enim in quibusdam locis illius et historia servanda est et allegoria, et saepe in quibusdam sola exquirenda est allegoria, aliquando vero sola necesse est ut teneatur historia.
chunks.english: In sacred discourse there is great discretion of understanding. For often in some places of it both history and allegory must be preserved, and often in some places allegory alone must be sought, but sometimes it is necessary that history alone be held.
chunks.notes: Source citation indicates this is from Paterius, book two, chapter twenty-nine, on Exodus.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In quibusdam locis, sicut diximus, historia simul tenenda est et allegoria, ut et tardiores pascantur per historiam, et velociores ingenio per allegoriam. Unde cum loquente Deo, populus lampades et sonitum buccinae, et montem fumigantem cerneret, perterritus petiit ut eis per Moysem Dominus loqueretur, sicut scriptum est: Stetit populus de longe, Moyses autem accessit ad caliginem in qua erat Deus (Exod., XX, 21).
chunks.english: In some places, as we said, history and allegory must be held simultaneously, so that both the slower may be fed through history and the quicker in wit through allegory. Hence when God was speaking and the people beheld lamps and the sound of trumpet and the smoking mountain, terrified they requested that the Lord speak to them through Moses, as it is written: The people stood afar off, but Moses approached the darkness in which God was, according to the book of Exodus, chapter twenty, verse twenty-one.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Turba populi allegoriarum caliginem non valet penetrare, quia valde paucorum est spiritualem intellectum rimari. Quia enim mentes carnalium sola saepe historia pascuntur, loquente Deo, longe populus stetit. Quia vero spirituales quique allegoriarum nubem penetrant, ut spiritualiter Dei verba cognoscant, Moyses accessit ad caliginem in qua erat Deus.
chunks.english: The crowd of people cannot penetrate the darkness of allegories, because it belongs to very few to probe spiritual understanding. Because the minds of carnal people are often fed by history alone, when God spoke, the people stood afar off. But because any spiritual persons penetrate the cloud of allegories to know God's words spiritually, Moses approached the darkness in which God was.
chunks.notes: Text appears to break off mid-sentence in the source, ending with 'Apud Paterium, lib. V'

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Apud Paterium, lib. V,
chunks.english: According to Paterius, book five
chunks.notes: Fragment at end of manuscript section - incomplete sentence indicating another citation was to follow

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: cap. 9, in Deut.) Lex Veteris Testamenti quasi ova in nidum posuit, cum dixit: Oculum pro oculo, dentem pro dente (Exod. XXI, 24); sed pullos produxit postmodum, cum dixit: Non quaeres ultionem, nec memor eris injuriae civium tuorum (Levit. XIX, 18).
chunks.english: Gregory continues: The Law of the Old Testament placed eggs in the nest, so to speak, when it said in the book of Exodus, chapter twenty-one, verse twenty-four, 'An eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth.' But it brought forth its young later when it said in the book of Leviticus, chapter nineteen, verse eighteen, 'You shall not seek revenge, nor remember the wrongs done by your fellow citizens.'
chunks.notes: Continuing from Paterius book five. Uses nest/eggs metaphor for how the Old Testament gradually developed moral teaching. The later verses in Leviticus represent spiritual maturity of the Law.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Notandum est quod de matre pullorum dicitur: Non tenebis eam cum filiis, sed abire patieris, captos tenens filios (Deut. XXII, 6). Quia videlicet in quibusdam locis praetermittenda est historia, ut solius matris pulli, id est, spiritualis intelligentiae sensus nobis in esum veniat, nec nos mater, sed pulli reficiant; quia non debemus de historiae exemplo, sed de spiritualis intellectus sensibus satiari.
chunks.english: Notice what is said about the mother of the young birds in the book of Deuteronomy, chapter twenty-two, verse six: 'You shall not keep her with her young, but you shall let her go, keeping the captured offspring.' This is because in certain passages we must set aside the historical narrative so that only the young of the mother—that is, the meaning of spiritual understanding—may come to us as food. The young, not the mother, should nourish us, because we ought not to be satisfied by the example of history, but by the insights of spiritual understanding.
chunks.notes: Uses Deuteronomy law about bird nests as allegory for biblical interpretation: sometimes literal history (mother) must be released to grasp spiritual meaning (young birds).

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum legimus aurum et argentum Aegyptiorum ab Israelitico populo petitione deceptoria subreptum (Exod. XII); et rursum cum legimus carnalia sacrificia omnipotenti Deo exhibita: quid in hoc verborum nido, nisi mater dimittenda est et filii tenendi? Nos enim cum a quibusque saecularibus vigilantiam ingenii in defensionem veritatis trahimus, et eorum eloquium in usum rectitudinis vertimus, quid aliud quam ab Aegyptiis aurum et argentum tollimus, ut ex eo et nos divites effici, et illi valeant pauperes ostendi?
chunks.english: When we read in the book of Exodus, chapter twelve, that gold and silver of the Egyptians was taken by the Israelite people through deceptive request, and again when we read of carnal sacrifices offered to almighty God—what else in this nest of words should we do but let the mother go and keep the offspring? For when we draw the alertness of mind from any secular writers to the defense of truth, and turn their eloquence to the service of righteousness, what else are we doing but taking gold and silver from the Egyptians, so that we may be made rich from it while they can be shown poor?
chunks.notes: Applies the bird metaphor to reading Scripture: literal sense (mother) is released, spiritual meaning (young) kept. Exodus story of Israelites taking Egyptian gold becomes allegory for Christians appropriating pagan learning for sacred purposes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut scriptum est: In captivitatem redigentes omnem intellectum in obsequium Christi (II Cor. X, 6). Matrem dimittentes, pullos edimus, cum historiae exempla dimittimus; sed ex ea allegoriarum sensus mente retinemus. Ubi recte additur: Ut bene sit tibi, et longo vivas tempore (Deut. XXII, 8). Quia longo tempore ille vivit qui per spiritualem intelligentiam aeternitatis annos apprehendit.
chunks.english: As it is written in Paul's second letter to the Corinthians, chapter ten, verse six: 'Taking every understanding captive in obedience to Christ.' We let the mother go and eat the young when we set aside historical examples but retain in our minds the allegorical meanings from them. Where it is rightly added in Deuteronomy: 'That it may be well with you, and you may live a long time.' For that person lives a long time who, through spiritual understanding, grasps the years of eternity.
chunks.notes: Concludes bird allegory: allegorical interpretation leads to eternal life, while literal history is temporary.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXXV] De praedestinatione.
chunks.english: Chapter 35: On Predestination
chunks.notes: Major theological chapter on predestination, central doctrine in patristic theology.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Greg., lib. I, Dial., 8.) Ea quae sancti viri orando efficiunt, ita praedestinata sunt ut precibus obtineantur. Nam ipsa quoque perennis regni praedestinatio ita est ab omnipotente Deo disposita, ut ad hoc electi ex labore perveniant, quatenus postulando mereantur accipere quod eis omnipotens Deus ante saecula disposuit donare.
chunks.english: According to Gregory, book one of the Dialogues: Those things which holy men accomplish through prayer are so predestined that they are obtained through prayers. For the predestination of the eternal kingdom itself is so arranged by almighty God that the elect arrive at it through labor, so that by asking they may merit to receive what almighty God arranged before the ages to give them.
chunks.notes: Paradox of predestination and prayer: God's eternal decree is fulfilled through human petition. Introduces Abraham/Isaac example.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Certissime novimus quod ad Abraham Dominus dixit: In Isaac vocabitur tibi semen (Gen. XXI, 13). Cui etiam dixerat: Patrem multarum gentium constitui te (Gen. XVII 4). Cui rursum promisit, dicens: Benedicam tibi, et multiplicabo semen tuum sicut stellas coeli, et velut arenam quae est in littore maris (Gen. XXII, 17).
chunks.english: We know most certainly that the Lord said to Abraham in the book of Genesis, chapter twenty-one, verse thirteen: 'Through Isaac your offspring shall be named.' To him He had also said in chapter seventeen, verse four: 'I have established you as father of many nations.' To him again He promised, saying in chapter twenty-two, verse seventeen: 'I will bless you and multiply your offspring like the stars of heaven and like the sand that is on the seashore.'
chunks.notes: Three Genesis promises to Abraham establishing divine decree to multiply his descendants through Isaac.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex qua re aperte constat quia omnipotens Deus semen Abrahae multiplicare per Isaac praedestinaverat, et tamen scriptum est: Deprecatus est Isaac Dominum pro uxore sua, eo quod esset sterilis; qui exaudivit eum, et dedit conceptum Rebeccae (Gen. XXV, 21). Si multiplicatio generis Abrahae per Isaac praedestinata fuit, cur conjugem sterilem accepit? Sed nimirum constat quia praedestinatio precibus impletur, quando is in quo Deus multiplicare semen Abrahae praedestinaverat, oratione obtinuit ut filios habere potuisset.
chunks.english: From this it is clearly evident that almighty God had predestined to multiply the offspring of Abraham through Isaac. And yet it is written in chapter twenty-five, verse twenty-one: 'Isaac entreated the Lord for his wife, because she was barren. He heard him and gave conception to Rebecca.' If the multiplication of Abraham's race through Isaac was predestined, why did he receive a barren wife? But it is certainly clear that predestination is fulfilled through prayers, since the one through whom God had predestined to multiply Abraham's offspring obtained by prayer that he might have sons.
chunks.notes: Paradox resolved: Isaac's prayer for fertility fulfills rather than contradicts God's eternal decree. Predestination works through human agency, not despite it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. VI Hypognost., c. 2, 5, 6, 7, 8, in append. tom. X Oper. Augustini.) Praedestinatio a praevidendo vel praeordinando futurum aliquid dicitur: et ideo Deus, cui praescientia non accidens est, sed essentia fuit semper, et est, quidquid antequam sit praescit, praedestinat, et propterea praedestinat quia tale erit quale futurum praescit. Ideo et apostolus: Nam quos praescivit, et praedestinavit (Rom. VIII, 29).
chunks.english: From book six of the Hypognostic Questions, included in the appendix of volume ten of Augustine's works: Predestination is so called from foreseeing or foreordaining something future. And therefore God, for whom foreknowledge is not an accident but essence, always has been and is—whatever He foreknows before it exists, He predestines, and He predestines it because it will be such as He foreknows it will be. Therefore the Apostle says in his letter to the Romans, chapter eight, verse twenty-nine: 'For those whom He foreknew, He also predestined.'
chunks.notes: Shifts to Augustinian material (pseudo-Augustinian appendix). Defines predestination as God's foreknowledge, which is identical with His essence.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deus non omne quod praescit praedestinat. Mala enim tantum praescit, bona vero et praescit et praedestinat. Quod ergo bonum est praescientia praedestinat, id est prius quam sit in re praeordinat. Hoc cum ipso auctore esse coeperit, vocat, ordinat et disponit.
chunks.english: God does not predestine everything that He foreknows. For He only foreknows evils, but He both foreknows and predestines good things. Therefore foreknowledge predestines what is good—that is, it preordains it before it exists in reality. When this begins to exist with its very author, He calls it, orders it, and arranges it.
chunks.notes: Critical distinction: God foreknows evil but does not predestine it. He both foreknows AND predestines good. This protects God from being author of evil.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde et sequitur: Nam quos praedestinavit, hos et vocavit; et quos vocavit, illos et justificavit; quos autem justificavit, illos et glorificavit. Justus et misericors Deus, praesciusque futurorum ex damnabili massa, non personarum acceptione, sed judicio aequitatis suae irreprehensibili, imo incomprehensibili, quos praescit misericordia gratuita praeparat, id est, praedestinat ad aeternam vitam, caeteros autem poena debita punit; quos ideo punit quia quid essent futuri praescivit, non tamen puniendos ipse fecit vel praedestinavit, sed tantum in damnabili massa praescivit.
chunks.english: Hence what follows in Romans: 'For those whom He predestined, these He also called; and those whom He called, these He also justified; but those whom He justified, these He also glorified.' God, just and merciful and foreknowing the future, from the damnable mass not by acceptance of persons but by the judgment of His irreproachable—indeed incomprehensible—equity, those whom He foreknows He prepares by gratuitous mercy, that is, He predestines to eternal life. But the rest He punishes with due punishment. He punishes them because He foreknew what they would be, yet He did not make them to be punished or predestine them to punishment, but only foreknew them in the damnable mass.
chunks.notes: 'Damnable mass' (damnabilis massa) refers to fallen humanity after Adam. Key Augustinian theme: from this mass God freely elects some, justly punishes others. Critical point: God foreknows but does not predestine damnation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Diximus] de damnabili humani generis massa Deum praescisse misericordia, non meritis, quos electione gratiae praedestinavit ad vitam: caeteros vero qui judicio justitiae ejus ab hac gratia efficiuntur expertes, praescisse tantum vitio proprio perituros, non ut perirent praedestinasse.
chunks.english: We have said that from the damnable mass of the human race, God foreknew by mercy, not by merits, those whom He predestined to life by the election of grace. But the rest, who by the judgment of His justice are made devoid of this grace, He only foreknew that they would perish by their own fault—He did not predestine them to perish.
chunks.notes: Emphatic restatement: election is by mercy alone, not merit. Non-election is not active divine causation but divine permission of human fault.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deus omnipotens, justus et misericors, quos in operibus impietatis et mortis praescivit, non praeordinavit, nec impulit: in quibus Deum ad iracundiam provocantes, salutis fidem, aut praedicatam sibi accipere nolunt, aut Deo judice non possunt, vel accepta male utuntur, et ob hoc traduntur in reprobum sensum ut non faciant ea quae conveniunt, his poenam praedestinatam esse rite fatemur.
chunks.english: God almighty, just and merciful, those whom He foreknew in works of impiety and death, He did not preordain nor drive to this. These, provoking God to wrath, either refuse to accept the faith of salvation when it is preached to them, or by God's judgment cannot accept it, or having accepted it use it badly. And because of this they are handed over to a reprobate mind so that they do not do what is fitting. For these we rightly confess that punishment is predestined.
chunks.notes: Clarifies divine justice: God does not cause sin, but responds to it. The phrase 'handed over to reprobate mind' echoes Romans chapter one. Predestination applies to punishment as consequence, not sin as cause.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum praescisset Deus Judam in vitiis propriae voluntatis pessimum fore, id est, electionem discipulatus sui bene a Christo conferendam male usurum, et avaritia ardentem pretio Judaeis Dominum traditurum, poenam ei praedestinavit ex merito, dicente per David Spiritu sancto: Deus laudem meam ne taceas, quia os peccatoris et dolosi super me apertum est (Ps. CVIII, 2), id est, Judae, vel Judaeorum in Christum.
chunks.english: Since God foreknew that Judas would be utterly wicked in the vices of his own will—that is, that he would use badly the election to discipleship well conferred by Christ, and burning with avarice would betray the Lord to the Jews for a price—He predestined punishment for him according to merit. As David says by the Holy Spirit in Psalm one hundred eight, verse two: 'O God of my praise, be not silent, for the mouth of the sinner and the deceitful one has been opened against me'—that is, of Judas, or of the Jews against Christ.
chunks.notes: Judas as case study in predestination: God foreknew Judas's evil choice, predestined just punishment, but did not cause the sin itself. Important for theodicy.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Judae, cum dicit: Quid mihi vultis dare, et ego vobis eum tradam (Matth. XXVI, 15)? Et post pecuniae sponsionem, dans signum traditionis: Quemcunque, inquit, osculatus fuero, ipse est, tenete eum. Ideo super me, ait, apertum est. Cum enim signum dedit, ore doloso aperuit quem tenerent. Judaeorum quoque, cum eum volentes dolo perdere, ut Evangelium pandit, clamaverunt dicentes: Crucifige, crucifige eum (Joan. XIX, 6).
chunks.english: The mouth of Judas, when he says in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-six, verse fifteen: 'What will you give me, and I will hand him over to you?' And after the promise of money, giving the sign of betrayal, he says: 'Whomever I kiss, that is the one; seize him.' Therefore it says 'has been opened against me.' For when he gave the sign, with deceitful mouth he revealed whom they should seize. The mouth also of the Jews, when wishing to destroy him by treachery, as the Gospel reveals, they cried out saying in the Gospel of John, chapter nineteen, verse six: 'Crucify, crucify him!'
chunks.notes: Continues Judas example, connecting Old Testament prophecy (Psalm 108) to New Testament betrayal. Both Judas individually and Jews corporately fulfill prophetic word through their own evil choices.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Tenenda est inconcusse haec regula,] omnes peccatores in malis propriis antequam essent in mundo, praescitos esse tantum, non praedestinatos; poenam autem eis esse praedestinatam secundum quod praesciti sunt: parvulos quoque non renatos ex aqua et Spiritu sancto praedestinatae poenae esse obnoxios, qui praesciti sunt non in propriis voluntatibus, quorum nullae sunt bonae vel malae, nisi tantum in Adae peccato quod traxerunt nascentes, et in hoc manentes solverunt tempus vitae praesentis.
chunks.english: This rule must be held unshakably: all sinners in their own evils, before they existed in the world, were only foreknown, not predestined. But punishment is predestined for them according to how they were foreknown. Also, little children not reborn from water and the Holy Spirit are liable to predestined punishment—they who are foreknown not in their own wills, of which they have none either good or evil, but only in Adam's sin which they contracted at birth, and remaining in this they completed the time of their present life.
chunks.notes: Systematic summary of predestination doctrine. Controversial point about unbaptized infants reflects Augustine's view of original sin. 'Water and Holy Spirit' refers to baptism from John chapter three.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Electos qui secundum propositum Dei vivunt, praescitos esse et praedestinatos electione gratuitae gratiae ejus, et regnum eis coelorum esse praedestinatum, sine dubitatione dicendum est. Hoc enim apostolus Paulus probat cum ante eos praedestinatos et electos esse testatur quam mundus constitueretur; scribens Ephesiis, dicit: Sicut elegit nos in ipso, id est, in Christo, ante mundi contitutionem ut essemus sancti et immaculati in conspectu ejus, in charitate, qui praedestinavit nos in adoptionem filiorum per Jesum Christum in ipsum (Ephes. I, 4).
chunks.english: The elect who live according to God's purpose must be said without doubt to be foreknown and predestined by the election of His gratuitous grace, and the kingdom of heaven is predestined for them. For the apostle Paul proves this when he testifies that they were predestined and elected before the world was established. Writing to the Ephesians, he says in chapter one, verse four: 'Just as He chose us in Him'—that is, in Christ—'before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and blameless before Him in love, who predestined us for adoption as sons through Jesus Christ to Himself.'
chunks.notes: Positive side of predestination: election to salvation is entirely by grace, determined before creation. Ephesians text is central proof text.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Taceat humana lingua, ne prorsus in praedestinatione de meritis extollatur. Attende dictum Apostoli: Sicut elegit nos Deus ante mundi constitutionem. Divinae voluntatis est hoc donum, non humanae fragilitatis meritum. Denique attende quid sequitur: In quo habemus, ait, redemptionem per sanguinem ejus, remissionem peccatorum, secundum divitias gratiae ejus, quae superabundavit in nobis in omni sapientia, et prudentia, ut notum faceret nobis sacramentum voluntatis suae, secundum beneplacitum ejus, quod proposuit in eo, in dispensationem plenitudinis temporum restaurare omnia in Christo, quae in coelis et quae in terra sunt in ipso.
chunks.english: Let the human tongue be silent, lest it boast at all about merits in predestination. Pay attention to the Apostle's saying: 'Just as God chose us before the foundation of the world.' This is a gift of divine will, not a merit of human frailty. Finally, pay attention to what follows: 'In Him we have,' he says, 'redemption through His blood, the forgiveness of sins, according to the riches of His grace which He lavished upon us in all wisdom and insight, to make known to us the mystery of His will, according to His good pleasure which He purposed in Him, for the dispensation of the fullness of time, to restore all things in Christ, those in heaven and those on earth in Him.'
chunks.notes: Extended quotation from Ephesians emphasizing salvation is entirely God's work, not human merit. Phrase 'let human tongue be silent' is rhetorical device commanding humility before divine mystery.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In quo etiam sumus praedestinati secundum propositum ejus, qui omnia operatur secundum consilium voluntatis suae, ut simus in laudem gloriae ejus, qui ante speravimus in Christo.
chunks.english: The passage continues: 'In Him we also have been predestined according to His purpose, who works all things according to the counsel of His will, so that we might be to the praise of His glory, we who first hoped in Christ.'
chunks.notes: Conclusion of Ephesians quotation. 'We who first hoped' likely refers to Jewish believers who preceded Gentile believers chronologically.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Praedestinatis apostolis, vel generaliter omnibus electis dicitur: Vigilate, et orate, ne intretis in tentationem (Matth. XXVI, 41). Et iterum: Vigilate in omni tempore orantes, ut digni habeamini fugere ista omnia quae futura sunt, et stare ante Filium hominis (Luc. XXI, 36).
chunks.english: To the predestined apostles, or generally to all the elect, it is said in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-six, verse forty-one: 'Watch and pray, lest you enter into temptation.' And again in the Gospel of Luke, chapter twenty-one, verse thirty-six: 'Watch at all times, praying that you may be counted worthy to escape all these things that are going to happen, and to stand before the Son of Man.'
chunks.notes: Apparent paradox: even the predestined are commanded to watch and pray. This shows predestination does not eliminate human responsibility or effort.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui absque praedestinationis gratia sunt, id est, alieni a proposito Dei, et perdurant in operibus malis, si etiam ex hac migraverint vita, non eos dicimus ita a Deo ordinatos ut perirent, tanquam ipse illis mores malae vitae creaverit, ipse ad opus omne mortis invitos praecipitaverit. Absit hoc a divino proposito. Non enim volens iniquitatem est Deus (Psalm. V, 5): nec mandavit cuiquam impie agere, nec alicui dedit laxamentum peccandi (Eccl. XV, 21). Fecit enim ut essent omnia, et sanabiles nationes orbis terrarum (Sapient. I, 14). Invidia autem diaboli mors introivit in orbem terrarum (Sapient. II, 24). Imitantur ergo illum qui sunt ex parte illius.
chunks.english: Those who are without the grace of predestination—that is, strangers to God's purpose—and who persist in evil works, even if they have departed from this life, we do not say that they were so ordained by God that they should perish, as if He created for them the habits of an evil life, as if He hurled them unwilling into every work of death. Far be this from the divine purpose! For God is not one who wills iniquity, as Psalm five, verse five says. Nor did He command anyone to act impiously, nor did He give to anyone license to sin, as Ecclesiasticus chapter fifteen, verse twenty-one says. For He made all things to exist, and the nations of the world to be healable, as the book of Wisdom chapter one, verse fourteen says. But through the envy of the devil death entered into the world, as chapter two, verse twenty-four says. Therefore those who are on his side imitate him.
chunks.notes: Strong defense of divine goodness. Multiple Scripture citations establish: God does not cause evil, does not command sin, made all things good. Evil enters through devil's envy and human imitation. Important theodicy passage.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Praedestinationem quippe negare immane est blasphemium, quam non tantum in apostolis debemus accipere, sed in patriarchis, et prophetis, et martyribus, et confessoribus, vel in omnibus sanctis et digne servientibus Deo. Nemo glorietur in se nisi in Deo. Nemo desperet. Solus enim Dominus scit qui sunt ejus. (II Tim. II, 19).
chunks.english: Indeed, to deny predestination is a monstrous blasphemy. We ought to recognize it not only in the apostles, but in the patriarchs, prophets, martyrs, confessors, and in all saints worthily serving God. Let no one glory in himself, except in God. Let no one despair. For the Lord alone knows who are His, as Paul's second letter to Timothy, chapter two, verse nineteen says.
chunks.notes: Pastoral conclusion balancing doctrine. Predestination must be affirmed (denying it is blasphemy), but response should be: no pride (glory only in God), no despair (we don't know who is elect). Timothy citation is God's knowledge versus our ignorance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In quantum autem possumus, omnes homines ad bonum opus exhortemur; nulli desperationem demus. Pro invicem oremus, in conspectu Dei nos humiliemur, dicentes: Fiat voluntas tua (Matth. VI, 10). Ipsius erit potestatis judicium in nobis debitum mutare damnationis, et gratiam praedestinationis indebitam praerogare.
chunks.english: But as much as we are able, let us exhort all people to good work. Let us give despair to no one. Let us pray for one another. Let us humble ourselves in God's sight, saying as in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter six, verse ten: 'Your will be done.' It will be in His power to change the judgment of due condemnation in us, and to grant the undue grace of predestination.
chunks.notes: Practical application: universal evangelism, mutual prayer, humility. Final sentence affirms both God's justice (due condemnation) and mercy (undue grace). Ends chapter on hopeful note despite heavy theology.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXXVI] De sapientia.
chunks.english: Chapter 36: On Wisdom
chunks.notes: Shifts from predestination to wisdom, likely continuing Gregorian material.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 6, n. 2.) Sapientia atque scientia doctrinae spiritualis verae sunt divitiae, in quarum comparatione quae transire possunt falsae nominantur. Excepto eo quod ad aeternam patriam divitiae spirituales ducunt, est eis a terrenis divitiis magna distantia, quia spirituales divitiae erogatae proficiunt, terrenae divitiae aut erogantur et deficiunt, aut retinentur et utiles non sunt. Qui ergo has in se veras divitias continent, recte gazophylacia spiritualis aedificii vocantur.
chunks.english: According to Gregory's second book on Ezekiel, homily six: Wisdom and knowledge of spiritual doctrine are true riches, in comparison with which things that can pass away are called false. Apart from the fact that spiritual riches lead to the eternal homeland, there is a great distance between them and earthly riches, because spiritual riches grow when distributed, while earthly riches either are distributed and decrease, or are retained and are not useful. Therefore those who contain these true riches in themselves are rightly called treasuries of the spiritual building.
chunks.notes: Contrast between spiritual and earthly riches. Paradox: spiritual wealth increases when given away, material wealth either diminishes (when spent) or becomes useless (when hoarded). Treasury metaphor for holy people.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. V, c. 5, n. 8.) Sapientia in rerum superficie non jacet, lucet quia in invisibilibus latet. Et tunc mortificatione nostra sapientiam contingentes apprehendimus, si, relictis visibilibus, in invisibilibus abscondamur. Quasi cor effodientes sapientiam quaerimus, ut omne quod terrenum mens cogitat a semetipsa manu sanctae discretionis abjiciat, et thesaurum virtutis qui se latebat agnoscat. Facile quisque thesaurum sapientiae invenit, si eam quae se male presserat molem a se terrenae cogitationis repellit.
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book five: Wisdom does not lie on the surface of things—it shines because it is hidden in invisible things. And then we grasp wisdom by touching it through our mortification, if, having abandoned visible things, we hide ourselves in invisible things. We seek wisdom as if digging up a heart, so that the mind may cast away from itself by the hand of holy discernment everything earthly that it thinks, and may recognize the treasure of virtue that was hiding. Anyone easily finds the treasure of wisdom if he repels from himself the mass of earthly thought that had badly oppressed him.
chunks.notes: Wisdom requires: turning from visible to invisible, mortification (death to worldly things), active excavation (digging metaphor), discernment to remove earthly thoughts. Hidden treasure metaphor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXV, 12, n. 29.) Scriptum est: Sapientia in capite viarum clamitat. In mediis semitis stat (Prov. VIII, 1). Transire fortasse per viam vitae temporalis cum ejus ignorantia poteramus, si aec eadem sapientia in semitae angulis constitisset. (Num. 30.) Investiganda fuerat, si occulta esse voluisset.
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book twenty-five: It is written in the book of Proverbs, chapter eight, verse one: 'Wisdom cries aloud at the head of the roads. She stands in the middle of the paths.' Perhaps we could have passed through the path of temporal life in ignorance of it, if this same wisdom had stationed herself in the corners of the path. She would have had to be sought out, if she had wished to be hidden.
chunks.notes: Proverbs personified Wisdom calls publicly in open places, not hidden corners. Point: divine wisdom is accessible, calls openly to all who will listen. No excuse for ignorance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Salomon prudentissimus ait: Sapientia aedificavit sibi domum, excidit columnas septem, immolavit victimas, miscuit vinum, proposuit mensam, misit ancillas suas, ut vocarent ad arcem et moenia civitatis (Prov. IX, 1, 2, 3), et reliqua.
chunks.english: The most prudent Solomon says in the book of Proverbs, chapter nine, verses one through three: 'Wisdom has built her house, she has hewn out her seven pillars, she has slaughtered her beasts, she has mixed her wine, she has also set her table, she has sent out her maidservants to call from the highest places of the city,' and so on.
chunks.notes: Extended Proverbs passage about Wisdom preparing a feast. Will be allegorized in next chunks as Church, incarnation, martyrs, Scripture, apostles.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral. XXXIII, 16, n. 32.] Sapientia domum sibi condidit cum unigenitus Dei Filius in semetipso intra uterum Virginis, mediante anima, humanum sibi corpus creavit. Unigeniti corpus domus Dei dicitur, sicut etiam templum vocatur: ita vero ut unus idemque Dei atque hominis Filius ipse sit qui inhabitat, ipse qui inhabitatur.
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book thirty-three: Wisdom built a house for herself when the only-begotten Son of God within the womb of the Virgin, with the soul as intermediary, created a human body for Himself. The body of the Only-begotten is called the house of God, just as it is also called a temple—in such a way, however, that one and the same Son of God and man is both He who dwells and He who is dwelt in.
chunks.notes: First allegorical interpretation: Wisdom's house is Christ's human body formed in Mary's womb. 'With soul as intermediary' reflects theology that Christ has both human body and human soul. Same person both indwells (divine) and is indwelt (human).

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Domus sapientiae Ecclesia vocatur quae quasi septem sibi columnas excidit, quia ab amore vitae praesentis saeculi disjunctas ad portandam ejusdem Ecclesiae fabricam mentes praedicantium erexit. Quae pro eo quod perfectionis virtute subnixae sunt, septenario numero designantur.
chunks.english: The house of wisdom is called the Church, which has hewn out seven pillars for herself, as it were, because she raised up the minds of preachers, disconnected from love of the present worldly life, to carry the structure of this same Church. These are designated by the number seven because they are supported by the virtue of perfection.
chunks.notes: Second interpretation: house is Church, seven pillars are preachers/apostles. Seven represents perfection/completeness (echoing seven gifts of Holy Spirit, seven days of creation). Pillars must be 'disconnected' from worldly love to support Church.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sapientia immolavit victimas, quia vitam praedicantium mactari in persecutione permisit. Vinum miscuit, quia divinitatis et humanitatis suae pariter nobis arcana praedicavit. Mensam quoque proposuit, quia Scripturae sacrae nobis pabula aperiendo praeparavit.
chunks.english: Wisdom slaughtered her beasts, because she permitted the life of preachers to be slain in persecution. She mixed wine, because she preached to us together the mysteries of both her divinity and her humanity. She also set a table, because by opening up the sacred Scriptures she prepared nourishment for us.
chunks.notes: Three more elements allegorized: slaughtered beasts = martyred apostles, mixed wine = union of divine and human natures in Christ, table = Scripture. Wine 'mixed' captures hypostatic union (two natures, one person).

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XVII, 32, n. 43.) Posuit mensam Dei sapientia, id est, Scripturam sacram, quae fessos ad se atque a saeculi oneribus venientes pane verbi reficit, et contra adversarios sua refectione nos roborat. Unde alias ab Ecclesia dicitur: Posuisti in conspectu meo mensam adversus eos qui tribulant me (Ps. XXII, 5).
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book seventeen: The wisdom of God has set a table—that is, sacred Scripture—which refreshes with the bread of the word those who come to it weary and burdened by worldly troubles, and strengthens us by its refreshment against adversaries. Whence elsewhere it is said by the Church in Psalm twenty-two, verse five: 'You have prepared a table before me in the presence of those who trouble me.'
chunks.notes: Scripture as nourishing table. Dual function: refreshes the weary, strengthens against enemies. Psalm 22 (23 in modern numbering) 'table before enemies' is spiritual warfare imagery.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Misit ancillas suas, apostolorum videlicet animas, in ipso suo initio infirmas, ut vocarent ad arcem et moenia civitatis; quia dum internam vitam denuntiant, ad alta nos moenia supernae civitatis levant, quae profecto moenia nisi humiles non ascendunt.
chunks.english: She sent out her maidservants—namely the souls of the apostles, weak in their very beginning—to call to the citadel and walls of the city. For while they proclaim the interior life, they lift us to the high walls of the heavenly city—walls which certainly none but the humble ascend.
chunks.notes: Maidservants = apostles, initially weak (before Pentecost?). They call people to heavenly Jerusalem. Paradox: must be humble to ascend high walls. Connects to earlier theme that God uses weak instruments.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXXIII, 16, n. 32.) Ancillas suas haec Dei sapientia misit, quae ad arcem nos atque ad civitatis moenia vocarent; quia praedicatores infirmos abjectosque habere studuit, qui fideles populos ad spiritualis patriae aedificia superna colligerent.
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book thirty-three: This wisdom of God sent out her maidservants who would call us to the citadel and walls of the city, because she was eager to have weak and lowly preachers who would gather faithful peoples to the heavenly buildings of the spiritual homeland.
chunks.notes: Reiterates divine strategy of using weak preachers. Echoes 1 Corinthians: 'God chose the weak things of the world.' Faithful peoples gathered upward to 'spiritual homeland' (heaven).

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XVII, 29, n. 43.) Ab eadem Sapientia subditur: Si quis est parvulus veniat ad me (Prov. IX, 4). Ac si aperte dicat: Quisquis se apud se magnum aestimat, aditum sibi mei accessus angustat; quia tanto ad me altius pertingitur, quanto uniuscujusque mens apud se verius humiliatur.
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book seventeen: By this same Wisdom it is added in Proverbs chapter nine, verse four: 'If anyone is simple, let him come to me.' As if she were saying openly: Whoever considers himself great narrows for himself the approach of access to me, because one reaches up to me more loftily the more truly each person's mind humbles itself.
chunks.notes: Proverbs invitation to 'simple ones.' Paradox: considering oneself great blocks access; humility enables ascent. Recurring theme: humility is precondition for divine wisdom.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XI, 6, n. 8.) Intuendum valde est quia cum una sit sapientia, alium minus, alium magis inhabitat: alii hoc, alii aliud praestat, et quasi cerebri more, nobismetipsis, velut quibusdam sensibus, utitur; ut quamvis ipsa sibimet nunquam sit dissimilis, per nos tamen diversa et dissimilia semper operetur, quatenus iste sapientiae, ille scientiae donum percipiat, iste genera linguarum, ille gratiam curationum habeat.
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book eleven: It must be carefully observed that although wisdom is one, it dwells in one person less and in another more. It grants one thing to some, another to others, and uses us like various senses, in the manner of a brain. So that although it is never unlike itself, through us it always works diverse and different things—so that this person may receive the gift of wisdom, that one the gift of knowledge, this one varieties of tongues, that one the grace of healings.
chunks.notes: Unity and diversity of wisdom. Brain/senses metaphor: one wisdom operates through many people with different gifts. Lists charismatic gifts from 1 Corinthians 12. God's unity expressed through human diversity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 7.) Verba sapientiae, quae reprobi audiunt, electi non solum audiunt, sed etiam gustant; ut eis in corde sapiat quod reproborum non mentibus, sed solummodo auribus sonat. Aliud est nominatum cibem audire solummodo, aliud vero etiam gustare. Electi itaque cibum sapientiae sic audiunt ut degustent, quia hoc quod audiunt eis per amorem medullitus sapit. Reproborum scientia usque ad cognitionem sonitus tenditur, ut equidem virtutes audiant, sed tamen corde frigido qualiter sapiant, ignorent.
chunks.english: From the same section: The words of wisdom, which the reprobate hear, the elect not only hear but also taste, so that what merely sounds in the ears of the reprobate, not in their minds, may have flavor in the heart of the elect. It is one thing merely to hear the name of food, another truly also to taste it. The elect therefore hear the food of wisdom in such a way that they taste it, because what they hear has flavor for them deeply through love. The knowledge of the reprobate extends only to recognition of sound, so that indeed they hear about virtues, but with cold heart they do not know how they taste.
chunks.notes: Hearing versus tasting wisdom. Reprobate: external/auditory only. Elect: internal/experiential through love. Food metaphor: knowing about food versus actually tasting it. 'Cold heart' contrasts with love that enables true tasting.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Cap. 7, n. 10.) Illa enim dicta in sapientiae radice solidata sunt, quae per vivendi usum etiam actuum experimento convalescunt. Quia multis et longior vita tribuitur, et sapientiae gratia non confertur. Recte per beatum Job dicitur: Apud ipsum est sapientia, et fortitudo: ipse habet consilium, et intelligentiam (Job. XII, 13).
chunks.english: From the same chapter: For those sayings are solidly rooted in wisdom which grow strong through the practice of living and even through the experience of actions. Because to many both longer life is granted and yet the grace of wisdom is not conferred. Rightly it is said through blessed Job in chapter twelve, verse thirteen: 'With Him are wisdom and might; He has counsel and understanding.'
chunks.notes: Wisdom requires not just hearing but practice and lived experience. Age alone does not bring wisdom. Job text begins Christological interpretation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Cap, 8, n. 11.] Haec non incongrue de Unigenito summi Patris accipimus, ut ipsum esse Dei sapientiam et fortitudinem sentiamus. Nam Paulus quoque nostro intellectui attestatur, dicens: Christum Dei virtutem et Dei sapientiam (I Cor. XXIV); qui apud ipsum semper est, quia in principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum (Joan. I, 1).
chunks.english: From chapter eight: We not inappropriately understand these things about the Only-begotten of the supreme Father, so that we may recognize that He Himself is the wisdom and strength of God. For Paul also testifies to our understanding, saying in Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter one, verse twenty-four: 'Christ the power of God and the wisdom of God'—who is always with Him, because as the Gospel of John chapter one, verse one says: 'In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.'
chunks.notes: Job's 'wisdom and might with Him' interpreted as Christ. Paul's 1 Cor text identifies Christ as God's wisdom and power. John prologue confirms eternal coexistence of Word with God. Moves from abstract wisdom to personal Wisdom (Christ).

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Habet Deus consilium et intelligentiam: consilium videlicet, quia disponit sua; intelligentiam, quia cognoscit nostra.
chunks.english: God has counsel and understanding: counsel, namely, because He arranges His own things; understanding, because He knows our things.
chunks.notes: Distinguishes divine counsel (God's sovereign plan) from divine understanding (God's knowledge of creatures). Completes Job interpretation with divine omniscience.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: How God is Seen by Holy People in This World
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXXVII] Qualiter a sanctis viris in hoc saeculo videatur Deus.
chunks.english: Chapter 37: How God is Seen by Holy People in This World
chunks.notes: Major mystical theology chapter on contemplation and vision of God in earthly life.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XVIII, 54, n. 88.) Beatus Moyses, qui cum Deo facie ad faciem locutus est, sicut loqui solet homo cum amico suo, ei inter ipsa verba suae locutionis dixit: Si inveni gratiam in conspectu tuo, ostende mihi temetipsum manifeste, ut videam te (Exod. XXXIII, 13). Certe si Deus non erat cum quo loquebatur, Ostende mihi Deum, diceret, et non Ostende temetipsum. Si autem Deus erat cum quo facie ad faciem loquebatur, cur se petebat videre quem videbat?
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book eighteen: Blessed Moses, who spoke with God face to face as a man is accustomed to speak with his friend, said to Him amid the very words of his conversation, as in the book of Exodus chapter thirty-three, verse thirteen: 'If I have found favor in your sight, show me yourself clearly, that I may see you.' Certainly if it was not God with whom he was speaking, he would have said 'Show me God,' and not 'Show me yourself.' But if it was God with whom he was speaking face to face, why did he ask to see Him whom he was seeing?
chunks.notes: Moses paradox: speaks with God 'face to face' yet asks to see God. Sets up distinction between mediated vision (through images/theophanies) and direct vision of divine essence.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed ex hac ejus petitione colligitur quia eum sitiebat per incircumscriptae naturae suae claritatem cernere quem jam coeperat per quasdam imagines videre; ut sic superna essentia mentis ejus oculis adesset, quatenus ei ad aeternitatis visionem nulla imago creata temporaliter interesset.
chunks.english: But from this petition of his it is gathered that he thirsted to perceive through the clarity of His uncircumscribed nature the One whom he had already begun to see through certain images—so that the supreme essence might be present to the eyes of his mind in such a way that no created image would temporally stand between him and the vision of eternity.
chunks.notes: Moses desired unmediated vision of God's 'uncircumscribed nature' (infinite divine essence) without created intermediaries. Distinction: vision through images vs. direct vision of essence. Foreshadows beatific vision theology.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Viderunt Patres Veteris Testamenti Deum, et tamen, juxta Joannis vocem, Deum nemo vidit unquam (Joan. IV, 12); et, juxta beati Job sententiam, Sapientia, quae Deus est, abscondita est ab oculis omnium viventium (Job, XXVIII, 21); quia in hac mortali carne consistentibus, et videri potuit per quasdam circumscriptas imagines, et videri non potuit per incircumscriptum lumen aeternitatis.
chunks.english: The Fathers of the Old Testament saw God, and yet, according to John's voice in the Gospel of John chapter one, verse twelve, 'No one has ever seen God.' And according to blessed Job's sentence in chapter twenty-eight, verse twenty-one, 'Wisdom, which is God, is hidden from the eyes of all living.' Because for those remaining in this mortal flesh, He both could be seen through certain circumscribed images, and could not be seen through the uncircumscribed light of eternity.
chunks.notes: Resolves biblical tension: patriarchs saw God (Genesis accounts) yet 'no one has seen God' (John). Solution: they saw through created images/theophanies, not divine essence directly. 'Circumscribed images' vs. 'uncircumscribed light' is key distinction.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 89.) Aeterna Dei claritas, si a quibusdam potest in hac adhuc corruptibili carne viventibus, sed tamen inaestimabili virtute crescentibus, quodam contemplationis acumine videri, hoc quoque ab ejusdem Veritatis sententia non abhorret, qua dicitur: Non enim videbit me homo, et vivet (Exod. XXXIII, 21); quoniam quisquis sapientiam, quae Deus est, videt, huic vitae funditus moritur, ne jam ejus amore teneatur.
chunks.english: From the same section: If the eternal clarity of God can be seen by certain people still living in this corruptible flesh, but nevertheless growing in immeasurable virtue, by a certain sharpness of contemplation, this also does not contradict the sentence of that same Truth by which it is said in Exodus chapter thirty-three, verse twenty-one: 'For man shall not see me and live.' Because whoever sees wisdom, which is God, dies utterly to this life, so that he may no longer be held by love of it.
chunks.notes: Mystical interpretation of 'no one sees God and lives': seeing God means dying to worldly life/attachments. Opens possibility of contemplative vision even in mortal flesh for those growing in virtue. Death is spiritual, not physical.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nullus Deum vidit, qui adhuc carnaliter vivit, quia nemo potest amplecti Deum simul et saeculum. Qui enim Deum videt, eo ipso moritur quo vel intentione cordis, vel effectu operis ab hujus vitae delectationibus tota mente separetur.
chunks.english: No one has seen God who still lives carnally, because no one can embrace both God and the world at once. For whoever sees God dies by that very fact by which he is separated with his whole mind from the delights of this life, either by intention of heart or by effect of work.
chunks.notes: Cannot serve two masters: seeing God requires total separation from worldly pleasures. This separation ('dying') can be by inner intention or outward action. Mystical death precedes mystical vision.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXXV, 8, n. 13.) Ex sola catholica Ecclesia veritas conspicitur, dum Moysi apud se esse locum Dominus perhibet de quo videatur. Unde et in petra Moyses ponitur, ut Dei speciem contempletur; quia nisi quis fidei soliditatem tenuerit, divinam praesentiam non agnoscit. De qua soliditate Dominus dicit: Super hanc petram aedificabo Ecclesiam meam (Matth. XVI, 18).
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book thirty-five: Truth is perceived only from the catholic Church, since the Lord testified to Moses that there is a place with Him from which He may be seen. And therefore Moses is placed upon the rock so that he may contemplate the form of God, because unless someone has held the solidity of faith, he does not recognize the divine presence. Concerning this solidity the Lord says in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter sixteen, verse eighteen: 'Upon this rock I will build my Church.'
chunks.notes: Ecclesiological point: true vision of God requires standing on rock of Catholic faith. Moses on rock seeing God = believer in Church seeing divine truth. Matthew 16 rock = Peter/faith foundation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dum ipsa per se Veritas dicit: Nemo vidit faciem meam unquam, quomodo Jacob testatur: Vidi Dominum facie ad faciem (Gen. XXXII, 30)?
chunks.english: While Truth itself says 'No one has ever seen my face,' how does Jacob testify in the book of Genesis chapter thirty-two, verse thirty: 'I have seen the Lord face to face'?
chunks.notes: Another biblical paradox: John's 'no one has seen God' versus Jacob's 'I saw God face to face' (at Peniel after wrestling angel). Will resolve in next section.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral. XXIV, 6, n. 11.] Humanae etenim mentis oculo interiori purgato, dum vitiorum omnium tribulationis igne aerugo fuerit concremata, tunc mundatis oculis cordis, illa laetitia patriae coelestis aperitur, ut prius purgemus lugendo quod fecimus et postmodum manifestius contemplemur per gaudia quod quaeramus.
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book twenty-four: For when the interior eye of the human mind has been purified, when the rust of all vices has been burned away by the fire of tribulation, then with the eyes of the heart cleansed, that joy of the heavenly homeland is opened—so that we first purge by mourning what we have done, and afterward contemplate more clearly through joys what we seek.
chunks.notes: Purgative-illuminative progression: tribulation burns away vice (purgation), then heavenly joy opens (illumination/contemplation). Mourning for sin precedes joyful vision. Classic mystical progression.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Prius ab acie mentis exurente tristitia interposita malorum caligo detergitur, et tunc splendente raptim coruscatione incircumscripti luminis illustratur. Quo utcunque conspecto, in gaudio cujusdam securitatis absorbetur, et quasi post defectum vitae praesentis ultra se rapta, aliquo modo in quadam novitate recreatur.
chunks.english: First the intervening darkness of evils is wiped away from the sharp edge of the mind by burning sorrow, and then it is illuminated by the suddenly shining flash of uncircumscribed light. When this is somehow glimpsed, the mind is absorbed in the joy of a certain security, and as if after the failure of present life, carried beyond itself, it is in some way recreated in a certain newness.
chunks.notes: Mystical experience described phenomenologically: darkness burned away, sudden flash of infinite light, absorption in joyful security, being carried beyond oneself (ecstasy), recreation/renewal. 'Uncircumscribed light' = divine infinity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ibi mens ex immenso fonte infusione superni roris aspergitur, ibi non se sufficere ad id quod rapta est contemplatur, et veritatem sentiendo videt, quia quanta est ipsa veritas non videt. Summae et incircumscriptae veritati tanto magis se quisque longe existimat, quanto magis appropinquat; quia nisi illam utcunque conspiceret, nequaquam eam conspicere se non posse sentiret.
