chunks.english: There the mind is sprinkled from the immense fountain by the infusion of heavenly dew. There it contemplates that it is not sufficient for that to which it has been caught up, and by experiencing truth it sees, yet it does not see how great that truth itself is. To the supreme and uncircumscribed truth, the more anyone approaches, the more he considers himself far away—because unless he glimpsed it somehow, he would in no way feel that he cannot fully see it.
chunks.notes: Paradoxes of mystical knowledge: seeing truth by experiencing it, yet not seeing its full magnitude; the closer one approaches infinite Truth, the more one realizes one's distance; awareness of inability to see fully proves partial vision. Apophatic theology: knowing by unknowing.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 12.) Adnisus animi, dum in visionem Dei tenditur, immensitatis ejus coruscante circumstantia reverberatur. Ipsa quippe, cuncta implens, cuncta circumstat; et idcirco mens nostra nequaquam se ad comprehendendam incircumscriptam circumstantiam dilatat, quia eam inopia suae circumscriptionis angustat.
chunks.english: From the same section: The striving of the soul, when it stretches toward the vision of God, is beaten back by the flashing surrounding of His immensity. For this immensity, filling all things, surrounds all things. And therefore our mind in no way expands itself to comprehend the uncircumscribed surrounding, because the poverty of its own circumscription constrains it.
chunks.notes: Spatial metaphor for encountering divine infinity: mind reaches toward God, is overwhelmed by divine immensity that both fills and surrounds everything. Finite mind cannot expand to comprehend infinite being. Human 'circumscription' (limitedness) versus divine 'uncircumscription' (limitlessness).

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde et ad semetipsam citius labitur, et prospectis quasi quibusdam veritatis vestigiis, ad se anima revocatur. Per contemplationem facta non solida et permanens summae veritatis visio, sed, ut ita dixerim, quasi quaedam visionis imitatio, Dei facies dicitur.
chunks.english: Whence it quickly falls back to itself, and having glimpsed as it were certain footprints of truth, the soul is recalled to itself. The vision of supreme truth made through contemplation, not solid and permanent, but, so to speak, a certain imitation of vision, is called the face of God.
chunks.notes: Contemplative experience is temporary, not permanent. Soul glimpses 'footprints' (vestigia) of truth, then falls back to itself. This imperfect, transient vision is what Scripture calls seeing God's 'face'—not full beatific vision, but anticipatory imitation. Explains Moses and Jacob's experiences.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia enim per faciem quemlibet agnoscimus, non immerito cognitionem Dei faciem vocamus. Beatus Jacob, postquam cum angelo luctatus est, ait: Vidi Dominum facie ad faciem (Gen. XXXII, 30), ac si diceret: Cognovi Deum, quia me cognoscere ipse dignatus est. Quam cognitionem plenissime fieri Paulus in fine testatur, dicens: Tunc cognoscam sicut et cognitus sum (I Cor. XIII, 12).
chunks.english: For since we recognize anyone by their face, we not undeservedly call knowledge of God 'face.' Blessed Jacob, after he wrestled with the angel, said in Genesis chapter thirty-two, verse thirty: 'I have seen the Lord face to face,' as if he were saying: 'I have known God, because He Himself deigned to make Himself known to me.' Paul testifies that this knowledge will be made most fully complete at the end, saying in his first letter to the Corinthians chapter thirteen, verse twelve: 'Then I shall know even as I am known.'
chunks.notes: Resolves Jacob paradox: 'face to face' means mutual knowledge, not visual perception of essence. Jacob knew God because God revealed Himself to Jacob. Paul's 'know as known' refers to eschatological perfection of knowledge in beatific vision. Distinction: earthly knowledge (mutual but partial) vs. heavenly knowledge (full reciprocity).

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ad Timotheum Paulus scripsit dicens: Quem vidit nullus hominum, sed nec videre potest (I Tim. VI, 16). [Moral. XVIII, 54, n. 92.] More suo homines vocans omnes humana sapientes, quia qui divina sapiunt videlicet supra homines sunt. Videbimus igitur Deum, si per coelestem conversationem supra homines esse mereamur.
chunks.english: Paul wrote to Timothy, saying in his first letter chapter six, verse sixteen: 'Whom no man has seen, nor can see.' From the Moralia, book eighteen: According to his custom calling 'men' all those who are wise in human things, because those who are wise in divine things are evidently above men. We will therefore see God if through heavenly conduct we merit to be above men.
chunks.notes: Resolves 'no one can see God': Paul means those living according to human wisdom only. Those who attain divine wisdom transcend merely 'human' status. Seeing God requires becoming 'more than human' through divine grace and heavenly way of life.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec tamen ita videbimus, sicut videt ipse seipsum. Longe quippe dispariliter videt Creator se quam videt creatura Creatorem. Quantum pertinet ad immensitatem Dei, quidam nobis modus figitur contemplationis, quia eo ipso pondere circumscribimur quo creatura sumus.
chunks.english: Yet we will not see in the same way that He sees Himself. For the Creator sees Himself in a far different manner than the creature sees the Creator. As regards the immensity of God, a certain measure of contemplation is fixed for us, because we are circumscribed by that very weight by which we are creatures.
chunks.notes: Even in beatific vision, asymmetry remains: God's self-knowledge infinite and comprehensive, creature's knowledge of God finite and limited. Creaturehood itself ('weight of being creature') is permanent limitation even in glory. No pantheistic absorption: creature remains creature even in highest vision.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 93.) Sed profecto non ita conspicimus Deum sicut ipse conspicit se, sicut non ita requiescimus in Deo quemadmodum ipse requiescit in se. Nam visio nostra vel requies erit utcunque similis visioni vel requiei illius, sed aequalis non erit.
chunks.english: From the same section: But certainly we do not perceive God in the same way that He perceives Himself, just as we do not rest in God in the same way that He rests in Himself. For our vision or rest will be somehow similar to His vision or rest, but it will not be equal.
chunks.notes: Reiteration with addition of 'rest' theme. Beatific vision brings similitude (likeness) to divine vision, but not equality. Creatures remain creatures; eternal distinction preserved even in glory. Both vision and rest share this quality: similar, not equal.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ne torpore negligentiae jaceamus in nobis, contemplationis penna nos sublevat, atque a nobis ad Deum erigimur intuendum. Raptique intentione cordis et dulcedine contemplationis, aliquo modo a nobis imus in ipsum; et jam hoc ipsum ire nostrum minus est requiescere, quoniam sic ire, perfecte quiescere est.
chunks.english: Lest we lie in ourselves in the torpor of negligence, the wing of contemplation lifts us up, and we are raised from ourselves to gaze upon God. Caught up by the intention of heart and the sweetness of contemplation, we go in some way from ourselves into Him. And now this very going of ours is less than resting, since to go thus is to rest perfectly.
chunks.notes: Flight metaphor: contemplation as wing lifting from self to God. Movement toward God is simultaneously rest (paradox). Human contemplation involves journey/ascent ('going'), unlike divine rest which is perfect and motionless. Going-that-is-resting describes contemplative ascent.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Perfecta requies est qua Deus cernitur; et tamen nostra requies aequanda non est requiei illius, quia non a se in aliam transit ut requiescat. Est itaque requies, ut ita dicam, similis atque dissimilis; quia quod illius quiescere est, hoc nostra requies imitatur.
chunks.english: Perfect rest is that by which God is perceived. And yet our rest is not to be equated with His rest, because He does not pass from Himself into another in order to rest. Therefore there is rest, so to speak, both similar and dissimilar—because what His resting is, our rest imitates.
chunks.notes: Divine rest: self-contained, no movement from self to other. Human rest: requires movement from self toward God. Similar: both are rest. Dissimilar: God rests in self, we rest by going beyond self to God. Imitatio Dei with permanent ontological distinction.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Visio Dei nunc fide inchoatur, sed tunc in specie perficitur, quando coaeternam Deo sapientiam, quam modo per ora praedicantium quasi per decurrentia flumina sumimus, in ipso suo fonte biberimus.
chunks.english: The vision of God is now begun by faith, but then it is perfected in direct sight, when we shall drink the wisdom coeternal with God—which now we receive through the mouths of preachers as through flowing streams—in its very fountain.
chunks.notes: Now/then eschatology: faith (present) versus sight (future). River metaphor: currently receive wisdom through intermediaries (preachers = streams), then will drink directly from source (fountain = God Himself). Wisdom is 'coeternal with God' = Christ the eternal Logos. Movement from mediated to immediate knowledge.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Ways God Speaks to Human Beings
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXXVIII] Quibus modis Deus loquitur hominibus.
chunks.english: Chapter 38: The Ways God Speaks to Human Beings
chunks.notes: Systematic chapter categorizing modes of divine communication. Will distinguish God speaking directly vs. through angels, various forms of angelic mediation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXVIII, 1, n. 2.) Sciendum summopere est quia duobus modis locutio divina distinguitur, cum aut per semetipsum Dominus loquitur, aut per creaturam angelicam ejus ad nos verba formantur.
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book twenty-eight: It must be known above all that divine speech is distinguished in two ways: either the Lord speaks through Himself, or His words are formed to us through angelic creatures.
chunks.notes: Binary division: immediate (God directly) vs. mediated (through angels). Will subdivide angelic mediation into many subcategories.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum per semetipsum Dominus loquitur, sola nobis vis internae inspirationis aperitur. Cum per semetipsum loquitur, de verbo ejus sine verbis ac syllabis cor docetur; quia virtus ejus in intima quadam sublevatione cognoscitur, ad quam mens plena suspenditur, vacua gravatur.
chunks.english: When the Lord speaks through Himself, only the force of interior inspiration is opened to us. When He speaks through Himself, the heart is taught from His word without words and syllables, because His power is known in a certain intimate elevation, toward which the full mind is suspended, the empty mind is weighed down.
chunks.notes: Direct divine speech: wordless inspiration, teaching without language, known in 'intimate elevation.' Paradox: full mind lifted up, empty mind pressed down (perhaps: those full of grace rise, those empty of grace cannot receive).

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pondus enim quoddam est vis divinae locutionis, quod omnem animam quam replet levet. Incorporeum lumen est, quod et interiora repleat, et repleta exterius circumscribat. Sine strepitu sermo est, qui et auditum aperit, et habere sonitum nescit.
chunks.english: For the force of divine speech is a certain weight that lifts every soul which it fills. It is an incorporeal light that both fills interiors and, having filled them, circumscribes them outwardly. It is speech without sound, which both opens the hearing and knows not how to have sound.
chunks.notes: Three paradoxical descriptions of immediate divine speech: (1) weight that lifts, (2) light that fills within and bounds without, (3) soundless speech that opens hearing. Captures ineffable, paradoxical nature of direct divine communication.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De adventu sancti Spiritus scriptum est: Factus est de coelo repente sonus tanquam advenientis spiritus vehementis, et replevit totam domum, ubi erant sedentes: et apparuerunt illis dispertitae linguae tanquam ignis, seditque super singulos eorum (Act. II, 2). Per ignem quidem Dominus apparuit, sed per semetipsum locutionem interius fecit. Et neque ignis Deus, neque ille sonitus fuit; sed per hoc quod exterius exhibuit, expressit hoc quod interius gessit.
chunks.english: Concerning the coming of the Holy Spirit it is written in the Acts of the Apostles, chapter two, verse two: 'Suddenly there came from heaven a sound like a rushing mighty wind, and it filled the whole house where they were sitting. And there appeared to them divided tongues as of fire, and it sat upon each of them.' Through fire indeed the Lord appeared, but He made speech inwardly through Himself. And neither was God the fire, nor was He that sound, but through what He displayed outwardly, He expressed what He accomplished inwardly.
chunks.notes: Pentecost as example: external signs (wind sound, fire tongues) were not God Himself but expressed inner divine action. Outer manifestation signifies but is distinct from inner reality. God Himself spoke within, while elemental signs testified without.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sanctus Spiritus, qui discipulos et zelo succensos et verbo eruditos intus reddidit, foras linguas igneas ostendit. In significatione igitur admota sunt elementa, ut ignem et sonitum sentirent corpora, igne vero invisibili et voce sine sonitu docerentur corda: foras ergo fuit ignis qui apparuit, sed intus qui scientiam dedit.
chunks.english: The Holy Spirit, who inwardly made the disciples both inflamed with zeal and instructed in word, outwardly showed fiery tongues. Therefore the elements were brought forward for signification, so that bodies might sense fire and sound, but hearts were taught by invisible fire and voice without sound. So the fire that appeared was outside, but the one who gave knowledge was inside.
chunks.notes: Inside/outside distinction at Pentecost: visible fire = external sign for bodies, invisible fire = interior knowledge for hearts. External elements signify internal spiritual reality. True teaching happened within, signs confirmed without.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dei locutio ad nos intrinsecus facta videtur potius quam auditur, quia dum semetipsam sine mora sermonis insinuat, repentina luce nostrae ignorantiae tenebras illustrat.
chunks.english: God's speech made to us inwardly is seen rather than heard, because when it insinuates itself without delay of words, it illuminates the darkness of our ignorance with sudden light.
chunks.notes: Direct divine speech is visual/illuminative rather than auditory. Instantaneous (no delay of sequential words), sudden enlightenment replacing ignorance. Privileging sight over hearing in mystical theology: understanding through light metaphor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 5.) Cum per angelum voluntatem suam Dominus indicat, aliquando eam verbis, aliquando rebus demonstrat, aliquando simul verbis et rebus, aliquando imaginibus cordis oculis ostensis, aliquando imaginibus et ante corporeos oculos ad tempus ex aere assumptis, aliquando coelestibus substantiis, aliquando terrenis, aliquando simul terrenis et coelestibus. Nonnunquam per angelum Deus humanis cordibus ita loquitur, ut ipse quoque angelus mentis obtutibus praesentetur.
chunks.english: From the same section: When the Lord makes known His will through an angel, sometimes He demonstrates it by words, sometimes by things, sometimes by words and things together, sometimes by images shown to the eyes of the heart, sometimes by images assumed temporarily from the air before bodily eyes, sometimes by heavenly substances, sometimes by earthly ones, sometimes by earthly and heavenly together. Sometimes through an angel God speaks to human hearts in such a way that the angel himself is presented to the gaze of the mind.
chunks.notes: Comprehensive taxonomy of angelic mediation: eight modes listed. Will illustrate each with biblical examples in following chunks. Demonstrates scholastic systematization of Scripture's varied theophanies.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 4.) Verbis plerumque per angelum loquitur Deus, cum nihil in imagine ostenditur, sed supernae verba locutionis audiuntur, sicut dicente Domino: Pater, clarifica Filium tuum, ut et Filius tuus clarificet te, protinus respondetur: Clarificavi, et iterum clarificabo (Joan. XVII, 1).
chunks.english: From the previous section: God frequently speaks through an angel by words, when nothing is shown in image, but words of heavenly speech are heard—as when the Lord says in the Gospel of John chapter seventeen, verse one: 'Father, glorify your Son, so that your Son may glorify you,' and immediately it is answered: 'I have glorified, and I will glorify again.'
chunks.notes: First mode: words only, no visual image. Example: divine voice at Jesus' prayer (John 12:28 or 17:1). Voice heard but no form seen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omnipotens Deus, qui sine tempore vi impulsionis intimae clamat, nequaquam in tempore per suam substantiam illam vocem edidit, quam circumscriptam tempore per humana verba distinxit; sed nimirum de coelestibus loquens, verba sua quae audiri ab hominibus voluit rationali creatura administrante formavit.
chunks.english: Almighty God, who cries out without time by the force of intimate impulse, by no means uttered that voice in time through His own substance, which He articulated through human words circumscribed by time. But certainly, speaking from the heavens, He formed His words which He willed to be heard by men through the administering of a rational creature.
chunks.notes: Theological precision: timeless God does not speak temporally in His own substance. Temporal, articulated speech is mediated through rational creature (angel). Distinguishes eternal divine being from temporal creaturely manifestation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 5.) Aliquando rebus per angelos loquitur Deus, cum nil verbo dicitur, sed ea quae futura sunt assumpta de elementis imagine nuntiantur. Sicut Ezechiel (I, 4) verborum aenigmata audiens electri speciem in medio ignis vidit. Ut videlicet dum solam speciem aspiceret, quae essent in novissimis ventura sentiret.
chunks.english: From the same section: Sometimes God speaks through angels by things, when nothing is said in words, but things that will be are announced by an image assumed from the elements—as Ezekiel in chapter one, verse four, hearing enigmas of words, saw the appearance of electrum in the midst of fire, so that while beholding only the appearance, he might perceive what would come in the last times.
chunks.notes: Second mode: symbolic visions without words. Ezekiel's vision of electrum (amber/glowing metal) in fire. Image itself communicates prophetic meaning without verbal explanation. Apocalyptic visions fit this category.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 6.) Aliquando per angelos verbis simul et rebus loquitur Deus, cum quibusdam motibus insinuat hoc quod sermonibus narrat.
chunks.english: From the same section: Sometimes God speaks through angels by words and things together, when He insinuates by certain movements what He narrates by speeches.
chunks.notes: Third mode: words plus visual/symbolic actions combined. Movement or action accompanies and reinforces verbal message. Prophetic sign-acts would fit here.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 7.) Aliquando imaginibus cordis oculis ostensis per angelos loquitur Deus, sicut Jacob subnixam coelo scalam dormiens vidit (Gen. XXVIII, 12); sicut Petrus linteum reptilibus et quadrupedibus plenum in exstasi raptus aspexit (Act. X, 11). Qui nisi incorporeis haec oculis cerneret, in exstasi non fuisset.
chunks.english: From the same section: Sometimes God speaks through angels by images shown to the eyes of the heart, as Jacob saw a ladder reaching to heaven while sleeping in Genesis chapter twenty-eight, verse twelve; as Peter, caught up in ecstasy, beheld a sheet full of reptiles and four-footed animals in the Acts of the Apostles chapter ten, verse eleven. If he had not perceived these things with incorporeal eyes, he would not have been in ecstasy.
chunks.notes: Fourth mode: interior visions perceived by spiritual senses during sleep or ecstasy. Jacob's ladder and Peter's sheet: seen with 'eyes of heart' not bodily eyes. Ecstasy proves vision was interior, not physical.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aliquando imaginibus et ante corporeos oculos ad tempus ex aere assumptis per angelos loquitur Deus, sicut Abraham non solum tres viros videre potuit, sed etiam habitaculo terreno suscipere, et non solum suscipere, sed eorum usibus etiam cibos adhibere (Gen. XVIII, 2).
chunks.english: Sometimes God speaks through angels by images assumed temporarily from the air before bodily eyes, as Abraham not only could see three men, but also receive them in an earthly dwelling, and not only receive them, but also offer foods for their use in Genesis chapter eighteen, verse two.
chunks.notes: Fifth mode: temporary physical manifestations. Three visitors to Abraham: visible to bodily eyes, received hospitality, ate food. Angels temporarily assume aerial bodies for physical interaction.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancti angeli nisi quaedam nobis interna nuntiantes ad tempus ex aere corpora sumerent, exterioribus profecto nostris obtutibus non apparerent; nec cibos cum Abraham caperent, nisi propter nos solidum aliquid ex coelesti elemento gestarent.
chunks.english: Unless the holy angels, announcing certain interior things to us, took bodies temporarily from the air, they certainly would not appear to our exterior gazes. Nor would they take foods with Abraham unless they bore something solid from the heavenly element for our sake.
chunks.notes: Theological explanation: pure spirits invisible to bodily eyes. Must assume aerial or elemental bodies for physical appearance and interaction. Eating was real but 'for our sake' (accommodating human capacity), involving 'heavenly element' (not ordinary matter).

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 8.) Aliquando coelestibus substantiis per angelos loquitur Deus, sicut baptizato Domino scriptum est quia de nube vox sonuit dicens: Hic est Filius meus dilectus, in quo mihi complacui (Matth. III, 17).
chunks.english: From the same section: Sometimes God speaks through angels by heavenly substances, as when the Lord was baptized it is written that from the cloud a voice sounded saying in the Gospel of Matthew chapter three, verse seventeen: 'This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.'
chunks.notes: Sixth mode: heavenly elements as medium. Voice from cloud at Jesus' baptism: cloud is heavenly substance, voice mediated through it. Distinguishes heavenly (cloud, fire) from earthly (bush, animals) elements.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aliquando terrenis substantiis per angelos loquitur Deus, sicut cum Balaam corripuit, in ore asinae humana verba formavit (Num. XXII, 28).
chunks.english: Sometimes God speaks through angels by earthly substances, as when He rebuked Balaam, He formed human words in the mouth of a donkey in the book of Numbers chapter twenty-two, verse twenty-eight.
chunks.notes: Seventh mode: earthly creatures as medium. Balaam's talking donkey: earthly animal speaks human language through angelic agency. God uses lower creation to rebuke prophet.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aliquando simul terrenis et coelestibus substantiis per angelos loquitur Deus, sicut ad Moysem in monte cum jussionis suae verba edidit ignem rubumque sociavit (Exod. III, 2), atque aliud superius, aliud inferius junxit.
chunks.english: Sometimes God speaks through angels by earthly and heavenly substances together, as when He uttered the words of His command to Moses on the mountain, He joined fire and bush in the book of Exodus chapter three, verse two, and united one thing from above, another from below.
chunks.notes: Eighth mode: combination of heavenly and earthly. Burning bush: fire (heavenly) + bush (earthly) together. Upper and lower elements joined in single theophany. Most complex mode, synthesizing previous categories.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 9.) Nonnunquam Deus humanis cordibus etiam per angelos, secreta eorum praesentia, virtutem suae aspirationis infundit, unde Zacharias ait: Dixit ad me angelus, qui loquebatur in me (Zach. I, 14). Dum ad se quidem, sed tamen in se loqui angelum dicit, liquido ostendit quod is qui ad ipsum verba faceret per corpoream speciem extra non esset.
chunks.english: From the same section: Sometimes God, even through angels, by their hidden presence infuses the power of His inspiration into human hearts. Hence Zechariah says in chapter one, verse fourteen: 'The angel who was speaking in me said to me.' When he says that the angel spoke to him, but nevertheless in him, he clearly shows that the one who was making words to him was not outside by bodily appearance.
chunks.notes: Ninth mode (additional): interior angelic inspiration without external manifestation. Zechariah's phrase 'angel speaking in me' (not just 'to me'): angel present within, no external form. Interior locution mediated by angel but lacking physical manifestation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde et paulo post subdidit: Et ecce angelus, qui loquebatur in me, egrediebatur (Zach. II, 3). Saepe sancti angeli non exterius apparent, sed sicut sunt angelici spiritus, voluntatem Dei prophetarum sensibus innotescunt; atque ita eos ad sublimia sublevant, ut quaeque in rebus futura sunt, in causis originalibus praesentia demonstrent.
chunks.english: Whence also a little later he added in chapter two, verse three: 'And behold, the angel who was speaking in me was departing.' Often the holy angels do not appear outwardly, but as they are angelic spirits, they make known the will of God to the senses of prophets. And thus they lift them up to sublime things, so that they demonstrate as present in original causes whatever things will be in reality.
chunks.notes: Angel 'departing' from within confirms interior presence. Prophetic inspiration: angels as spiritual beings directly enlighten prophetic consciousness, elevating prophets to see future events in their eternal causes (divine ideas). Platonic-Augustinian epistemology: seeing temporal effects in eternal causes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Humanum videlicet cor ipso carnis corruptibilis pondere gravatum, ac ipsam corpulentiam suam quasi obicem sustinens interna non penetrat. Et grave exterius jacet, quia levantem manum interius non habet. Nonnunquam fit ut prophetarum sensibus ipsa ut est subtilitas angelicae virtutis appareat, eorumque mens quo spiritu subtili tangitur levetur. Et non jam torpens pigraque in imis jaceat, sed repleta intimis afflatibus ad superna conscendat, atque inde quasi de quodam rerum vertice quae infra se ventura sunt videat.
chunks.english: For the human heart, weighed down by the very weight of corruptible flesh, and sustaining its own corpulence as an obstacle, does not penetrate interior things. And it lies heavy outwardly because it does not have an uplifting hand inwardly. Sometimes it happens that to the senses of prophets the very subtlety of angelic power appears as it is, and their mind is lifted up by which subtle spirit it is touched. And no longer lying torpid and sluggish in the depths, but filled with intimate breathings, it ascends to the heights, and from there, as from a certain summit of things, it sees what will come below it.
chunks.notes: Anthropology: body weighs down spirit, corpulence obstructs interior vision. Angelic assistance: subtle angel touches prophet's mind, lifts it above bodily weight. Prophet ascends to metaphysical 'summit' to survey future events below. Vertical metaphor for epistemological transcendence enabled by angelic mediation.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Ways God Questions Human Beings
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XXXIX] Quibus modis Deus interroget hominem.
chunks.english: Chapter 39: The Ways God Questions Human Beings
chunks.notes: Parallel chapter to previous: as God speaks in various ways, He also questions in various ways. Will distinguish three modes of divine questioning.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Mor. XXVIII, c. 4, n. 15.) Deus omnipotens tribus modis humanum genus interrogare consuevit, cum aut flagelli districtione nos percutit, et quanta nobis insit vel desit patientia ostendit; aut quaedam quae nolumus praecipit, et nostram nobis obedientiam vel inobedientiam patefacit; aut aliqua nobis occulta aperit et aliqua abscondit, et mensuram nobis nostrae humilitatis innotescit.
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book twenty-eight, chapter four: Almighty God is accustomed to question the human race in three ways: either He strikes us with severity of scourging, and shows how much patience we have or lack; or He commands certain things we do not wish, and reveals to us our obedience or disobedience; or He opens certain hidden things to us and conceals others, and the measure of our humility is made known to us.
chunks.notes: Three modes of divine interrogation: (1) through suffering/tribulation testing patience, (2) through difficult commands testing obedience, (3) through partial revelation testing humility. Each mode reveals human spiritual condition to the person experiencing it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Flagello Deus hominem interrogat, cum mentem bene sibi per tranquillitatem subditam afflictionibus pulsat, sicut beatus Job et laudatur attestatione Judicis (Job. II, 3, 7), et tamen ictibus conceditur percussoris, ut ejus patientia tanto verius claresceret, quanto inquisita durius fuisset.
chunks.english: God questions man by scourging when He strikes with afflictions a mind well submitted to Him through tranquility—as blessed Job is both praised by the testimony of the Judge in the book of Job chapter two, verses three and seven, and yet is granted to the blows of the striker, so that his patience might shine forth all the more truly, the more harshly it had been tested.
chunks.notes: Job as example of first mode. God praises Job, yet permits Satan to afflict him. Purpose: patience shines brighter when tested harder. Divine 'questioning' through trial reveals (to Job and observers) depth of his virtue.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Praecipiendo nonnunquam dura nos interrogat Deus: sicut Abraham terram suam jubetur egredi (Gen. XII, 1. Ibid. 22, 2) et pergere quo nesciebat; in montem unicum filium ducere, et quem ad consolationem senex acceperat immolare (Gen. XXII, 2). Cui nimirum Abrahae ad interrogationem bene respondenti, id est, ad jussionem obedienti, dicitur: Nunc cognovi, quia times Deum (Ibid. 12).
chunks.english: Sometimes God questions us by commanding hard things—as Abraham is ordered to leave his land in the book of Genesis chapter twelve, verse one, and go where he did not know; to lead his only son to the mountain, and to sacrifice him whom he had received as an old man for consolation in chapter twenty-two, verse two. To this Abraham, responding well to the questioning—that is, obeying the command—it is said in verse twelve: 'Now I know that you fear God.'
chunks.notes: Abraham as example of second mode: difficult commands (leave home, sacrifice Isaac) test obedience. 'Now I know' = anthropomorphic divine speech; God's eternal knowledge expressed in temporal testing that reveals Abraham's fear of God to Abraham himself and to witnesses.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Vel sicut scriptum est: Tentat vos Dominus Deus vester, ut sciat si diligitis eum (Deut. XIII, 3). Tentare quippe Dei est magnis nos ejus jussionibus interrogare. Scire quoque ejus, nostram obedientiam nosse nos facere.
chunks.english: Or as it is written in the book of Deuteronomy chapter thirteen, verse three: 'The Lord your God tests you, that He may know whether you love Him.' For God's testing is to question us by His great commands. And His knowing is to make us know our own obedience.
chunks.notes: Deuteronomy text: 'that He may know' explained as making us know ourselves. Divine testing reveals human character to humans, not new information to omniscient God. Pedagogical, not epistemic purpose.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aperiendo nobis quaedam atque claudendo nos interrogat Deus, sicut per Psalmistam dicitur: Palpebrae ejus interrogant filios homiminium (Ps. X, 6). Palpebris quippe apertis cernimus, clausis nihil videmus. Quid ergo per palpebras Dei, nisi ejus judicia accipimus, quae juxta aliquid clauduntur hominibus, et juxta aliquid reserantur?
chunks.english: God questions us by opening certain things to us and closing others, as it is said through the Psalmist in Psalm ten, verse six: 'His eyelids question the sons of men.' For with eyelids open we see, with them closed we see nothing. Therefore what do we understand by the eyelids of God except His judgments, which are in one respect closed to men and in another respect opened?
chunks.notes: Third mode: partial revelation. Eyelids open/closed = some mysteries revealed, others concealed. This tests humility: can we handle both knowing and not knowing without pride or despair?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Homines qui se nesciunt, sibimet innotescunt; quatenus dum quaedam intelligendo comprehendunt, quaedam vero cognoscere omnino non possunt, eorum corda sese latenter inquirant, si illos divina judicia vel clausa non stimulant, vel aperta non inflant.
chunks.english: People who do not know themselves are made known to themselves, so that while they comprehend certain things by understanding, but altogether cannot know certain other things, their hearts may secretly examine themselves—whether the divine judgments, either closed or opened, neither goad them to presumption when closed, nor inflate them with pride when opened.
chunks.notes: Purpose of partial revelation: self-knowledge through testing response to mystery and knowledge. Properly humble response: neither frustrated by what's hidden, nor proud of what's revealed. Divine questioning reveals spiritual maturity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Paulus apostolus hac de interrogatione probatus est, qui post perceptam internam sapientiam, post aperta claustra paradisi, post ascensum coeli tertii, post supernae locutionis mysteria adhuc dicit: Ego me non arbitror comprehendisse (Philipp. III, 13). Et rursum: Ego sum minimus apostolorum, qui non sum dignus vocari apostolus (I Cor. XV, 9). Et rursum: Non quia sufficientes sumus cogitare aliquid a nobis quasi ex nobis, sed sufficientia nostra ex Deo est (II Cor. III, 5).
chunks.english: The apostle Paul was tested by this mode of questioning, who after receiving interior wisdom, after the barriers of paradise were opened, after ascending to the third heaven, after the mysteries of heavenly speech, still says in his letter to the Philippians chapter three, verse thirteen: 'I do not consider myself to have comprehended.' And again in his first letter to the Corinthians chapter fifteen, verse nine: 'I am the least of the apostles, who am not worthy to be called an apostle.' And again in his second letter to the Corinthians chapter three, verse five: 'Not that we are sufficient to think anything from ourselves as from ourselves, but our sufficiency is from God.'
chunks.notes: Paul as example: received extraordinary revelations (third heaven, paradise) yet remained humble. Three self-deprecating statements show he passed the test of partial knowledge. Despite great knowledge, maintained awareness of insufficiency.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Apertis ergo palpebris Dei interrogatus recte respondit, qui et superna secreta attigit, et tamen in humilitate cordis sublimiter stetit.
chunks.english: Therefore, questioned with the eyelids of God opened, he responded rightly—he who both touched heavenly secrets and yet stood sublimely in humility of heart.
chunks.notes: Paul with 'eyelids open': given great revelation, yet responded with humility. Paradox: stood 'sublimely' (high) through 'humility' (low). True spiritual height through lowliness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Rursum cum secreta Dei judicia de repulsione Judaeorum et gentilium vocatione Paulus discuteret, atque ad ea pervenire non posset, quasi clausis Dei palpebris interrogatus est; sed rectum valde responsum dedit, qui Deo sese in ipsa ignorantia scienter inclinavit, dicens: O altitudo divitiarum sapientiae et scientiae Dei, quam incomprehensibilia sunt judicia ejus, et investigabiles viae ejus! Quis enim cognovit sensum Domini, aut consiliarius ejus fuit (Rom. XI, 33)?
chunks.english: Again, when Paul was discussing the secret judgments of God concerning the rejection of the Jews and the calling of the Gentiles, and could not arrive at understanding them, he was questioned as if with the eyelids of God closed. But he gave a very right response—he who knowingly bowed himself to God in that very ignorance, saying in his letter to the Romans chapter eleven, verse thirty-three: 'O the depth of the riches of the wisdom and knowledge of God! How incomprehensible are His judgments, and how inscrutable His ways! For who has known the mind of the Lord, or who has been His counselor?'
chunks.notes: Paul with 'eyelids closed': faced divine mystery (election of Gentiles, rejection of Jews), could not understand. Right response: worship and humble confession of God's incomprehensibility. 'Knowingly bowed in ignorance' = learned ignorance, docta ignorantia.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ecce absconsis mysteriis idem Paulus quasi clausis palpebris inquisitus placita ac recta respondit: qui secreti aditum pulsans, quia per cognitionem intromitti ad interiora non valuit, per confessionem ante januas humilis stetit, et quod intus comprehendere non potuit foris timendo laudavit.
chunks.english: Behold, the same Paul, examined by hidden mysteries as if with closed eyelids, gave a pleasing and right response—he who, knocking at the entrance of the secret, because he could not be admitted to the interior through knowledge, stood humbly before the doors through confession, and what he could not comprehend within, he praised from without with fear.
chunks.notes: Beautiful image: Paul at door of divine mystery, cannot enter through knowledge, so stands outside in humble worship. What cannot be comprehended within can be praised from without. Apophatic theology: worship of the incomprehensible.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Synagogue and Israel Under the Law
chunks.latin: [CAPUT XL] De synagoga vel Israelitico populo sub lege constituto.
chunks.english: Chapter 40: The Synagogue and Israel Under the Law
chunks.notes: Final chapter. Theological assessment of Israel and Judaism from Christian perspective. Will discuss Israel's faithfulness before Christ, rejection after, contrast with Church.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XI, c. 16, n. 24, 25.) Ante incarnationem Domini Judaei veraces fuerunt, quia hunc venturum esse crediderunt atque nuntiaverunt. Sed postquam in carne apparuit, hunc esse negaverunt, quia quem venturum praedixerant negaverunt praesentem.
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book eleven, chapter sixteen: Before the incarnation of the Lord, the Jews were truthful, because they believed and announced that He would come. But after He appeared in the flesh, they denied that He was this One, because they denied as present the One whom they had predicted would come.
chunks.notes: Assesses Israel's status before and after Christ: faithful prophets became unfaithful rejectors. Christian supersessionist perspective typical of patristic era.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde recte beatus Job dicit: Commutans labium veracium, et doctrinam senum auferens (Job. XII, 20): quia nequaquam Judaei credendo secuti sunt quae patres suos praedixisse meminerunt.
chunks.english: Whence blessed Job rightly says in chapter twelve, verse twenty: 'Changing the lips of the truthful, and taking away the teaching of the elders'—because the Jews by no means followed in believing what they remembered their fathers had predicted.
chunks.notes: Job text applied to Jewish rejection of Jesus: they remembered patriarchs' prophecies but didn't believe fulfillment. 'Changing lips' = abandoning truth their ancestors spoke.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum Judaeorum populus in legis mandato permaneret, et cuncta gentilitas nulla Dei praecepta cognosceret, et illi per fidem principari videbantur, et isti in profundo pressi jacuerunt per infidelitatem. Sed cum incarnationis dominicae mysterium Judaea negavit, gentilitas credidit, et principes in despectione ceciderunt, et hi qui oppressi in culpa perfidiae fuerant, in verae fidei libertatem levati sunt.
chunks.english: When the people of the Jews remained in the commandment of the Law, and all the Gentiles knew no precepts of God, the former seemed to rule through faith, and the latter lay pressed down in the depths through unfaithfulness. But when Judea denied the mystery of the Lord's incarnation, the Gentiles believed, and the princes fell into contempt, and those who had been oppressed in the guilt of faithlessness were lifted up into the freedom of true faith.
chunks.notes: Reversal theology: Jews (formerly faithful leaders) fell, Gentiles (formerly unfaithful oppressed) rose through faith in Christ. Romans 9-11 theology of Israel's stumbling and Gentile inclusion.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Israelitarum casum longe ante Jeremias intuens, ait: Factus est Dominus velut inimicus: praecipitavit Israel; praecipitavit moenia ejus, dissipavit munitiones ejus (Thren. II, 5). Quia antiquus ille populus, qui fidelis esse Deo videbatur, reprobatus corde repul us est, ut, sua perfidia deceptus, contra ipsum post insurgeret quem ante praedicavit.
chunks.english: Jeremiah, seeing the fall of the Israelites long before, says in the Lamentations chapter two, verse five: 'The Lord has become like an enemy: He has cast down Israel; He has cast down its walls, He has scattered its fortifications.' Because that ancient people, who seemed to be faithful to God, with rejected heart was repulsed, so that, deceived by its own faithlessness, it afterward rose up against the very One whom it had previously preached.
chunks.notes: Lamentations applied prophetically to Jewish rejection of Christ. 'Became like enemy' = judgment on former covenant people. Rose against (crucified) the Messiah they had prophesied.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XIX, 23, n. 40.) Si Israeliticus populus a bono opere minime claudicasset, nequaquam voce Domini Psalmista dixisset: Filii alieni mentiti sunt mihi, filii alieni inveteraverunt, et claudicaverunt a semitis suis (Psalm. XVII, 46).
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book nineteen, chapter twenty-three: If the Israelite people had not limped at all from good work, the Psalmist would by no means have said in the voice of the Lord in Psalm seventeen, verse forty-six: 'The alien sons have lied to me, the alien sons have grown old, and they have limped from their paths.'
chunks.notes: Psalm applied to Israel: became 'alien sons' (estranged), lied (denied Messiah), grew old (in obsolete covenant), limped from paths (departed from righteousness). 'Limping' introduces next metaphor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Israeliticus populus claudus idcirco nominatur quia sanum gressum in operatione non habuit, quia utroque pede uti noluit, dum unum Testamentum recepit, aliud sprevit. Quem cum ad se venientem sancta Ecclesia suscipit, quia ei jam Vetus tenenti etiam Novum Testamentum inserit, ad dirigendos gressus illius quasi alterum pedem jungit.
chunks.english: The Israelite people are therefore called lame because they did not have sound footing in action, because they refused to use both feet, while they received one Testament and spurned the other. When the holy Church receives him coming to her, because she joins the New Testament to him already holding the Old, she joins as it were the other foot to direct his steps.
chunks.notes: Extended metaphor: two feet = Old and New Testaments. Israel 'lame' by accepting only Old Testament. Church 'heals' by adding New Testament, giving both feet for balanced walk. Envisions eventual Jewish conversion ('when Church receives him coming').

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Mor. XXXI, 15, n. 29.) Per unicornem bestiam potest Judaicus populus intelligi, qui dum de accepta Lege non opera, sed solam inter cunctos homines elationem sumpsit, quasi inter caeteras bestias cornu singulare gestavit.
chunks.english: From the Moralia, book thirty-one, chapter fifteen: By the unicorn beast the Jewish people can be understood, who, when from the received Law they took not works but only pride among all men, bore as it were a single horn among the other beasts.
chunks.notes: Unicorn as symbol of Jewish pride in Law. 'Single horn' = exclusive claim to divine revelation, but without corresponding righteous works. Proud boasting without performance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In loco Synagogae Dominus, ex qua per carnem natus est, sanctam Ecclesiam sibi in amore et contemplatione conjunxit, ut quae prius proxima ex cognatione, id est, cognita per praedestinationem fuerat, postmodum jam conjuncta in amore continuo uxor fiat.
chunks.english: In place of the Synagogue, from which He was born according to the flesh, the Lord joined to Himself the holy Church in love and contemplation, so that she who was previously near by kinship—that is, known through predestination—might afterward, already joined in continuous love, become a wife.
chunks.notes: Spousal imagery: Synagogue (bride) replaced by Church (new bride). Church was predestined (foreknown) even while Synagogue existed, then became actual bride after Christ. Replacement theology with spousal metaphor common in patristic and medieval exegesis.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ev., hom. 3, n. 1.) Synagoga idcirco ab auctore suo non recognoscitur, quia legis observationem tenens, spiritalem intellectum perdidit, et sese ad custodiam litterae foris fixit.
chunks.english: From book one on the Gospels, homily three: The Synagogue is therefore not recognized by its author, because while holding the observance of the Law, it lost the spiritual understanding, and fixed itself on the custody of the letter outwardly.
chunks.notes: Final assessment: Synagogue's rejection explained as literalism without spiritual understanding. Held to 'letter' (external observance) but lost 'spirit' (inner meaning pointing to Christ). Classic Christian critique of Jewish interpretation as merely literal. Ends work with supersessionist theology typical of patristic period.
